with thin leaves, Thphr. HP 9.11.4, Sor. 2.16, Anon.Vat. 16, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 118.30: Comp., Thphr. HP 3.9.5, 6.2.6.
with small, weak voice, Sapph. Oxy. 1231 Fr. 22.2, Arist. HA 538b13 ( Comp.).
thin-lipped, Arist. HA528a29; v.l. λεπτόχειλος, ον.
with delicate skin, dub. cj. in E. Fr. 906.
with thin or little juice, Thphr. CP 6.16.5 ( Comp.).
with fine sand, προστόμια A. Supp. 3 (anap.), as Pauw for λεπτομαθῶν.
with small spots, of red porphyry with white granules, Plin. HN 36.57.

definition: Λέπτυνις, ἡ, name for Persephone, Lyc. 49.

children.definition: attenuation, Hp. Prorrh. 2.25; αἱ τοῦ ὑγροῦ λ. evaporation, Hero Spir. 1 Praef. - τέον, one must reduce, τὸ πάχος Aët. 16.61.
of or for making thin, attenuating, Dsc. 5.88, Gal. 6.572, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 8.369d (also Comp., ib.e): c.gen., χυλὸς λ. αἵματος Id. ap. Ath. 8.356d; τὸ φῶς λ. τοῦ ἀέρος Stoic. 2.143.

definition: λεπτύνω, fut. -ῠνῶ LXX Ps. 17(18).42: aor. 1 ἐλέπτυνα Hp. Epid. 6.1.5:— Pass., aor. ἐλεπτύνθην Id. Aph. 5.46: pf. λελέπτυσμαι Id. Morb. 1.19, Arist. HA 511b22; inf. λελεπτύνθαι Ath. 12.552e: ( λεπτός): —

children.definition: make thin or meagre, αἱ ταλαιπωρίαι λ. [τὰ πρόβατα] Arist. HA 596a29, cf. Pr. 882a27; λ. τὸ σχῆμα [τῶν ταγμάτων] Plb. 3.113.8 (cf. λεπτυσμός) ; φωνὴν βαρεῖαν . . λεπτύνων Babr. 103.5:— Pass., to be reduced, grow lean or slender, Hp. Aph. 2.7, Arist. HA 518b29, al.; τοὺς ὤμους λεπτύνεσθαι X. Smp. 2.17; λελεπτυσμένος ( -ισμένος cod.) κατὰ τὴν οὐράν, of a serpent, Philum. Ven. 18.1; of things, to be rarefied, Damox. 2.28, cf. Ph. 1.642, S.E. M. 10.25.

comminute or liquefy food in digestion, Plu. QConv. 2.689d; - ύνουσα δίαιτα diet productive of thin humours, Gal. Vict.Att. 3:— Pass., become fluid, opp. παχύνεσθαι, of foods, Hp. VM 19; also -όμενα εἰς πνεῦμα διακρίνεται Arist. Pr. 966b14.
thresh, winnow, λ. Δηοῦς καρπόν AP 9.21.

definition: λεπτυξίς ἀπὸ τοῦ λέπους, καὶ τῆς χωρίσεως, Hsch.

children.definition: thinning, Hp. Epid. 6.3.16; τριχῶν Dsc. 5.112; esp. of the line of battle, Ael. Tact. 38.3.
to be contained in a husk, Sch. Nic. Th. 802.
small husk, thin peel, etc., Hp. Nat.Puer. 22, Arist. HA 546b20, Theoc. 5.95; egg-shell, Hp. Nat.Puer. 13.
strip off the husk ( λεπυριῶσαι· ἐξαχυριῶσαι), Hsch.
like husks, consisting of coats or layers, like the onion, Arist. HA 546b30, Thphr. HP 4.6.2, 7.9.4, al.; cf. λεπυρώδης.
rind, shell, husk, Batr. 131, LXX Ca. 4.3, Dsc. Eup. 1.89, Porph. Gaur. 17.7.
in a husk, peel, rind, γενέθλη Nic. Th. 136; ἀθέρων στάχυς ib. 803.
Thphr. HP 1.6.7.
coat of an onion, etc., Theopomp.Com. 33, Plu. QConv. 2.684a, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.256, 445; rind, ῥοᾶς Dsc. Eup. 1.74.

definition: λέπω, fut. λέψω ( ἀπο-) prob. in E. Cyc. 237; Ep. inf. ἀπο-λεψέμεν Il. 21.455: aor. ἔλεψα 1.236, Nic. Fr. 82:— Med., Alex. 49:— Pass., fut. λᾰπήσομαι ( ἐκ-) Hp. ( Nat.Puer. 29) ap. Erot.: aor. 2 λᾰπῆναι Hsch., ( ἐκ-) Ar. Fr. 164: pf. λέλεμμαι ( ἀπο-) Epich. 158, but λέλαμμαι IG 2(2).463.68:—

children.definition: strip off the rind or husks, peel, bark, περὶ γάρ ῥά ἑ χαλκὸς ἔλεψε φύλλα τε καὶ φλοιόν Il. 1.236; κρόμμυον λ. Eup. 255; κυάμου κολοκάσιον Nic. l.c.:— Pass., κάλαμος λελαμμένος IG l.c.

data.quote: περὶ γάρ ῥά ἑ χαλκὸς ἔλεψε φύλλα τε καὶ φλοιόν

children.label: II
children.definition: give a hiding to, i.e. thrash, Pl.Com. 12, Timocl. 29, Apollod.Car. 5.10 ( Pass.); Ἀφροδίτην PBerol. 13426 (Gercke-Norden Einleitung 31(9)p.42).
eat, Antiph. 135; Phot. cites λέπτει (sic) = κατεσθίει from Eup. ( Fr. 427).

children.label: III
children.definition: Med., = δέφομαι: hence, indulge in indecent gestures, Alex. 49, Mnesim. 4.18 (anap.).
bare, windswept, etym. of ἑλεσπίς, EM 328.24.

Lerna, a marsh in Argolis, the mythol. abode of the Hydra, Plu. Cleom. 15, Paus. 2.4.5; also Λέρνη, Cratin. 347, Str. 8.6.8, etc.: gen. Λέρνης A. Pr. 652, etc.: prov., Λέρνη κακῶν an abyss of ills, Hsch.; so Λ. θεατῶν, of the theatre, Cratin. l.c.:— Adj. Λερναῖος, α, ον, Hes. Th. 314, etc.; also ος, ον E. Ion 191 (lyr.):— Λερναία χολή, of malignant anger, Trag.Adesp. 229.

definition: λέρος, ὁ, a fish, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.14.

children.definition: president of the council of Lesbos, IGRom. 3.87 ( Amastris).
do like the Lesbian women, Lat. fellare, Ar. Ra. 1308, Luc. Pseudol. 28.

definition: Λεσβίζω, = foreg., in Att. fut. - ιεῖν, Ar. V. 1346 codd. (leg. - ιᾶν).

children.definition: Lesbian woman, Il. 9.271, cf. Pherecr. 149:—also Λεσβ-ιάς, άδος, Hermesian. 7.52, AP 9.26 ( Antip.Thess.).

Lesbos, Il. 24.544, Od. 4.342, etc.; the seventh in magnitude of islands known to the Greeks, Alex. 268.6:—hence Adv. Λεσβ-όθεν, from Lesbos, Il. 9.664; Λεσβ-όθι, at Lesbos, EM 25.15:— Adj. Λέσβιος, α, ον, Sapph. 92, Hdt. 1.23, etc.: prov., μετὰ Λέσβιον ᾠδόν, of those who are judged second best, Cratin. 243; Λέσβιον κῦμα or κυμάτιον, v. κῦμα I.3, A. Fr. 78, Vitr. 4.6.2; so τὸ Λέσβιον (without κ.) PCair.Zen. 445.11 (iii B.C.); Λεσβία οἰκοδομία Arist. EN 1137b30; Λ. πώματος οὐκ ἔστιν ἄλλος οἶνος ἡδίων πιεῖν Alex. 274, cf. Philyll. 24; ἡδίων ὁ Λ. (sc. οἶνος), with a play on words, indicating a preference for Theophrastus (of Lesbos) over Eudemus (of Rhodes), Arist. ap. Gell. 13.5.

data.quote: Λ. πώματος οὐκ ἔστιν ἄλλος οἶνος ἡδίων πιεῖν

children.label: II
children.definition: Λέσβιον, τό,
ἡ δευτέρα τρόπις acc. to Poll. 1.85.
drinking-cup, Hedyl. ap. Ath. 11.486b.

definition: λέσπιν μεγάλην. ὑδρηλήν. Δίδυμος τὴν καταδυομένην εἰς πέλαγος πέτραν. οἱ δὲ τὴν νοτεράν. ἄλλοι δὲ σπίδα βαθεῖαν. οἱ δὲ λόχμην, Hsch.

children.definition: prate, chatter, κακὰ λ. Thgn. 613.
= foreg., -ουσά τε καὶ ἀκούουσα καλά Perict. ap. Stob. 4.28.19, cf. Call. Fr. 98b.

definition: Λεσχανάσιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), a month at Tegea, IG 5(2).3.
λεσχάραι οἷον αἱ σχολαί, κτλ. (cf. sq. [λέσχη]), EM 561.17.
λέσχη, ἡ, (prob. from *λέχ-σκη, cf. λέχος) orig.

children.definition: couch: hence, funeral bier or tomb, IG 12(1).709 ( Camirus); then,

lounging place, resort of idlers or beggars, οὐδʼ ἐθέλεις εὕδειν χαλκήϊον ἐς δόμον ἐλθὼν ἠέ που ἐς λέσχην Od. 18.329; πὰρ δʼ ἴθι χάλκειον θῶκον καὶ ἐπαλέα λέσχην Hes. Op. 493, cf. 501; κατίζων ἐν ταῖς λ. τῶν γερόντων Ps.- Hdt. Vit.Hom. 12.

data.quote: οὐδʼ ἐθέλεις εὕδειν χαλκήϊον ἐς δόμον ἐλθὼν ἠέ που ἐς λέσχην
πὰρ δʼ ἴθι χάλκειον θῶκον καὶ ἐπαλέα λέσχην

children.definition: public building or hall, used as a lounge or meeting-place, esp. at Sparta and in other Doric cities, Cratin. 164 (pl.), cf. Paus. 3.14.2, Plu. Lyc. 16, 24 (pl.); also in Attica, IG 1(2).888, 2.1055.23, Procl.ad Hes. Op. 491; at Delphi, hall adorned with paintings by Polygnotus, Luc. Im. 7, Paus. 10.25.1; at Cnidus, council-chamber, Plu. Def.orac. 2.412d, cf. Aet.Gr. 298d; of the council of the Olympian gods, Ζεὺς ἇς λέσχας ἀπηξιώσατο (sc. τὰς Ἐρινῦς) A. Eu. 366 (lyr.); also σύγκλητον τήνδε γερόντων λ. this specially summoned council, S. Ant. 161 (anap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: talk or gossip, such as went on in the λέσχαι (cf. λεσχηνεύω, etc.), μακραὶ λ. E. Hipp. 384, cf. IA 1001 (pl.), Epicr. 11.32 (pl., anap.), LXX Pr. 23.29 (pl.), AP 13.6 ( Phal.); in bad sense, malicious gossip, scandal, Vett.Val. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).165 (pl.); also in good sense, conversation, discussion, γενομένης λ., ὃς γένοιτο . . ἄριστος Hdt. 9.71; ἐκ λόγων ἄλλων ἀπικέσθαι ἐς λ. περὶ τοῦ Νείλου Id. 2.32; λόγον εἴ τινʼ οἴσεις πρὸς ἐμὰν λ. if thou hast aught to discuss with me, S. OC 167 (lyr.); αἶσαν λέσχης οἶνος ἔχειν ἐθέλει Call. Aet. 1.1.16 [Fr. 178.16 Pf.]; ἥλιον ἐν λέσχῃ κατεδύσαμεν Id. Epigr. 2.3; λύω λέσχας, ‘cut the cackle’, prov. for breaking off discussion and setting to work in earnest, Pl.Com. 223.

data.quote: ἐκ λόγων ἄλλων ἀπικέσθαι ἐς λ. περὶ τοῦ Νείλου

children.definition: gossip, v.l. in Hp. Ep. 17 (pl.).
chat, πολλὰ τοῖσιν ἰδιώτῃσιν Hp. Decent. 7.
chatterer, Timo 46.
gossip, Pl. Ax. 369d.
gossip, chatterer, Ath. 14.649c.

chat or converse with, τοῖς πρέσβεσι App. BC 2.91:— Med., Heraclit. 5, Democr. 85, Hp. Decent. 7 (v.l.), Prorrh. 2.4, Morb. 1.19, Nic.Dam. 3 J.: — Hdt. has the compds. περιλεσχήνευτος, προλεσχηνεύομαι.
Suid.

guardian of the meetings in the λέσχαι, Cleanth.Stoic. 1.123, Plu. E apud Delph. 2.385c, Corn. ND 32:— Dor. Λεσχᾱνόριος, ὁ (sc. μήν), a month in Thessaly, IG 9(2).509, al.; in Crete, - ορία [νεμονηΐα] Supp.Epigr. 1.410 (iv B.C.).
scholar, pupil, Thales ap. D.L. 1.43, Anaximen. ib. 2.4. (On the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.74.)
superfluity of words, PMag.Par. 1.2085.
given to scandal, Vett.Val. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).169.

definition: λεσῶνις, PAmh. 2.35.11 (ii B.C.); gen. - ώνιος ib. 41.15 (ii B.C.); dat. - ώνει ib. 40.1 (ii B.C.); later gen - ώνου Sammelb. 6154.31 (i B.C.), dat. -ώνῃ BGU 37v (i A.D.): ὁ:—

children.definition: chief administrator of a temple in Egypt, ll.cc.:—hence λεσωνεία, ἡ, his office, PAmh. 2.35.30 (ii B.C.), Wilcken Chr. 92 i 13 (ii/iii A.D.):—written λεσονία, BGU 719.10 (i/ii A.D.). (Egypt. mr šn = ἀρχιερεῖς.)

definition: λετμός ἀναδρήσσει· τὸ σῶμα <Ἀ>μερίας φησί, Hsch. λετωνῆσαι· ἀφειδῶς παῖσαι κατὰ τῶν ἰσχίων, Id.

children.definition: in sad or sorry plight, wretched, πτωχῷ λ. ἐναλίγκιον Od. 16.273; λ. ἐσόμεσθα 2.61. Adv. - έως, χωρεῖν to go in ill plight, Il. 13.723.

children.label: II
children.definition: sore, baneful, νῦν δέ με λ. θανάτῳ εἵμαρτο ἁλῶναι, i.e. by drowning, 21.281, cf. Od. 15.359; κήδεσιν . . λευγαλέοισι ib. 399; ἄλγεσι λ. 20.203; πολέμοιο μεθήσετε λ. Il. 13.97; ἐν δαῒ λ. 14.387; φρεσὶ λ. πιθήσας 9.119; λ. ἐπέεσσιν 20.109; ἤθεα λ. Hes. Op. 525; ποινή ib. 754; κόρος Thgn. 1174; ἀνῖαι A.R. 1.295; κέντρον Nic. Th. 836.
λ. χιτών sorry tunic, Philet. 17.
λευγαλέα· διάβροχος, Phot., cf. EM 561.28 (prob. an error due to misunderstanding of S. Fr. 785).

definition: λεύγη, ἡ, a measure of milk, Hsch.

children.definition: Levite, Ev.Luc. 10.32, Plu. QConv. 2.671f:—fem. Λευῖτις, φυλή v.l. in J. AJ 3.11.1; Λευῑτικός, ή, όν, Ep.Hebr. 7.11; τὸ -κόν, title of book of VT.

definition: Λευκαθέα, ἡ, goddess worshipped in Thessaly (

children.definition: IG 9(2).422 ( Pherae), Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1910.380 ( Larissa).

children.label: II
children.definition: Λευκάθεα, τά, festival at Teos, CIG 3066.25:—hence Λευκᾰθ-εών, ῶνος (sc. μήν), ὁ, month at Chios, GDI 5661.25 (iv B.C.); at Teos, Supp.Epigr. 2.579.21 (iv B.C.); at Magnesia on Maeander, Inscr.Magn. 89.6:— also Λευκᾰθ-ιών, at Lampsacus, CIG 3641b17; Λευκᾰθ-εος, at Astypalaea, SIG 780 (i B.C.).
Hes. Sc. 146 ( ὀδόντων . . λευκὰ θεόντων codd.).

to be white, Hdt. 8.27 (codd. opt.), PLeid.X. 84, Gloss.; of spots on the body, LXX Le. 13.38; [ τρίχες] λευκαθίζουσαι Babr. 22.9; αἶγες χιόνι λ. Id. 45.3, cf. Ael. NA 17.8, 9; λ. οἱ λόφοι, of snow-clad hills, Alciphr. 3.30; οἰκία λ. γύψῳ Epict. Gnom. 43; of fluids in the eye, to be colourless, Cass. Pr. 27; of eyes, S.E. P. 1.44:— Pass., λελευκαθισμένη clad in white, LXX Ca. 8.5. ( λευκανθ- is read in Babr., but is against the metre, also in Ael., Alciphr., Epict., Cass., and S.E., and is v.l. in Hdt. l.c., LXX Ca. l.c.; cf. λευκαθέω, ὑπολευκαθίζω.)

definition: λευκαία, ἡ, a synonym (perh. a variety) of σπάρτος, used for cordage or tackle, Moschio ap. Ath. 5.206f:—written λευκέα in BGU 544.5 (ii A.D.), Artem. 3.59 (who dists. it from κάνναβις), Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: λευκαίας στέφανος IG 12(1).155 iii 79, iv 118:—hence Λευκαῖος Ζεύς, Zeus of the white poplar, Paus. 5.5.5.

definition: λευκαίνω, late aor. 1 inf. λευκᾶναι (v. infr.): pf. Pass. λελεύκασμαι Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 2.54b, Orib. Fr. 102:—

children.definition: make white, λεύκαινον ὕδωρ ξεστῇς ἐλάτῃσιν Od. 12.172; ἅλα ῥοθίοισι λ. E. Cyc. 17; ἐς γένυν ἕρπει λευκαίνων ὁ χρόνος Theoc. 14.70; plaster with whitening, λευκᾶναι τὰ λευκώματα Ephes. 3p.148:— Pass., to be or become white, Arist. GA 730a6, Sopat. 8, A.R. 1.545, Diph.Siph. l.c.; to be clarified, of oil, Orib. l.c.

data.quote: ἐς γένυν ἕρπει λευκαίνων ὁ χρόνος

children.definition: cause to appear white, of the effect of dawn on lamplight, E. IA 157 (anap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., have a sensation of whiteness, S.E. M. 7.191, al.

children.label: III
children.definition: grow white, E. Hyps.Fr. 34(60) i13, Arist. Pr. 890a9, LXX Le. 13.19; ἀφροῖο with foam, Nic. Al. 170.
white thistle, Tyrimnus leucographus, Thphr. HP 6.4.3, Plin. HN 21.94 (v. infr.).
tuberous thistle, Cnicus tuberosus, Dsc. 3.19, Gal. 12.58, Plin. HN 22.40:—in form λευκ-άκανθος, ἡ, ib. 21.94, v.l. in Gal. 6.623.
rich in pearl-barley, Sopat. 3.
with white headband, πῦρ Opp. H. 4.238.
white-flower, like χρυσάνθεμον, name of several plants of the genus Anthemis, Dsc. 3.137, Plin. HN 21.163:— also λευκ-ανθεμίς, ίδος, ἡ, ib. 22.53.
white-blossoming, Nic. Th. 530: generally, blanched, white, καπνός Pi. N. 9.23 (dub.); λ. κάρα S. OT 742, cf. AP 12.165 ( Mel.).

definition: λευκανίων (?), dub. sens. in PSI 8.944.5 (iv A.D.).

children.definition: a growing white, Arist. Ph. 224b15, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 304.1; clarification of oil, Gal. 11.484.
one must bleach, κηρόν Dsc. 2.83.
one who makes or paints white, Gloss.
of or for whitening, δύναμις Sch. Pl. Tht. 156d. Adv. - κῶς, διατεθῆναι have a sensation of whiteness, S.E. M. 7.192.
bright-orbed, of the moon, Doroth. ap. Heph.Astr. 3.20.
of or with white clay, Str. 9.5.19: as Subst., leucargilion, white clay, Plin. HN 17.42.

definition: λευκάς, άδος, fem. of λευκός: Λ. πέτρη as pr.n. of mythical and real promontories, Od. 24.11, Anacr. 19, cf. E. Cyc. 166; Λ. alone, Th. 1.30, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: λ. ὀρεινή mountain dead-nettle, Lamium maculatum, Dsc. 3.99; λ. ἥμερος dead-nettle, L. Moschatum, ibid.
ἤρυγγος, white, Nic. Th. 849.
PHolm. 3.6.

white-shielded, of a Trojan, Il. 22.294; of the Carians, X. HG 3.2.15; of a Maced. corps, Plu. Cleom. 23; in Trag. esp. of the Argives, A. Th. 89 (lyr.), S. Ant. 106 (lyr.), E. Ph. 1099; κόραι λ. Lyr.Adesp. 68.
white-gleaming, of a fish, Antiph. 217.20.
white agate, Plin. HN 37.139.

definition: λευκελεφάντινα λευκὰ ὡς ἐλεφάντινα, Hsch. ( λεύκʼ ἐλέφαντι Valck. from Il. 5.583).

children.definition: white fig-tree, Ath. 3.76c: also as Adj., of the fruit, λ. ἰσχάδες Hermipp. 68.
whitish red, χροιαί Arist. Phgn. 806b4; of persons, Ptol. Tetr. 143.
white heron or spoonbill, Platalia leucorodius, Arist. HA 593b2.
leprosy or elephantiasis, λέπρην ἢ λεύκην ἔχειν Hdt. 1.138; λειχῆνες καὶ λέπραι καὶ λεῦκαι Hp. Prorrh. 2.43; λ. ἀλφούς τε Pl. Ti. 85a; [ ἐξάνθημα] ὃ καλεῖται λ. Arist. HA 518a13, cf. Pr. 891a26.

children.label: II
children.definition: white poplar, Populus alba, Thphr. HP 1.10.1, al.; used for chaplets, Ar. Nu. 1007, Eup. 14.4, D. 18.260, Theoc. 2.121; later λεύκη λευκή Hippiatr. 22.
poplar in the place, And. 1.133.

children.label: IV
children.definition: white spots on the nails, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.146.

children.label: V
children.definition: κόγχοι, = ἀνδροφυκτίδες, Epich. 42.11.

children.label: VII
children.definition: white clay or chalk, Gloss.
chestnuts from Λευκαί (or Λεῦκαι) on Mt. Ida, Gal. 6.778.
white-livered, i.e. cowardly, Com.Adesp. 1072.
with white soil, [ πέτραι] Gp. 2.6.39.
with white oars, Ἄρης E. IA 283 (lyr.).
white, blanched, θρίξ A. Pers. 1056, dub. in PFay. 2 iii 32 (Lyr., ii A.D.).

definition: Λευκιανή, ἡ, epith. of Artemis, BCH 12.269 ( Panamara).

children.definition: of white poplar, στέφανοι Arist. Oec. 1353b27; μύρον Gal. 13.631.
decorated with chaplets of white poplar, OGI 266.14 ( Pergam., iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: λευκαία 1) of hemp, σχοινία Hsch. s.v. μασχάλην.
daughters of Leucippus, nymphs worshipped at Sparta, κόραι Λ. E. Hel. 1466 (lyr.), cf. Paus. 3.13.7.
riding or driving white horses, Ibyc. 16, Stesich. 86, Pi. P. 4.117, S. El. 706; of Persephone, Pi. O. 6.95; λ. Ἀώς B. Scol.Oxy. 24.
λ. ἀγυιαί full of white horses, Pi. P. 9.83.
white mullet, Hices. ap. Ath. 7.306e, Gal. 6.713.
Theoc. 5.147.
with white arms or shoulders, Suid. s.v. λευκώλενος, Sch.D Il. 1.55.

definition: λευκόγειος, ον, Thphr. CP 2.4.4, Hsch. s.v. ἄργιλος; λευκο-γέως, ων, Str. 9.5.18, Eust. 332.21 ( v.l. λευκόγαιος):—

children.definition: of or with white earth, ll. cc.
paint in white on a coloured ground, Arist. Po. 1450b2.
painting in white, Phlp. in Mete. 74.22.
clay for painting white, Plin. HN 27.103; = μόροχθος λίθος, Dsc. 5.134, Aët. 2.16.
ossifragus, Gloss.

definition: λευκοδέρματος, ον, gloss on sq., Hsch.

children.definition: with a white skin, Hsch.
Melissa Ep. 11.1.
Procl. Par.Ptol. 203.

definition: λευκόζωτος τῆς γῆς ἡ μὲν καλεῖται λ., ἡ δὲ μελάνζωτος, Hsch.

children.definition: the white goddess (cf. Λευκαθέα), name of the sea-goddess Ino, Od. 5.334, Pi. P. 11.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: λ., ἡ, the faculty of seeing white, Aristo Stoic. 1.86.

definition: Λευκόθιον, τό, name of a building in Delos, IG ΙΙ(2).154 A 24, al. (iii B.C.).

children.definition: a white Bithynian vine, Gp. 5.17.4.
white-haired, white, λευκότριχα κριόν Ar. Av. 971; λευκοτρίχων πλοκάμων E. Ba. 112 (lyr.); -τριχες ἵπποι Call. Cer. 121; τῶν λευκοτρίχων Arist. GA 786a24; λ. πρόβατα Str. 16.4.26.
with white cuirass, X. An. 1.8.9.
white house, PLond. 2.405.12 (iv A.D.).
made of λευκόϊον, Thphr. Od. 27, cf. Philonid. ap. Ath. 15.675e (- όϊον codd.); ὁ λ. (sc. στέφανος) AP 11.34 ( Phld.):— written λευκόϊος, Apollon. Mir. 45 (s.v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: of the colour of λευκόϊον, δεῖγμα POxy. 113.5 (ii A.D.).

definition: λευκόϊον [ ῐ], τό, for λευκὸν ἴον, lit.

children.definition: white-violet:

children.label: I
children.definition: gilliflower, Matthiola incana, Theoc. 7.64, Dsc. 3.123, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: snowdrop, Galanthus nivalis, flowering very early, Thphr. HP 6.8.1; joined with the narcissus and lily in AP 5.143 ( Mel.), 146 ( Id.).

children.label: III
children.definition: λ. τὸ μέλαν, = ἴον τὸ μέλαν, Hp. Nat.Mul. 32.
yielding white fruit, Thphr. HP 3.18.6.
white-stalked, Thphr. HP 7.4.6: Comp., ib. 5.
Hsch.
Hsch.
made of white wax, Hsch. s.v. Δατύς.
white-legged, Anatolius in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(3).188.13.
white-haired, Poll. 4.139.
white cabbage, Gp. 12.1.4.

definition: λεύκοκρας λευκοκέφαλος, Hsch.: pl. - κρατες ( -κέρατες cod.) · ἢ διὰ τὸ τοὺς ἐν Εὐβοίᾳ βοῦς λευκοὺς εἶναι, ἢ ἴσως ἀντὶ τοῦ λαμπρούς, Id.

children.definition: white with waves or surf, ᾐόνες E. Or. 992 (lyr.).

made of white marble, ἔργα Supp.Epigr. 4.270 ( Panamara); τὰ ἐν τῷ θεάτρῳ λ. OGI 510 ( = Ephes. 2 No.39, ii A.D.); στήλη, στάλα λ., IPE 12.40.42 ( Olbia), al.; κρηπίς Str. 5.3.8; στοαί Id. 12.5.3: as Subst., -λίθου στάλᾳ IPE 12.357 ( Chersonesus).
white flax for ropes and rigging, used esp. by the Phoenicians, Hdt. 7.25, 34, 36, Ael. NA 5.3.

definition: λευκολόφας, ᾱ, ὁ, = sq. 1, E. Ph. 119 (lyr.).

children.definition: white-crested, Anacr. 82, Ar. Ra. 1016, Philet. 4.

children.label: II
children.definition: τοῦτʼ ἀνὰ λευκόλοφον prob. on this white hill, AP 7.636 ( Crin.).
the white sprat ( μαινίς), Polioch. 1.
with white wool, Eust. 403.44.
grey, Hdn. Epim. 163, Tz.ad Lyc. 334.
with a white forehead, Hippiatr. 104, Hsch. s.v. φαλαρός.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., name of a bird, PPetr. 3p.152 (iii B.C.), PGrenf. 2.14b3 (iii B.C.), etc.; λ. ἄγριος PMag.Par. 1.2395, 3148, cf. 2.209 (prob.).
pale-yellow, ἔμπλαστρος Gal. 13.460.
white and mouse-coloured, BGU 1258.22 (ii B.C.); esp. of asses, ib. 1066.6 (i A.D.), PLond. 2.303.16 (ii A.D.):—also λευκό-χρως, BGU 228.4 (ii/iii A.D.).
with white navel or centre, of fig-trees, Thphr. CP 5.1.8.
white, as a colour, τὸ λ. οἶδεν knows white from black, Ar. Eq. 1279; opp. μέλαν, Pl. Prt. 331d.
a white dress, λευκὸν ἀμπέχει are dressed in white, Ar. Ach. 1024; ἠμφιεσμένη λευκά Id. Th. 840.
white of egg, Hp. Nat.Mul. 32, Arist. GA 753a35, Dsc. 2.50.
τὰ λ. the whites of the eyes, Hp. Prog. 2, Alex. 222.9, cf. Arist. HA 492a1.
τὰ λ. the menstrua alba of young girls, Id. GA 738a26, HA 581b2; more generally, Hp. Prorrh. 1.80, Epid. 4.22.
white formation in testaceans, Arist. HA 529a3.
the south wind which cleared the weather (for the usual νότος brought rain), Arist. Mete. 362a14: distd. from λιβόνοτος, Gal. 16.410, 17(1).655.

definition: λευκοοινάριον, τό, inscription of amphorae at Pompeii, CIL 4 Suppl. 6564, al. (written λευκουν-).

children.definition: with white fruit, AP 9.563 ( Leon.).
fair-cheeked, AP 5.159 ( Mel.).
with white-edged robe, Alexander Magnus ap. Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.180e.
pale-grey, Erot. s.v. τὸ χρῶμα ἀφυῶδες.
white-robed, Corinn. 20: metaph., ἡμέρη λ., Lat. dies albo notandus, Hippon. 32.
white-leaved, Poet. de herb. 8.
white-armed, only in acc. pl. - πήχεις, E. Ph. 1351 (lyr.), and dat. pl. - πήχεσι, Id. Ba. 1206.
with white sides, Sch. Theoc. 4.45.
full of persons in white, ἐκκλησία Ar. Ec. 387.
clad in white down to the feet, in acc. - ήρην, Zos.Alch. p.117 B.
motley-white, Sch. Theoc. 4.45.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., λ., ἡ, name of a gem, Plin. HN 37.171.
that makes white, Sch. S. Aj. 624.

definition: λευκόπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: white-footed, bare-footed, Βάκχαι E. Cyc. 72 (lyr.), cf. Ar. Lys. 665, Anacreont. 8.5.
with white πρωκτός, a play on the words εὐρύπρωκτος and λευκός II.1c, conveying a notion of cowardice, Call.Com. 11 (s.v.l.).
white-winged, of a ship, E. Hipp. 752 (lyr.): generally, white, νιφάς A. Pr. 993; Ἁμέρα E. Tr. 848 (lyr.).

definition: λευκοπτέρυξ, ῠγος, ὁ, ἡ, = foreg., prob. l. in Ion Eleg. 10.

children.definition: Alex. 321.
fine wheat, in pl., Ph. 1.614, 669.
pale-red, τριχώματα Arist. Col. 797b13; prob. to be read for λευκόπυρον μάλαγμα, Gal. 13.984.
with white horses, ἡμέρα A. Pers. 386, S. Aj. 673; τέθριππον Plu. Cam. 7; epith. of the Dioscuri (cf. λεύκιππος), Pi. P. 1.66; at Thebes also of Amphion and Zethus, E. HF 29; θεοί Id. Ph. 606.
rose-pink, Sammelb. 7033.37 (v A.D.).
the white rose, Gloss.
white-nosed, of a horse, Hippiatr. 104.
a fish (cf. λευκίσκος), Theoc. Beren. 4, cf. Arist. HA 567a20.

definition: Λεῦκος, ὁ, divinity at Miletus, Schwyzer 725 (vi B.C.).

children.definition: light, bright, clear (opp. μέλας in all senses), αἴγλη Od. 6.45; λευκὸν (v.l. λαμπρόν) . . ἠέλιος ὥς Il. 14.185; λ. φάος S. Aj. 708 (lyr.), cf. infr. II.3; αἰθήρ E. Andr. 1228 (anap.); of metallic surfaces, λέβης Il. 23.268; λ. γαλήνη a glassy calm, Od. 10.94; of water, clear, limpid, Il. 23.282, Od. 5.70, A. Supp. 23 (anap.); λ. νᾶμα E. HF 573; -ότατος ποταμῶν Call. Jov. 19.

clear, distinct, of the voice, Arist. Top. 106a25, S.E. M. 6.41: in literary sense, clear, λ. στίχος AP 11.347 ( Phil.): prov., λευκὸς Ἑρμῆς, when a rogue was detected, Macar. 5.53. Adv. - κῶς, πάντα φαίνειν, of Hermes, Corn. ND 16: Comp. - ότερον, διαλεχθῆναι Hld. 7.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: white, freq. in Hom., varying from the pure white of snow ([ ἵπποι] -ότεροι χιόνος Il. 10.437) to the grey of dust ( λευκοὶ ἐγένοντο κονισάλῳ 5.503); γάλα λ. 4.434; κρῖ 5.196; ἄλφιτα 18.560; ἡνία λεύκʼ ἐλέφαντι 5.583; ὀδόντες 10.263; ὀστέα 16.347; ἱστία 1.480; φᾶρος 18.353, etc.; λ. ἅρμα, = λεύκιππον, E. Ph. 172; of the white horses used by tyrants, λ. ζεῦγος D. 21.158, cf. λεύκιππος; λ. λίθος marble, OGI 219.36 ( Sigeum, iii B.C.), etc., cf. λευκόλιθος; λευκῷ<ν>λίθῳ λ. στάθμη a white line on a white stone, prov. of explanations which do not explain, S. Fr. 330; ἡ λ. ῥίζα white root (= ἡ τοῦ δρακοντίου, acc. to Gal. 19.118), Hp. Morb. 2.48, Nat.Mul. 32; freq. of white or grey hair, λ. κάρη Tyrt. 10.23; θρίξ S. Ant. 1092; λ. γῆρας Id. Aj. 625 (lyr.); λευκὰ γήρᾳ σώματα E. HF 909, etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: white, fair, sts. as a sign of youth and beauty, χρώς, πήχεε, Il. 11.573, Od. 23.240; λ. παρειά, παρηΐς, S. Ant. 1239, E. Med. 923; σάρξ, δέρη, ib. 1189 (v.l.), IA 875 (troch.); freq. with the notion of bare, κῶλον, πούς, Id. Ba. 665, 863 (lyr.), Ion 221 (lyr.); cf. λευκόπους.

children.label: c
children.definition: white-skinned, Pl. R. 474e: hence, weakly, womanish, Ar. Th. 191, Ec. 428, X. HG 3.4.19; λευκῶν ἀνδρῶν οὐδὲν ὄφελος Macar. 5.55; cf. λευκόπρωκτος, λευκόχρως.

children.label: d
children.definition: λευκαὶ φρένες in Pi. P. 4.109 is expld. by Hsch. μαινόμεναι, frantic, passionate (cf. λευκῶν πραπίδων· κακῶν φρενῶν, Id.).
λ. χρυσός, pale gold, i.e. gold alloyed with silver (prob. the same as ἤλεκτρον), opp. ἄπεφθος χρυσός, Hdt. 1.50.

bright, fortunate, happy, λευκὸν ἦμαρ νυκτὸς ἐκ μελαγχίμου A. Pers. 301, cf. Ag. 668; a joyful day or holiday, Call. Aet. 1.1.2 [Fr. 178.2 Pf.]; λ. ἡμέρα a happy day, S. Fr. 6, cf. Sch. Call. Iamb. in PSI 9.1094.39 [on Fr. 191.37 Pf. ]; variously expld. in Phylarch. 83 J., Plu. Per. 27; ἡ λ. ψῆφος the vote of acquittal, Luc. Harm. 3, cf. Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: λεύκη, ἡ, λευκόν, τό, as Subst., v. sub vocc. (Cogn. with Lat. lux, etc.)
with white flesh, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.44, Epaenet. ap. Ath. 7.312b.
pale-grey, of a coloured garment, PHamb. 10.20 (ii A.D.).
white-chested, ὄνος BGU 982.9 (ii A.D.).
white-wreathed, of suppliant boughs, A. Supp. 191, 334.

children.label: II
children.definition: λευκοστεφῆ· τὰ κεραυνόβλητα, Hsch.
grizzled, θρίξ E. IA 222 (lyr.).
white-robed, Orph. Fr. 33.
white-ankled, Ἥβα Theoc. 17.32.
of white substance, ἄρτοι Antiph. 176.3.
whiteness, Hp. Aër. 20, Pl. Tht. 156d, al.
white-necked, Anatolius in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(3).188.
have white hair, Str. 6.1.13.
white-growing, μύρτα Ar. Av. 1100 (lyr.).
provide with marble facing, τὰς πυλίδας CIG 2749 ( Aphrodisias).
worker in marble or white stone, BCH 32.500 ( Aphrodisias), Milet. 7.60 ( Didyma), Princeton Exp.Inscr. Sect.B No.1170, Wiener Denkschr. 44(6) p.31 No.70 ( Cilicia, iii A.D.).
white-tailed, Hsch. s.v. μάλουρος.
of a white web, φᾶρος Eust. 1530.56.
white-gleaming, ψάμαθος E. IA 1054 (lyr.); αὐγά prob. in Id. Hyps. Fr. 3(1)ii 4 (lyr.); αὐχήν Nonn. D. 15.232; cf. sq. [λευκόφαιος]
whitish grey, ash-coloured, πρόβατον PHib. 1.32.13 (iii B.C.); χιτών PCair.Zen. 433.9 (iii B.C.), cf. Ath. 3.78a, Poll. 7.129; καρπός prob. in Posidon. 3 J.
white-eye, name of a gem, Plin. HN 37.171.
have dropsy, Hp. Coac. 472.
the beginning of dropsy (also called λευκὸν φλέγμα), dub. in Cels. 3.21.
one of a leuco-phlegmatous temperament, Hp. Epid. 3.14.
ὁ λ. ὕδερος oedematous dropsy, anasarca, Gal. 10.82, al.
suffering from white phlegm, Hp. Epid. 4.30.
affected with dropsy, Hp. Epid. 4.10.
with white husk, cj. in Posidon. 3 J.; cf. λευκόφαιος.
Hsch.
wear white garments, of ἔφηβοι, IG 3.1132 (ii A.D.).
white-skin-coloured, Philox. 2.31.
white-robed, δαίμων APl. 16.20 ( Ammian.); shining white, Zos.Alch. p.118 B.
bearing white grapes, ἄμπελοι Gp. 5.2.2.

definition: Λευκοφρυηνά, τά, festival of Artemis Leucophryene, SIG 561.26 ( Magn. Mae., iii B.C.), al.

children.definition: white-browed, ἀγορή Orac. ap. Hdt. 3.57.

children.label: II
children.definition: λευκόφρυς, v. λυκόφρυς.
white-leaved, Dsc. 4.103; ῥάβδος λ., name of a plant growing in the Phasis, Arist. Mir. 846a29, Ps.-Plu. Fluv. 5.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: λευκόφυλλον, τό, = ξηρόμυρον, Aët. 16.128(118).
white-coated, ἥπατα Batr. 37.
pale-green, Aret. SD 1.8, 15.
whitewashed, ἐπάλξεις Ulp.ad D. 3.29.
whiteness, white colour, Placit. 3.1.1.

of pale complexion, Arist. GA 728a2, Aret. SD 1.13, etc.: generally, white, heterocl. acc. λευκόχροα κόμαν E. Ph. 322 (lyr.): pl. λευκόχροας Ptol. Geog. 7.2.17:—also λευκό-χροιος, ον, Hp. Epid. 2.1.10, Phlp. in GA 53.3.
of pale gold colour, Plin. HN 37.128, 171: as Adj., Lyd. Mag. 3.70.
Phint. ap. Stob. 4.23.61a.
= foreg., κάμηλος PGrenf. 2.74.7 (iv A.D.).
white-skinned, colourless, Eub. 35, Alex. 98.18, Theoc. Ep. 2.1, Arist. Phgn. 808b4.
whitish grey, ὄνοι Hippiatr. 14.
whiten over, [ πυξίον] Aen.Tact. 31.14; βωμόν IG 2(2).1672.140:— Med., λευκοῦσθαι τὰ ὅπλα whiten their shields, X. HG 2.4.25, cf. 7.5.20; λ. πόδα bare the foot, AP 9.403 ( Maec.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be made or become white, λευκωθεὶς κάρα μύρτοις Pi. I. 4(3).69; τοῖχος λελευκωμένος whitened or plastered, Pl. Lg. 785a; γραμματεῖον λελευκωμένον, = λεύκωμα I, D. 46.11; ὁ ἄνθρωπος οὐ λευκός ἐστιν ἀλλὰ λελεύκωται Arist. Ph. 185b29; of a leper, Ph. 1.346; λελευκωμένος πίναξ, of the list of proscribed, D.C. Fr. 109.12.

data.quote: ὁ ἄνθρωπος οὐ λευκός ἐστιν ἀλλὰ λελεύκωται

children.definition: white-armed, epith. of Hera, Il. 1.55, 195, etc.; of Persephone, etc., Hes. Th. 913, Pi. P. 3.98, etc.; of female slaves, Od. 6.239, 18.198, 19.60; λ. λίνον, perh. with a play on λευκόλινον, of a useless woman, Diogenian. 6.22.

tablet covered with gypsum, used as a public notice-board, ἐς λ. γράψαι, ἀναγράφειν, Lys. 9.6, Lex ap. D. 24.23, IG 12(5).647.40 ( Ceos), PHib. 1.29.9 (iii B.C.), etc.: hence ἐν λευκώμασιν γραφῆναι to be posted in a list of defaulters, ‘to be sold up’, App.Prov. 2.63; of the proscription-list, D.C. 47.3; of the album of senators, Id. 55.3: hence οἱ τοῦ λ. senators, Procop. Arc. 29.

children.label: II
children.definition: whiteness, Arist. Phgn. 813a28.
a white spot in the eye, caused by a thickening of the cornea, PGrenf. 1.33.14 (ii B.C.), Dsc. 3.84, Gal. 14.775, Sammelb. 4414.6 (ii A.D.), Aët. 7.39 tit.
to be affected with λεύκωμα II.2, Sch. A. Pr. 499.
good for λεύκωμα II.2, κολλούρια Paul.Aeg. 3.22.
of the nature of λεύκωμα II.2, πάθος Erot. s.v. ἄργεμον.

definition: λευκωπίας λευκὸς ὀφθῆναι, Hsch. - ωσις, εως, ἡ,

children.definition: Hippiatr. 11.

children.label: II
children.definition: whitening, Olymp.Alch. 91 B.; of pearls, etc., PHolm. 2.36, al.
whitewasher, or λευκ-ωτός, ή, όν, whitewashed, in dat. - ωτῇ, IG 1(2).374.46.

definition: λευρός, ά, όν (also ός, όν A. Pr. 371), poet. Adj.

children.definition: smooth, level, even, λευρῷ ἐνὶ χώρῳ Od. 7.123, Orac. ap. Hdt. 1.67; Σικελίας λευροὺς γύας A. l.c.; λ. οἶμος αἰθέρος ib. 396; ἐν ψαμάθῳ λευρᾷ E. Hec. 700 (lyr.); πέδον, πέτρα, Id. Ph. 836, Ba. 982 (lyr.); ὁδοί Call. Aet. Oxy. 2080.67 [Fr. 43.65 Pf.].

children.label: II
children.definition: smooth, polished, ξίφος Pi. N. 7.27; δέρμα . . λευρὸν ἔθηκε βοός AP 6.116 ( Samus).

children.label: III
children.definition: λευρᾶς σωφροσύνης· τελείας, καὶ ταπεινῆς, κοίλης, ὁμαλῆς, μὴ τραχείας, Hsch.

stoning, χεὶρ λ. E. Or. 863; λ. καταφθοραί death by stoning, Id. Ion 1237 (lyr.); θανάτου λεύσιμον ἄταν ib. 1240 (lyr.); θανεῖν λ. πετρώματι Id. Or. 50; λ. δοῦναι δίκην ib. 614, cf. Heracl. 60; λ. ἀραί curses that will end in stoning, A. Ag. 1616; stoned, θῦμα ib. 1118 (lyr.).
stoning, A. Eu. 189, E. Fr. 878.

definition: λεύσσω, by good authors used only in pres. and impf. (in codd. sts. with single σ, as also in IG (v. infr.), CIG 3284 ( Smyrna), Hsch.); Ep. impf. λεῦσσον Od. 8.200; Ion. λεύσσεσκον Emp. 129.5: fut. λεύσω dub. in AP 15.7, Man. 6.93: aor. opt. λεύσσειε ib. 487, λεύσσειεν ib. 620.—

children.definition: IG 5(2).16 ( Tegea, iii B.C.), cf. Κλειτορίων . . λεύσει· ὁρᾷ AB 1096:— look or gaze upon, see, c. acc., Il. 1.120, al., Pi. P. 4.145: c. Part., πυρπολέοντας ἐλεύσσομεν Od. 10.30; of the gods, ὁ εἰσαιὲν ὁρῶν κύκλος λεύσσει νιν Διός S. OC 705 (lyr.); λεύσσετε . . οἷα πάσχω Id. Ant. 940 (anap.); used by Com. in mock Trag. phrases, Ar. Th. 1052, Ra. 992 (both lyr.).

data.quote: ὁ εἰσαιὲν ὁρῶν κύκλος λεύσσει νιν Διός

children.definition: look, gaze, λεύσσων ἐπὶ οἴνοπα πόντον Il. 5.771; Κυκλώπων ἐς γαῖαν ἐλεύσσομεν Od. 9.166; ἐς αὐτόν 8.171, cf. S. OT 1254; στατὸν εἰς ὕδωρ Id. Ph. 716 (lyr.); ἐς χέρας E. Ph. 596 (troch.); πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω λ. Il. 3.110; ὁ μὴ λεύσσων, like ὁ μὴ βλέπων, he that lives no more, S. Tr. 828 (lyr.); so c. acc., εἰ λεύσσει φάος E. Ph. 1084, cf. Tr. 269 (lyr.).
λ. φονίου δέργμα δράκοντος A. Pers. 81 (lyr.); λεπτά, δεινὸν λ. κόραις, E. Or. 224, 389; φόνον λεῦσσόν τε προσώπῳ and looked murder, Theoc. 25.137.

one who stones, E. Tr. 1039; τὸν Κασσανδρέων λευστῆρα their oppressor, Ael. NA 5.15; so perh. in Hdt. 5.67, where the oracle tells Cleisthenes Ἄδρηστον μὲν εἶναι Σικυωνίων βασιλέα, ἐκεῖνον δὲ λευστῆρα (or perh. a mere stone-thrower, i.e. ψιλός: Suid., quoting Ael. Fr. 115, makes it Pass., = ὁ καταλευσθῆναι ἄξιος).

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., λ. μόρος death by stoning, A. Th. 199; λευστῆρα πρῶτον . . ῥίψας πέτρον Lyc. 1187, cf. Hsch.

definition: λευστός, ή, όν, neut. pl. λευστ-ά· ὁρατά, λιθοβόλητα, Hsch.
λευτον, dub. sens. in IG 5(2).3, εἰ δʼ ἂν λευτον μὲ ἰνφορβίε ( Tegea, iv B.C.).

children.definition: to be clad in white, Pl. R. 617c, CIG 2715.8 ( Stratonicea), Str. 11.11.8, Ph. 1.156.
clad in white, Phint. ap. Stob. 4.23.61a; λεώς Ph. 2.188, cf. Orph. H. 51.11, Aristid. Or. 48(24).31.
Suid.

definition: λεύω, fut. λεύσω ( κατα-) Ar. Ach. 285: aor. ἔλευσα ( κατ-) Hdt. 9.5, Th. 1.106:— Pass., fut. λευσθήσομαι J. Ap. 2.27: aor. ἐλεύσθην S. OC (v. infr.), Hp. Ep. 27: ( λᾶας):—

children.definition: stone, Th. 5.60; πέτροις λ. μνῆμα E. El. 328; τὸ λευσθῆναι πέτροις S. OC 435, cf. E. IA 1350.
of or for a couch, φυλλάς A.R. 1.1182, cf. Theognost. Can. 9.

children.label: II
children.definition: λέχος 4) in the nest, τέκνων ὑπερδέδοικε λεχαίων for her nestlings, A. Th. 292 (Lachm., for λεχέων).

grown with grass fit to make a bed, i.e. grassy, meadowy, epith. of various towns, Il. 2.697, h.Ap. 224, h.Merc. 88:—masc. λεχεποίης, ου, of the river Asopus, from its grassy banks, Il. 4.383, Orac. ap. Hdt. 9.43.— Hom. has both forms in acc. sg. only; the dat. occurs ap. Hdt. l.c.

definition: λεχέρνα ὑπὸ Ἀργείων ἡ θυσία ἐπιτελουμένη τῇ Ἥρᾳ, Hsch.

children.definition: bed-ridden, E. Ph. 1541 (lyr.).

definition: λεχήρια ἐνήλατα, Hsch. λεχμάδ . . . · ἤλεκτρον, Id. λέχνη· τρόπος, Id.

children.definition: lie down, pres. only in Hsch. λέχεται ( λεύχεται cod.) · κοιμᾶται, cf. Theognost. Can. 139: pf. part. λελοχυῖα ( = λεχὼ γενομένη) Hsch.; other tenses in Ep.: fut. λέξομαι: aor. ἐλεξάμην; also 3 sg. aor. ἔλεκτο, λέκτο; imper. λέξο, λέξεο (v. infr.):— lie down, esp. to sleep, λέξεται ὕπνῳ will lie asleep, Il. 4.131, cf. Od. 7.319; λέξομαι εἰς εὐνήν 17.102: aor., πὰρ δʼ Ἑλένη ἐλέξατο 4.305; τῷ ἔνι λεξάσθην Il. 14.350; λεξάσθων παρὰ τάφρον let them bivouac, 9.67, cf. 8.519; ἔλεκτο Od. 19.50, Hes. Sc. 46; λέκτο Od. 4.453, al.; imper. λέξο Il. 24.650, Od. 10.320; λέξεο Il. 9.617, Od. 19.598.

marriage-bed: and generally, marriage, ἐμὸν λ. ἀντιόωσαν Il. 1.31; ὁμὸν λ. εἰσαναβαίνοι 8.291; λ. δʼ ᾔσχυνε καὶ εὐνὴν Ἡφαίστοιο ἄνακτος Od. 8.269, cf. 3.403; ἑτέρῳ λέχεϊ, i.e. in adultery, Pi. P. 11.24; ἰὼ λ. καὶ στίβοι φιλάνορες A. Ag. 411 (lyr.); τὸ σὸν λ. ξυνῆλθον S. Aj. 491; λ. Ἡρακλεῖ . . ξυστᾶσα Id. Tr. 27; κρύφιον ὡς ἔχοι λέχος ib. 360; λέχους γὰρ . . ἁγνὸν δέμας (sc. ἐστί) E. Hipp. 1003: freq. in pl., ἐκ λεχέων Pi. P. 9.37; λεχέων Διὸς εὐνάτειρα A. Pr. 895 (lyr.); τὰ νυμφικὰ λ. S. OT 1243: ἱέμενοι λεχέων Id. Tr. 514 (lyr.); γῆμαι μείζω λέχη make a great marriage, E. El. 936; λ. τἀλλότρια ib. 1089; μικρὰ μεγάλων ἀμείνω . . λέχη ib. 1099: hence for the concrete, λ. νεώτερον younger spouse, Sapph. 75; σὰ λέχεα thy spouse, E. El. 481 (lyr.); ὤλεσας κεδνὸν λ. Id. Hipp. 835: used by Com. in poet. or mock Trag. passages, λ. γαμήλιον Ar. Av. 1758; κουρίδιον λ. Id. Pax 844; παιδὶ συμμεῖξαι λ. Id. Th. 891.

Ch. 938 (lyr.); but also, of brave men, Id. Ag. 1259, E. Or. 1401 (lyr.), 1555; of a baby, Ar. Th. 514 (but by way of contrast, of a coward, λέοντʼ ἄναλκιν, of Aegisthus, A. Ag. 1224); οἴκοι μὲν λέοντες, ἐν μάχῃ δʼ ἀλώπεκες Ar. Pax 1189 (lyr.); ἀντὶ λέοντος πίθηκον γίγνεσθαι Pl. R. 590b; ξυρεῖν ἐπιχειρεῖν λέοντα, of a dangerous undertaking, ‘to bell the cat’, ib. 341c.

Can. 9, Hsch., Phot.: λεώλεθρος, λεώλης, ες, utterly destroyed, Hsch. (also λειώλης, q.v., cf. λιωλεθρία Hsch.): λεωπάτητος [ ᾰ], ον, v.l. for λακπάτητος, S. Ant. 1275.—The Gramm. expl. it as shortd. for τελέως, A.D. Pron. 58.12, Erot. l.c. (ubi λίως codd.), Gal. l.c. (ubi male λεῶς), EM 560.31.

[ἡ ἀτραπὸς] κατὰ Ἀλπηνὸν πόλιν comes to an end at . . , Hdt. 7.216, cf. Th. 7.6; ἡ ἡμέρη ἔληγε Hdt. 9.52, cf. X. An. 7.6.6; of heat, wind, rain, etc., λ. μένος ἠελίοιο Hes. Op. 414; λήξαντος οὔρου Pi. P. 4.292; ψακὰς λ., νότος λ., A. Ag. 1534 (lyr.), S. Aj. 258 (anap.); ἅμα τῷ τοῦ σώματος ἄνθει λήγοντι Pl. Smp. 183e.

Pers. 705 (troch.); θρήνων, γόων, S. El. 104 (anap.), 353; ὀδύνης Pl. Phdr. 255d; λ. τοῦ βίου, i.e. to die, X. Ap. 8; φύλλα πτόρθοιο λ. Hes. Op. 421; also λ. ἀπʼ ἔργων A.R. 4.928: c. dat., λ. τῇ αὐθαδίᾳ PTeb. 16.9 (ii B.C.).

follow logically, Them. in Ph. 115.5; τὸ λῆγον, opp. τὸ ἡγούμενον, the consequent, opp. antecedent, Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.70, S.E. P. 2.111, 112.

Ba. 282, Or. 213; λήθην ποιεύμενος τά μιν ἐόργεε forgetting . . , Hdt. 1.127; λ. ποιεῖν τινος S. Fr. 259; Λήθην . . κωφήν, ἄναυδον Id. Fr. 670; χρόνος πάντα . . ἐς λ. ἄγει Id. Fr. 954; τῶν ἰδίων λ. λαβών Timocl. 6.5, cf. Phld. Rh. 1.254 S.; τῶν αὑτοῦ κακῶν ἐπάγεσθαι λ. Men. 467; παρέχειν Pl. Phdr. 275a; ἐμποιεῖν Id. plunder, SIG 38 B 20 ( Teos, v B.C.), Hdt. 4.112, Lys. 20.24 (prob.), etc.

children.definition: booty, spoil, mostly of cattle, ληΐδα δʼ ἐκ πεδίου συνελάσσαμεν . . , πεντήκοντα βοῶν ἀγέλας, κτλ. Il. 11.677, cf. X. Lac. 13.11; then of all kinds of booty, Il. 9.138, 18.327, Od. 10.41; πλαζόμενοι κατὰ ληΐδα 3.106: in A. Th. 331 (lyr.), concrete for αἰχμάλωτοι, cf. A.R. 1.695; cf. ληϊάς.
cattle, stock (cf. λεία) , ληΐδʼ ἀέξειν, βουκολίας τʼ ἀγέλας τεκαὶ αἰπόλιαπλατέʼ αἰγῶν Hes. Th. 444, cf. Theoc. 25.97.

data.quote: ληΐδʼ ἀέξειν, βουκολίας τʼ ἀγέλας τεκαὶ αἰπόλιαπλατέʼ αἰγῶν

definition: ληϊστής, οῦ, ὁ, = Att. λῃστής, h.Bacch. 7, Hdt. 6.17, SIG 38 B 20 ( Teos, v B.C.), Democr. 260, A.R. 1.750.

children.definition: to be carried off as booty, to be won by force, Il. 9.406: also in form λεϊστός, ib. 408, Inscr.Prien. 268c5.
plundering, ζῆν ἀπὸ . . ληϊστύος Hdt. 5.6.
Od. 15.427, Nic. Th. 347: in Prose λῄστωρ, Sammelb. 4309.14 (iii B.C.)

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., ληΐστορι χαλκῷ AP 9.649 ( Maced.).
she who makes or dispenses booty, epith. of Athena, Il. 10.460, Paus. 5.14.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., = ληϊάς, A.R. 1.818, Lyc. 105.

definition: ληϊτοάρχαι οἱ καθηγούμενοι τῶν θυσιῶν καὶ ἑστιάσεων, καὶ ἀρχαὶ καὶ ἱερεῖς, Hsch. (Cf. λῄταρχος.)

children.definition: town-hall, council-chamber, as the Achaeans of Achaea Phthiotis called it, Hdt. 7.197; = δημόσιον acc. to Plu. Rom. 26, Id. Aet.Gr. 2.280a:— Hsch. has λάϊτον· τὸ ἀρχεῖον, λαΐτων· τῶν δημοσίων τόπων; cf. λαιετόν, λαῖστρον, Suid., Zonar.:— Hsch. also quotes ληΐτη, λῃτή, = ἱέρεια, a public priestess.

definition: ληϊτουργέω, -ουργός, early forms of λῃτ-, λειτ- (q.v.).

children.definition: aor. inf. ληκῆσαι Pherecr. 177:— Pass., of the woman, Ar. Th. 493; ληκούμεσθʼ (sic) Pherecr. l.c.

children.label: II
children.definition: ληκᾶν· τὸ πρὸς ᾠδὴν ὀρχεῖσθαι, Hsch.

definition: ληκέω, Dor. and later Gr. λᾱκέω,

children.definition: crack, crackle, Theoc. 2.24; burst asunder, ἐλάκησε μέσος Act.Ap. 1.18; λακῆσαι τὰς ψύλλας ποιήσεις Gp. 13.15.5:—in Call. Iamb. 1.183 P. the context is broken.
wenching, in pl., Epicur. Fr. 414; or perh. from ληκέω (cf. sq. [ληκητής]), bawling, = ἀνακραύγασμα.
bawler, ἀγοραίων λ. ἐπέων Timo 42.
beat time, tattoo, Luc. Lex. 8, A.D. Adv. 152.11.
one must lay claim to, ὅλου τοῦ κλήρου Is. 7.23.
extreme, νῆσον εἰς ληκτηρίαν to the farthest bounds of the island, Lyc. 966, cf. 1391 (s.v.l.).
causing to cease, ὀδύνης v.l. in Hp. Liqu. 6; terminal, [ συλλαβαί] A.D. Synt. 7.10; ζῴδιον Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.194.18 (Rhetor.ex Teucro).
declaim in a hollow voice, as though speaking into a λήκυθος, τραγῳδὸς Μοῦσα-ίζουσα Call. Fr. 10.13 P., Phryn. PS p.86 B., Poll. 4.114, 7.182: c.acc., θέσεις λ. declaim commonplaces, Str. 13.1.54.
Dim. of λήκυθος, small oil-flask, Ar. Ra. 1200- 1246, D. 24.114, PTeb. 221 (ii B.C.), Anon. ap. Suid., etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: ληκύθιον ἀπώλεσεν in Ar. l.c., Heph. 6.2.
hollow, affected speaking, Plu. Suav. 2.1086e, Anon. ap. Suid.
one who declaims in a hollow voice, S. Fr. 1063.
maker of oil-flasks, Str. 15.1.67.
seller of oil-flasks, Poll. 7.182.

definition: λήκυθος ( Dor. λάκυθος [ᾱ] IG 42(1).123.130 ( Epid., iv B.C.)), ἡ,

children.definition: oil-flask, δῶκεν δὲ χρυσέῃ ἐν ληκύθῳ ὑγρὸν ἔλαιον Od. 6.79, cf. 215, Hp. Morb. 4.51, Ph. Bel. 102.41, etc.; casket for unguents, cosmetics, etc., S. Fr. 130; αἱ δὲ λήκυθοι μύρου γέμουσι Ar. Pl. 810, cf. Fr. 207; buried or burnt with the dead, Id. Ec. 538, 996, 1032, cf. IG 14.865, CIG 8346 k.

data.quote: δῶκεν δὲ χρυσέῃ ἐν ληκύθῳ ὑγρὸν ἔλαιον

children.definition: rhetorical bombast, Cic. Att. 1.14.3, Plin. Ep. 1.2.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: projecting cartilage on the gullet, Adamʼs apple, = βρόχθος, Clearch. 72.
carrying an oil-flask, Poll. 3.154.
membrum virile (whence ληκάω), Hsch., Phot.

will, desire, purpose, Epich. 182 (prob.l.): concrete, λ. Κορωνίδος wilful Coronis, Pi. P. 3.25; μητρῷον λ. thy proud mother, S. El. 1427; λήματος κάκη weakness of will, cowardice, A. Th. 616; ἥκιστα τοὐμὸν λ. ἔφυ τυραννικόν E. Med. 348; ἐς τὸ κέρδος λ. ἔχων ἀνειμένον Id. Heracl. 3, cf. 199, Alc. 981 (lyr.), Ba. 1000 (lyr.).

data.quote: ἐς τὸ κέρδος λ. ἔχων ἀνειμένον

children.label: II
children.definition: temper of mind, spirit, either,

courage, resolution, εὔτολμον ψυχῆς λ. Simon. 140; γενναῖον λ. Pi. P. 8.45, cf. N. 1.57; αἴθων λ. fiery in courage, A. Th. 448; δύο λήμασιν ἴσους Ἀτρεΐδας Id. Ag. 122 (lyr.); τοξουλκῷ λήματι πιστοί relying on their archer spirit, Id. Pers. 55 (anap.); ἀρείφατον λ. Id. Fr. 147; πέτρας τὸ λ. κἀδάμαντος E. Cyc. 596; λ. οὐκ ἄτολμον Ar. Nu. 457 (lyr.); καθʼ Ἡρακλέα . . τὸ λ. ἔχων Id. Ra. 463; or,

insolence, arrogance, audacity, ὅσον λ. ἔχων ἀφίκου S. OC 877 (lyr.); ὦ λῆμʼ ἀναιδές ib. 960; δῆλον . . τἀνθρώπουʼ στι τὸ λῆμα Ar. Nu. 1350 (lyr.).— Poet. word, also used in Ion. Prose, in signf. spirit, courage, ἔργα χειρῶν τε καὶ λήματος Hdt. 5.72; λήματος πλέος ib. 111, cf. 7.99, 9.62: and in late Prose, as D.S. 2.58 (pl.), J. BJ 3.10.4, Luc. Dem.Enc. 50, etc.; defined by Andronic. Pass. p.575 M.
bleared, of the eyes, Luc. Lex. 4.
high-spirited, λ. κἀνδρεῖος εἶ Ar. Ra. 494; cf. sq. [ληματιάω]
to be high-spirited, v.l. in Ar. l.c.
Dim. of λῆμα, = φρόνημα, Hsch. (pl.).

definition: ληματόομαι, in pf. Pass. λελημάτωμαι· λῆμα ἔχω εἰς τὸ ἔργον, Hsch.

children.definition: to be bleared, of the eyes, Hp. Prorrh. 2.18; to be blear-eyed or purblind, λημᾶν κολοκύνταις to have oneʼs eyes running pumpkins, Ar. Nu. 327, cf. Hsch.; λ. καὶ ἀμβλυώττειν Luc. Tim. 2, etc.: metaph., Κρονικαῖς λήμαις λ. τὰς φρένας Ar. Pl. 581.

a humour that gathers in the corner of the eye, rheum, Hp. VM 19, Prog. 2: in pl., sore eyes, Ar. Lys. 301 (v. Sch.): metaph., ἡ τοῦ Πειραιέως λ. the eye-sore of Piraeus, of Aegina, Pericles ap. Arist. Rh. 1411a15, Plu. Per. 8; Κρονικαὶ λῆμαι old prejudices that dim the mindʼs eye, Ar. Pl. 581; ὄψεως λ. ἡ δεισιδαιμονία Plu. Suav. 2.1101c. (Cf. λάμας.)
misty, λημηρῇ νεφέλῃ εἰλυμένος ὄσσε Heliod. ap. Stob. 4.36.8.

definition: λημίον, τό, Dim. of λήμη, Hp. Coac. 214, Epid. 1.5.

children.definition: anything received, opp. δόμα, Antig. ap. Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.182e; λ. καὶ ἀνάλωμα receipt and expense, Lys. 32.20, Pl. Lg. 920c, Anaxandr. 26; ἀνενεγκεῖν ( ἐν- Pap.) ἐν λήμματι place to credit, PEleph. 15.4 (iii B.C.), cf. BGU 1346.2 (i B.C.), etc.: generally, gain, profit, D. 5.12, etc.; λ. τι κέρδους Id. 45.14; esp. of unjust gain, Din. 1.45; παντὸς ἥττων λήμματος unable to resist any temptation of gain, D. 19.339; ὥσπερ ἂν τρυτάνη ἐπὶ τὸ λ. ῥέπειν Id. 18.298; λ. λαβεῖν Id. 21.28, 27.39: freq. in pl., S. Ant. 313, D. 8.25, etc.; τὰ λ. τοῦ ἀργυρίου Id. 49.57; λημμάτων μετέχειν Id. 58.40; τἀπὸ Θρᾴκης λ. ἕλκουσι δεῦρο Antiph. 196.

data.quote: ὥσπερ ἂν τρυτάνη ἐπὶ τὸ λ. ῥέπειν

children.label: II
children.definition: statement taken as true, assumption; esp. premiss in a syllogism, ἐπὶ λ. τῷ τοιούτῳ A.D. Synt. 245.13; τὰ οἰκεῖα τῇ ἐπιστήμῃ λ. Arist. Top. 101a14; λήμματα τιθέναι ib. 156a21, cf. Gell. 9.16, Phld. Rh. 1.9 S.; prop. the major premiss (the minor being πρόσληψις), Crinis Stoic. 3.269; later, ἀποδεικτικὰ λήμματα παρασχεῖν offer scientific proofs, Gal. 14.627.

children.label: III
children.definition: matter, substance, or argument of a sentence, etc., opp. form or style ( λέξις), D.H. Dem. 20, Longin. 15.10, etc.: hence, title or argument of an epigram, Lat. lemma, Mart. 14.2; theme or thesis, Plin. Ep. 4.27.3, Mart. 10.59; nutricis lemmata, ‘baby songs’, Aus. Ep. 12.90.

children.label: IV
children.definition: LXX, burden laid on one, commission received, esp. of prophecy, Na. 1.1, Je. 23.33, al.; even, λῆμμα ἰδεῖν Hb. 1.1, cf. La. 2.14.
place to credit, PFlor. 361.7 (iii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: assume, posit, τὰ λελημματισμένα premisses, A.D. Synt. 101.27.
quick at seizing opportunity, Hp. Decent. 3.

definition: λημμάτιον, τό, Dim. of λῆμμα, Ptol. Alm. 1.10, Olymp. in Mete. 261.27, Dam. Pr. 233, 396, al., Zonar.

children.definition: receiver of taxes, PKlein.Form. 51 (vi A.D.).
worshippers of the Lemnian deities, IG 12(1).43 ( Rhodes, i B.C.). Λήμνιος, v. Λῆμνος.

woollen fillet or ribbon, by which chaplets were fastened, IG 2(2).1297.11 (iii B.C.), al., Plb. 18.46.12, Posidon. 9 J., Plu. Sull. 27, AP 12.123; of ribbons attached to birdʼs feet, Callix. 2; surgical bandage, Mnesith. ap. Orib. inc. 15.16; pledget, Heliod. ap. Orib. 50.49.1, Gal. 19.97, etc.

Lemnos, Il. 1.593, al., Od. 8.283; sacred to Hephaestus, Sch. A.R. 1.851, etc.: Λαμνόθεν, Adv. from Lemnos, Pi. P. 1.52:— Adj. Λήμνιος, α, ον, Lemnian, πῦρ S. Ph. 800, Ar. Lys. 299; Λ. ἔργα, prov. from the wickedness of certain Lemnian women, Hdt. 6.138, cf. A. Ch. 631 (lyr.); Λ. ἄμπελοι Ar. Pax 1162:—also Λημνιακός, Dor. Λαμν- Call. Fr. 1.44 P.:—also fem. Λημνιάς ( Λαμνιάς), άδος, Pi. O. 4.22; Λημνίς, ίδος, μίλτος Nic. Th. 865.
soreness of eyes, Sch. Ar. Nu. 326.

definition: λημύδριον, τό, Dim. of λήμη, Gal. 17(1).868.

children.definition: receipts and payments, PLond. 1.77.50 (vi A.D.).
λήμψομαι, = λήψομαι, v. λαμβάνω.
full of rheum, Alex.Trall. 2.
secretion of rheum in the eyes, PMed. in Sitzb.Heidelb.Akad. 1913 (13).33,41.

definition: λῆν, inf. of λῶ; but λήν· λίαν, Hsch.

children.definition: leader of Bacchanals, θοᾶν Ληναγέτα Βακχᾶν BMus.Inscr. 902 ( Halic., iii B.C.).
Bacchanals, Heraclit. 14, Str. 10.3.10, D.P. 702, 1155, Theoc. 26 tit. (Arc. acc. to Hsch.)
celebrate Bacchanal rites, Heraclit. 15.
of or belonging to the Λήναια, ἀγῶνες Posidipp. ap. Ath. 7.414e; διδασκαλίαι Plu. VOrat. 2.839d; θέατρον Λ. Poll. 4.121.
belonging to the wine-press; esp.
god of the wine-press, D.S. 3.63.

Λήναια (sc. ἱερά), τά, the Lenaea, an Athenian (also Rhodian, IG 12(1).125) festival held in the month Ληναιών (i.e. Gamelion) in honour of Dionysus, at which there were dramatic contests, esp. of the Com. Poets, Ar. Ach. 1155 (lyr.).

Λήναιον, τό, the Lenaeum, the place at Athens where the Lenaea were held, οὑπὶ Ληναίῳ ἀγών the Lenaean dramatic contest, opp. τὰ κατʼ ἄστυ, ib. 504, cf. Pl. Prt. 327d, Lex ap. D. 21.10; Διονύσια τὰ ἐπὶ Ληναίῳ SIG 1029.9 (iv B.C.).
Ar. Eq. 547 (anap.).

definition: Ληναιών, ῶνος, ὁ, name of a month in many Greek calendars, Hes. Op. 504, SIG 1014.94 ( Erythrae), etc.
Ληνεύς, έως, ὁ, epith. of Dionysus, SIG 1024.24 ( Myconos).

children.definition: Hsch.
the place of the ληνός I, Gp. 6.1.3.

definition: ληνίδιον, τό, Dim. of ληνός, PTeb. 414.37 ( ii A.D., prob.), POxy. 2153.4 (iii A.D.).

children.definition: a Bacchante, Eust. 629.30, Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: PTeb. 414.31 (ii A.D.); = ληνός 4, EM 478.28 ( λινίδα codd.).
one who treads the wine-vat, Him. Or. 6.3, 21.6, Sammelb. 5810.12 (iv A.D.), Gloss.
tread the wine-press, Hsch. s.v. τραπεῖν.
vat, PMasp. 97.2 (vi A.D.).
Gloss.

definition: ληνός, Dor. λᾱνός Theoc. 7.25, IG 14.150.5 ( Syracuse): ἡ:—

children.definition: anything shaped like a tub or trough, Hp. Mochl. 38; esp.
wine-vat in which the grapes are pressed, PCair.Zen. 300.15 (iii B.C.), Theoc. 7.25, 25.28, D.S. 3.63.
trough, for watering cattle, watering-place for them, h.Merc. 104, LXX Ge. 30.38, 41.
kneading-trough, Men. 116.
socket into which the mast fitted, = ἱστοπέδη, Asclep.Myrl. ap. Ath. 11.474f, Poll. 1.91.
coffin, Pherecr. 5, CIG 1979, al. ( Thessalonica), IG l.c.
the meeting-point of the sinuses of the dura mater, still called torcular Herophili, Herophil. ap. Gal. 2.712, cf. UP 9.6.
hollow of a chariot, Hsch. (pl.).
the lower parts of the nose, Poll. 2.80.
wool: hence, fillet, A. Eu. 44, Epic. in Arch.Pap. 7p.4 (pl.): in pl., fleece, A.R. 4.173, 177.
belonging to the ληξίαρχος: τὸ λ. γραμματεῖον the register of each Athenian deme, IG 1(2).79.6, Is. 7.27, D. 44.35, Lycurg. 76, etc.

definition: ληξίαρχος, ὁ, the officer at Athens who kept order in the ἐκκλησία, Poll. 8.104.

children.definition: allaying fever, Asclep. ap. Gal. 14.136:—also ληξοπύρετος, Gal. 13.68, 1013.

definition: λῆξις (A), εως, ἡ, Ion. λάξις (q.v.), ( λαγχάνω)

children.definition: determination or appointment by lot, ἀρχῆς Pl. Lg. 765d.
portion assigned by lot, allotment, ib. 740a, 747e, Criti. 109c, 113b; cf. λάξις.

children.label: b
children.definition: section of a body, determined by lot, Arist. Ath. 30.3, 31.3.

children.label: c
children.definition: fortunes, αἱ διάφοροι τῆς ἀνθρωπείας ψυχῆς λήξεις Simp. in de An. 4.6.

data.quote: αἱ διάφοροι τῆς ἀνθρωπείας ψυχῆς λήξεις

children.definition: assigned sphere, θεῶν καὶ τῶν εἰς θείαν λῆξιν πορευθέντων Jul. Or. 6.187c; ἡ ἑτέρα λ. the other world, Hld. 2.24; ἡ ἑῴα λ. the eastern part of the empire, Procop.Gaz. Pan. 497.3; ἡ τῆς Ἀθηνᾶς λ. the sphere of Athena, Lib. Or. 12.36, Decl. 1.175, Ep. 1065.3; province, τὰς λ. [τῶν θεῶν] Herm. in Phdr. p.74A.; dwelling-place, εἰ . . αἱ λ. τῶν ψυχῶν . . ὑποσέληνοί εἰσιν ib. p.104A.

data.quote: θεῶν καὶ τῶν εἰς θείαν λῆξιν πορευθέντων

children.label: II
children.definition: λ. δίκης or λ. alone, written complaint lodged with the Archon, as the first step in private actions, nearly, = ἔγκλημα, Pl. R. 425d, Is. 11.10, Aeschin. 1.63, cf. λαγχάνω I.3; very rarely of public actions, as in D. 39.17.

λ. τοῦ κλήρου, an application to the Archon (required of all except direct descendants) to be put in legal possession of an inheritance, τοῦ κλήρου λαχεῖν τὴν λ. ἠξίωσεν Is. 3.2, cf. Arist. Ath. 43.4.

data.quote: τοῦ κλήρου λαχεῖν τὴν λ. ἠξίωσεν

children.definition: cessation, μόχθων, ἀνέμων, A. Eu. 505 (lyr.), A.R. 1.1086; of the flow of a river, Ph. 1.175; τῆς ἐνεργείας λῆξιν λαμβανούσης Gal. Phil.Hist. 17, cf. M.Ant. 9.21.
death, decease, PMasp. 19.6 (vi A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: termination, A.D. Synt. 104.28; λ. ἡ εἰς ς̄ Id. Adv. 195.27.

children.label: III
children.definition: end, extremity, τοῦ κόλου Sor. 1.7.
Asclep. ap. Gal. 14.136.
waning, Heph.Astr. 2.34; ληξῐ-φωτέω, wane, Anubion ap.eund. 2.5.

definition: ληός, ὁ, Ion. form of λαός (q.v.).

children.definition: to be taken or accepted, Pl. Prt. 356b.

children.label: II
children.definition: ληπτέον, one must take hold, Ar. Eq. 603; ἔργον λ. one must undertake, X. Mem. 1.7.2; one must assume in arguing, etc., Pl. Phlb. 61a; one must take or choose, ἐκ τούτων ἐπιστάτας λ. X. Cyr. 8.1.10; λ. δὲ . . τίνας ὅρους λέγουσι Arist. Pol. 1280a7.
one must take, receive, ὁμήρους δοτέον καὶ λ. X. HG 3.2.18; one must submit to, πληγὰς ὑπὸ τῶν ἀμεινόνων Id. Lac. 9.5.
one who accepts, Zonar.
disposed to accept, Arist. EN 1120b15.

children.label: II
children.definition: assimilative, opp. ἐκκριτικός, Id. Ph. 243b14.
to be apprehended, λόγῳ καὶ διανοίᾳ Pl. R. 529d; τῷ λογισμῷ Max.Tyr. 7.5; πρὸς αἴσθησιν Chryserm. ap. Gal. 8.741.

children.label: b
children.definition: to be apprehended by the senses, opp. νοητός, AP 11.354.6 ( Agath.).
acceptable, not to be refused if offered, Stoic. 3.32, 34.

children.label: II
children.definition: Arist. Pr. 896b6.
Ph. 1.77, Hsch.; f.l. for ληναΐζω in Heraclit. 15.
Phld. Mus. p.92 K.

to be foolish or silly, speak or act foolishly, S. Tr. 435, Ar. Eq. 536, al., Pl. Tht. 152b, etc.; ξυνθιασώτης τοῦ ληρεῖν Ar. Pl. 508; περί τινος Isoc. 12.11, 33; λῆρον ληρεῖς Ar. Pl. 517; ληρεῖς ἔχων (v. ἔχω B. IV. 2) Id. Ra. 512, cf. Pl. Grg. 497b: c. acc., μὴ ληρήσῃς τὸν ἐκτιναγμόν σου PFay. 114. 21 (i A.D.).
to be delirious, Hp. Epid. 1.4.3 [1.26.γʹ].
silly talk, nonsense, Pl. Grg. 486c (pl.), Phld. Mus. p.72 K. (pl.), Gal. 8.651 (pl.).
silly talk, trifling, Plu. Garr. 2.504b, D.L. 7.118; λ. τοῦ γήραος dotage of the old, Aret. SD 1.6.

definition: Ληρόκριτος, name given by Epicurus to Democritus, D.L. 10.8.

children.definition: trash, trumpery, of what is showy but useless, λήροις ἀναδῶν τοὺς νικῶντας Ar. Pl. 589; τραγικὸς λ. Id. Ra. 1005; λῆρόν τε τἄλλʼ ἡγεῖτο τοῦ γνῶναι πέρι φύσεις ποιητῶν no good as connoisseurs of poets, ib. 809; λ. πάντα πρὸς τὸ χρυσίον Antiph. 232.1, cf. X. An. 7.7.41; λ. εἶναι δοκεῖ τὸ νόμισμα, φύσει δʼ οὐθέν mere trash, Arist. Pol. 1257b10; a mere trifle, Pl. Phd. 72c, Men. Epit. 60; λ. ἐστι τἄλλα πρὸς Κινησίαν thereʼs naught to compare with Cinesias, Ar. Lys. 860; οἱ ποιηταὶ λ. εἰσιν useless, futile, Xenarch. 7.1; ποιητῶν λ. Cratin. 306; ἐμὲ μὲν λ. ἡγεῖσθαι Pl. Chrm. 176a, cf. Tht. 176d, Luc. DMeretr. 10.3; λεπτοτάτων λ. ἱερεῦ Ar. Nu. 359; λῆροι καὶ παιδιαί, of flute-playing at banquets, Pl. Prt. 347d; λῆροι καὶ φλυαρίαι futile nonsense, Id. Hp.Ma. 304b; ὁδοὺς καὶ κρήνας καὶ λήρους D. 3.29; παροψίδες καὶ λῆρος side-dishes and suchlike trumpery, Alex. 261.5; παρεὶς λ. πολὺν ἀστακὸν ὠνοῦ Archestr. Fr. 24, cf. 35.7; as an exclamation, λῆρος nonsense! humbug! Ar. Pl. 23, cf. Eub. 41.8.
delirium, Hp. Epid. 1.4.3 [1.26.γʹ] (as v.l. for παράληρος).

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., silly, ποιητής Luc. Gall. 6, cf. Rh.Pr. 17. Adv. - ρως Tz. H. 13.337. (Perh. derived fr. sq.)

robbery, piracy, Th. 1.5, Pl. Lg. 823e, etc.; ἀπὸ λῃστείας βίον ἔχειν, ζῆν, X. An. 7.7.9, Arist. Pol. 1256a36: in pl., πόλιν . . κατὰ γῆν λῃστείαις πορθουμένην Th. 8.40.

definition: λῃστήρ, ῆρος, ὁ, in Hom. ληϊστήρ,

Grg. 507e; ληϊστὴς κατεστήκεε Καρχηδονίων he began a course of piracies upon them, Hdt. 6.17, cf. Th. 1.5, 8, 6.4; οἱ λ. αὑτοὺς ποριστὰς καλοῦσιν Arist. Rh. 1405a25; of irregular troops, IG 12(2).526 ( Eresos).

piratical, πλοῖον D. 23.148; λῃστικῷ τρόπῳ PTeb. 53.11 (ii B.C.).
ἡ -κή, = λῃστεία, Pl. Sph. 222c.
τὸ -κόν, piracy, Th. 1.4, 13; piratical vessels, Id. 2.69.
Adv. - κῶς in the manner of pirates: Comp. -κώτερον, πλοῖα λ. παρεσκευασμένα Id. 1.10, cf. 6.104. Cf. λῃστρικός.
E. Cyc. 172, Critias 6.12 D.; λῆστιν ἴσχειν, = ἐπιλανθάνεσθαι, forget, S. OC 584.
latrunculator, Gloss.
slaying robbers, AP 11.280 ( Pall.).

τριακόντορος λ. (cf. λῃστρίς) Th. 4.9, cf. App. Pun. 25, etc.; λ. σκάφη D.S. 3.43: metaph., of ἑταῖραι, τὰ λ. τῆς Ἀφροδίτης AP 5.43 ( Rufin.), 160 ( Hedyl. or Asclep.); λ. τρόπῳ BGU 1061.14 (i B.C.).
Str. 7.2.2; also λ. δύναμις Plu. Sert. 18; βίος λ. Arist. Pol. 1256b1; ἔθνη ib. 1338b23; τὸ λ. ἦθος Str. 12.8.9; ὁ λ. πόλεμος App. Mith. 96. Adv. -κῶς Str. 2.5.26.

definition: λῃστρίς, ίδος, ἡ, fem. of foreg., νῆες λ.

latrina, Gloss. (dub.).
public priest, Lyc. 991. (Cf. λήϊτον.)
public priestess, Call. Fr. 123, Hsch.; cf. λείτειραι.

definition: λῆτο ἐπελάθετο, Hsch. (Cf. λήϊτο· ἐπέθετο, Id).

children.definition: born of Leto, epith. of Apollo and Artemis, E. Ion 465 (lyr.), AP 9.525.12:—fem. Λᾱτογένεια, A. Th. 148 (lyr.).

definition: Λητοΐδης [ ῐ], ου, Aeol., Dor. Λᾱτοΐδας, α, ὁ,

definition: Λητώ, Dor. Λᾱτώ, όος, contr. οῦς, ἡ,

children.definition: Leto, mother of Apollo and Artemis, Il. 21.497, Hes. Th. 406, cf. 918, al.; on the accent of the acc. sg., v. Hdn.Gr. 2.33; voc. Λητοῖ Il. 21.498, h.Ap. 14, 62. ( Dor. un contr. acc. Λητόα Tyrannio ap.Sch.Gen. Il. 21.497):— Adj. Λητῷος, α, ον, of or born from Leto, κόρη A. Fr. 170, S. El. 570; Dor. Λᾱτῴα AP 6.280:—fem. also Λητωῐάς, άδος, Call. Dian. 83, Opp. C. 1.109, etc.; and Λητωΐς, Dor. Λᾱτ-, ΐδος, AP 6.272 ( Pers.), A.R. 2.938.

priest, prob. in IG 5(2).405 ( Lusi); cf. λείτωρ, λειτορεύω, λῃτῆρες.
Antim. 53.

data.quote: ἥδιστον ὅτῳ πάρεστι λ. ὧν ἐρᾷ καθʼ ἡμέραν

Epich. 223; cf. λιπόνηρος.

definition: λιάζομαι, aor. ἐλιάσθην, Ep. 3 pl. λίασθεν Il. 23.879: 3 sg. plpf. λελίαστο Mosch. 4.118 (for Act. v. sub fin.):—

children.definition: bend, incline; and so,

children.label: I
children.definition: go aside, recoil, shrink, ἐκ ποταμοῖο λιασθείς Od. 5.462; ἀπὸ πυρκαϊῆς ἑτέρωσε λ. Il. 23.231; νόσφι λ. 1.349, 11.80; ὕπαιθα λιάσθη he shrank beneath his attack, 15.520, cf. 21.255; δεῦρο λιάσθης hither hast thou retired, 22.12; παρὰ κληῗδα λιάσθη ἐς πνοιὰς ἀνέμων, of a vision, disappeared by the key-hole, Od. 4.838: metaph., stray from the straight path, Emp. 2.8; in A.R. of parting, separating from others, 1.94, 3.827, 1164:—once in Trag., πρός σʼ ἐλιάσθην hastened to thee, E. Hec. 98 (anap.).
sink, fall, πρηνὴς ἐλιάσθη Il. 15.543; λιαζόμενον ποτὶ γαίῃ 20.420, cf. 418; ἐν γῇ Mosch. l.c.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀμφὶ δʼ ἄρα σφι λιάζετο κῦμα retired, drew back, Il. 24.96; πτερὰ πυκνὰ λίασθεν (for ἐλιάσθησαν) the dying birdʼs thick wings dropped, 23.879; where Aristarch. read λίασσεν it dropped its wings, though the Act. is not used exc. impf. λίαζον they loosened (the cables), Lyc. 21.
to be over-enthusiastic, [ παρὰ τὸ] λίαν λιάζειν A.D. Pron. 34.27; λιάζειν· λίαν ἐσπουδακέναι, Phot.
Hsch. s.v. ἐλιάνθη; cogn. with λιαρός.

definition: λίαν [v. fin.], Ion. and Ep. λίην, Adv.

children.definition: very, exceedingly, in Hom. with an Adv., λ. ἑκάς Od. 14.496; λ. ἀεικελίως 8.231: with an Adj., λ. μέγα εἶπες 3.227, 16.243; νήπιος λ. τόσον 4.371, cf. 13.238; λ. λυπρός 13.243; λ. ἐνθύμιος ib. 421: alone with a Verb, very much, overmuch, κεχολώατο λ. 14.282; λ. ἄχθομαι ἕλκος Il. 5.361; οὔ τι λ. ποθὴ ἔσσεται not exceedingly, 14.368; μή τι λ. προκαλίζεο Od. 18.20, cf. Il. 6.486; also, in Hom., καὶ λίην, which always begins the sentence or verse, surely, aye surely, καὶ λ. κεῖνός γε ἐοικότι κεῖται ὀλέθρῳ Od. 1.46, cf. 3.203, Il. 1.553, al.

data.quote: καὶ λ. κεῖνός γε ἐοικότι κεῖται ὀλέθρῳ

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom., ἀσχάλα μὴ λίην Archil. 66.7, cf. Sol. 6; λίην δὲ δειλιάζεις Anacr. ap. Ptol.Ascal. p.409 H.; λ. πιστεύειν to believe implicitly, Hdt. 4.96; μὴ κάμνε λ. Pi. P. 1.90; μὴ λ. στένε S. El. 1172, cf. E. Med. 158 (lyr.); ἀσπάζου αὐτὴν λ. POxy. 936.13 (iii A.D.); καὶ λ. σαφῶς Ar. Eq. 1231; λ. ἀσελγῶς Lys. 24.15; λ. πόρρω Pl. Prt. 310c; ἐντὸς λ. τῶν τειχῶν Th. 7.5: with other words of like sense, πολὺ λ. Isoc. 9.48; λ. πάνυ Antiph. 184.2 (dub.), cf. Eust. 972.46; κόμπος λ. εἰρημένος, opp. πεπλασμένος (compare our very and verily), A. Pr. 1031:—in Trag. and Com. freq. betw. Art. and Noun, ἡ λ. φιλότης βροτῶν his too great love . . , A. Pr. 123 (anap.); τὸ λ. ποτόν Cratin. 187; ἡ λ. τρυφή Men. 587; τὰ λ. μειράκια Theopomp.Com. 29; αἱ πρὸς τυράννους λίαν ὁμιλίαι D. 6.21; τὸ λ. excess, violence, E. Andr. 866, Pl. Cra. 415c. [ Hom. has ῐ nine times, ῑ thirty-two times; the latter is found both in arsi and in thesi. In later Ep. and Trag. both quantities are found: ᾱ always.]
Gloss.
warm, lukewarm, αἷμα, ὕδωρ, Il. 11.477, 830, Od. 24.45, etc.; οὖρος λ. a warm, soft wind, 5.268; ὕπνος λ. gentle, balmy, Il. 14.164, cf. A.R. 3.300, etc.

( Ἀθηνᾶ 18.6, Tegea); indeterminate in Sapph. 44.30 L.-P., S. Fr. 1064, Anaxandr. 41.37, SIG 247ii 19 ( Delph., iv B.C.).

Sat. 16; when pounded, μάννα λιβανωτοῦ Gp. 6.6.1; cf. λιβανομάννα: the best kind was λ. ἄρρην Dsc. 1.68, Alciphr. 2.4.
Thphr. HP 9.1.6.

censer, Carnead. ap. Plu. Tranq. 2.477b, Keil-Premerstein Zweiter Bericht No.20 ( Thyatira), Ramsay Studies in the Eastern Rom. Provinces p.319 ( Pisidia), Hsch.

anything that drips or trickles, esp. spring, fount, stream, S. Ph. 1215 (lyr.), E. Andr. 116, 534 (lyr.); λ. νυμφαία Antiph. 52.13; standing water, Babr. 24.6: in pl., streams, λιβάσιν ὑδρηλαῖς . . πηγῆς A. Pers. 613; δακρύων λιβάδες streams of tears, E. IT 1106 (lyr.); γάλακτος A.R. 4.1735; also ἀραιὰ ἡ Αἴγυπτος καὶ ῥᾳδία λιβάδας διαδοῦναι Ephor. 65 J.: in pl., also of pools of water that collect after rain, ὑπόνομοι λ. Str. 8.6.21, cf. Gal. 6.627, Gp. 2.6.14; of marshes, Thphr. HP 2.4.4; cf. λιβάζω.

ναῦς), BGU 455.9 (i A.D.), etc.

Λῐβύηθεν, from Libya, D.P. 46, 222:—also Λῐβύηθε, Dor. Λῐβῠ-ᾱθε, Nic. Al. 368, Theoc. 1.24:— Adj. Λῐβῠκός, ή, όν, Hdt. 2.8, etc.; Λ. ὄρνεον, i.e. a strange, foreign bird, Ar. Av. 65; Λ. λόγοι a kind of fables resembling those of Aesop, Arist. Rh. 1393a30; also, western, Ptol. Tetr. 119; = δυτικός, Procl. Par.Ptol. 29.
