Fr. 364: - κόν (sc. πλοῖον), τό, a light, swift vessel, felucca, such as was used by the Λιβυρνοί, Plu. Cat.Mi. 54:—also Λῐβυρνός, ὁ, BGU 709.23 (ii A.D.), prob. in Supp.Epigr. 3.565.11 ( Tyras, iii A.D.):—fem. Λῐβυρνίς (sc. ναῦς), ίδος, ἡ, Plu. Ant. 67, etc.; -ίδες νῆσοι Str. 7.5.5:—hence Λῐβυρνάριος, ὁ, Stud.Pal. 20.123.33 (v A.D.).

a Libyan, Hdt. 4.181, al., S. El. 702, etc.: and as Adj., = Λιβυκός, αὐλός E. Alc. 346; Λ. καυλός, = σίλφιον, Antiph. 217.13:—fem. Λίβυσσα [ῐ], Pi. P. 9.105, S. Fr. 11, Hdt. 4.189, Call. Ap. 86, Riv.Fil. 57.379 ( Crete):—also Λῐβυστικός, ή, όν, A. Eu. 292, Fr. 139, etc.; fem. also Λῐβυστίς, ίδος, ἡ, A.R. 4.1753; cf. Λιβύη.

children.label: II
children.definition: serpent, Nic. Th. 490.

children.label: III
children.definition: Hsch.

definition: Λιβυστικόν, τό, a herb, Gal. 6.267, 12.62:—also Λῐβυστιάς, άδος, ἡ, Androm. ap. Gal. 14.40:—hence Λῐβυστικᾶτον, τό, a drink made from it, Alex.Trall. 8.2. [Identical with Λιγυστικόν, q.v.]

children.definition: Liby-Phoenician, i.e. Carthaginian, Plb. 3.33.15, etc.
visiting Libya, Juba ap. Hsch.
Hsch.

definition: λίγα [ῐ], Adv. of λῐγύς (cf. τάχα, ὦκα, etc.),

children.definition: in loud, clear tone, ἀμφʼ αὐτῷ χυμένη λίγʼ ἐκώκυε Il. 19.284, cf. Od. 8.527; λίγʼ ἄειδεν in clear, sweet tone, 10.254, cf. Alcm. 59, Thgn. 939; ζεφύρου λ. κινυμένοιο A.R. 4.837.

cry out with a loud, clear voice, of heralds, Il. 11.685; of mourners, A. Th. 874 (lyr.); of shepherds, Mosch. 3.81; also φόρμιγγι, σύριγγι λ., produce clear sounds on . . , play on . . , A.R. 1.740, AP 9.363.7 ( Mel.): c.acc.cogn., μέλος λ. Bion 2.1, cf. Mosch. 3.120; [ οὐκ] ᾤετο δεῖν τὸν ἐν δικαστηρίοις λόγον κωτίλλειν καὶ λιγαίνειν D.H. Dem. 44:— Med., Arat. 1007:— Pass., of a person, to be made λιγύς, Ὁμήρῳ ὑπὸ Καλλιόπης λιγαινομένῳ Max.Tyr. 3.8.

data.quote: οὐκ] ᾤετο δεῖν τὸν ἐν δικαστηρίοις λόγον κωτίλλειν καὶ λιγαίνειν

children.label: II
children.definition: sing of, AP 9.197 ( Marin.).
charm, ὦτα φθεγξαμένη λ. Ph. 2.267, cf. Hsch. λιγαίνει· τέρπει.

definition: λιγάνταρ εἶδος τέττιγος ( Lacon.), Hsch. λιγγούριον, v. λυγκούριον.

children.definition: λιγδαρεοχύται· οἱ ἐν ταῖς λίγδαις τὰς <ς>άρκας χέοντες, τουτέστι χοάναις, Hsch. λιγδεύει· ἀπηθεῖ, Id.
grazing, βάλε χεῖρʼ ἐπὶ καρπῷ λίγδην Od. 22.278; v. ἐπιλίγδην.
mortar, Nic. Th. 589, 618, cf. S. Fr. 35, and ἴγδις.

children.label: II
children.definition: clay mould, Poll. 10.189, Ael.Dion. Fr. 249.

children.label: III
children.definition: lye, used as soap, Eust. 1229.27: so in Hsch., λίγδα· ἡ ἀκόνη, καὶ ἡ κονία.

definition: λίγειος [ ῐ], α, ον, later form of λιγύς, cj. Coraës for λίγιον, λύγιον (q.v.), Hld. 6.5; λιγήϊα συρίζουσι (Schneid. for λιγέα) Opp. C. 4.411. Adv. - είως Suid.
λιγιπενές ἀσθενές, ἀγεννές, Hsch. (cf. ὀλιγηπελής). λίγνον, =

children.definition: bandum (‘bannerʼ), Gloss. ( σίγνον Scaliger). λιγνύζων, ὁ, v. λιθίζω.
smoky, sooty, καπνός A.R. 2.133, 3.1291.

definition: λιγνύς, ύος, ἡ (parox. in Call. Fr. 1.57 P.),

children.definition: thick smoke mixed with flame, murky fire (such as is made by burning resinous substances, Arist. Mete. 387b6, al.), ἱέντα . . διὰ στόμα λιγνὺν μέλαιναν A. Th. 494; στέροψ λ., of the fires seen by night on the two peaks of Parnassus, S. Ant. 1127 (lyr.); λ. σῶμα καταιθαλοῖ Ar. Av. 1241; λ. καὶ καπνός Id. Lys. 319; λιγνὺς πρόσεδρος S. Tr. 794, expld. by Sch. of the smoke of the altar hanging round Heracles: pl., αἱ φλόγες καὶ αἱ λ. Plb. 34.11.18, cf. Str. 6.2.11.
soot, λ. ἐστι καπνώδης αἰθάλη Erot. s.v. γλῶσσαλιγνυώδης; used medicinally, Dsc. 2.72, Gal. 12.61. [ ῡ Tryph. 322; but ῠ Call. l.c., and prob. in S. Ant. l.c.]
smoky, sooty, dark-coloured, πνεῦμα Hp. Coac. 255; γλῶσσα Id. Epid. 3.17.ιβʹ; opp. καπνώδης, Gal. 9.470; ἀναθυμιάσεις, πνεύματα, Agath. 2.15, 5.8.
Hsch.

definition: λίγξε, only aor. 1, λίγξε βιός the bow

children.definition: twanged, Il. 4.125.

definition: λιγουρά, Boeot. fem. of λιγυρός, Corinn. 21:—also λῐγουροκώτῐλος, α, ον,

children.definition: clear and plaintive, ἐνοπαί Ead. 20.4.

definition: λιγρόν πικρόν, λιγυρόν, ἡδύ, γλυκύ, Hsch.

children.definition: clear-singing, Arc. 86.
Sol. 20.3, cf. Suid. s.v. Μίμνερμος.
clear-sounding, κιθάρη AP 9.308 (Bianor); Μοῦσαι Ath.Mitt. 27.339; dub. in B. Scol.Oxy. 4.

definition: λιγύθροος, ον, = foreg., D.P. 574, Coluth. 276, etc.

children.definition: shrill, νευρά B. 5.73; clear-voiced, χοροί Id. 13.14.
loud-rattling, gloss on λιγυρώτατον, Suid.; cf. foreg.

definition: λιγυμακρόφωνος, ον, epith. of heralds, Tim. Pers. 232.

children.definition: clear-singing, νύμφαι h.Hom. 19.19.
clear-speaking, AP 7.343.
shrill-blowing, whistling, ἄνεμοι h.Ap. 28.

definition: λιγύπνοος, ον, contr. λιγύπνους, ουν, = foreg., Coluth. 309, IG 14.1934f7.

children.definition: chirping with the wings, of the cicada, AP 7.195 ( Mel.).
sing loud or clear, ᾠδήν Luc. Lex. 2, cf. Hsch.

definition: λιγύριον, τό, a precious stone ( Dim. of λίγυρος), LXX Ex. 28.19, J. BJ 5.5.7.

children.definition: Poll. 4.72.

definition: λιγυρός, ά, όν, Boeot. fem. λιγουρά (q.v.),

children.definition: clear, shrill, ὦρτο δὲ κῦμα πνοιῇ ὕπο λιγυρῇ Il. 23.215, cf. 5.526, 13.590; of a whip, 11.532, S. Aj. 242 (anap.); ἀκόνα (v. ἀκόνη) ; λιγυρὰ ἄχεα griefs which vent themselves in shrill wailings, E. Med. 205 (lyr.); also (like λιγύς), of a clear, sweet sound, as of the Sirens, λιγυρῇ θέλγουσιν ἀοιδῇ Od. 12.44; λιγυρὴν ἔντυνον ἀοιδήν ib. 183; of a bird, Il. 14.290; of locusts, Hes. Op. 583; λ. σύριγγες Id. Sc. 278: metaph., of poets, Id. Op. 659; ἀοιδά Theoc. 15.135, etc.: neut. pl. as Adv., λιγυρὰ ἀείδειν Thgn. 939: regul. Adv. -ρῶς Theoc. 8.71.—Poet. word, used occasionally in Prose, λιγυρὸν ὑπηχεῖ echoes shrilly, Pl. Phdr. 230c; φωνὴ λ., opp. λαμπρά, Arist. HA 616b31, cf. Aud. 804a29 ( Comp.): also in later Prose, Plu. Sollert. 2.974a, Luc. Salt. 72, Phal. 1.11, etc.

data.quote: ὦρτο δὲ κῦμα πνοιῇ ὕπο λιγυρῇ

children.definition: συμβιῶναι . . ἥδιστος καὶ -ώτατος Isoc. Ep. 4.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: pliant, flexible, of dogs’ tails, X. Cyn. 4.1.
clearness, sweetness, of Homer, prob. in Phld. Herc. 1677.21.

definition: λιγύς, λίγεια (not λιγεῖα, Hdn.Gr. 1.249), λιγύ; of sound,

children.definition: clear, shrill, λιγέων ἀνέμων λαιψηρὰ κέλευθα Il. 14.17; ὦρτο δʼ ἐπὶ λ. οὖρος Od. 3.176, cf. 4.357: more freq. of a clear, sweet sound, clear-toned, φόρμιγγι λιγείῃ, φόρμιγγα λίγειαν, Il. 9.186, Od. 8.67, etc.; of articulate sounds, clear-voiced, Μοῦσα λίγεια 24.62, Alcm. 1; λ. Σειρήν Id. 7; λ. ἀγορητής in Il. as epith. of Nestor, 1.248, 4.293; also of Thersites, 2.246; ἐπέων οἶμος λ. Pi. O. 9.72. Adv. λιγέως, ἀγορεύειν Il. 3.214: freq. also, λ. κλαίειν wail shrilly, 19.5, Od. 11.391; ἰάχειν Hes. Sc. 233: neut. as Adv., λ. πνείοντες ἀῆται Od. 4.567; λ. μέλπεσθαι Hes. Sc. 206; λιγύ or λιγέα κλάζειν Mosch. 4.24, A.R. 4.1299.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hes., mostly of sad sounds, as always in A., λ. κωκύματα Pers. 332; κἀνακωκύσας λιγύ ib. 468; λ. πάθεα Supp. 113 (lyr.); of the nightingale, Ag. 1146 (lyr.), S. OC 671 (lyr.); also of music, λίγεια λωτοῦ χάρις E. Heracl. 892 (lyr.); αὐλοῦ λ. ἦχον, v.l. for γλυκὺν in Mosch. 2.98.—Poet. word ( Μοῦσαι λίγειαι Pl. Phdr. 237a).

Ligurian, A. Fr. 199.1, Hdt. 5.9, Th. 6.2, etc.: as Adj., Λ. στρατός A. Fr. 199.9 (on the accent, v. Hdn.Gr. 1.236.7):— Adj. Λῐγυστικός, ή, όν, Ligurian, S. Fr. 598, Str. 2.4.3; ἡ Λιγυστική Liguria, Arist. Mete. 351a16, cf. 368b32:—also Λῐγυστῖνος, η, ον, σάγοι, χιτῶνες Str. 4.6.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ λ. bastard lovage, Laserpitium Siler, Dsc. 3.51.
shrill-sounding, φόρμιγγες Pi. Parth. 2 Fr. 1.34.
clear-voiced, in Hom. always epith. of heralds, Il. 2.50, al., Od. 2.6, etc.; αὐλίσκοι Thgn. 241; ἀηδών Ar. Av. 1380; ὄρνιθες B. 5.23; μέλισσα (of a poet) Id. 9.10; αὐδή Opp. H. 5.620.
sound clear or loud, Sch. Theoc. 8.30.
clear-voiced, loud-voiced, ἅρπη Il. 19.350, cf. h.Merc. 478; also of sweet sounds, Ἑσπερίδες Hes. Th. 275, 518; ἀηδών Theoc. 12.7; ἀοιδή Orph. A. 5.

definition: λιδρίον τρύβλιον, Hsch. λίζει· παίζει, and λίζουσι· παίζουσιν, Id. λιζόν· ἔλαττον, Id. (i.e. ὄλιζον). λίζω,

children.definition: graze, Eust. 1926.37, as giving the Root of λίγδην, ἐπιλίγδην. λιζῶνες· ἐλάττονες, Hsch. (Cf. ὀλείζων, ὀλίγος). λίημος· ψάμαθος, Id. (fort. ἄμμος). λίην, Ion. and Ep. for λίαν. λίηνος· λιθοπυργία, Id. λίηφος·, δεινός, Id. λῖθʼ, v. λῖτα.
conveyance of stone, IG 1(2).347.37, SIG 241 B 87 ( Delph., iv B.C.).
for conveying stones, ναῦς IG 1(2).336.8; μηχανή Poll. 10.148.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. λ., ὁ, stone-haulier, SIG 241 A 47, 244i38 (pl., Delph., iv B.C.).
fling stones, Arist. Pr. 881b1, Plb. 10.29.5; ἐπὶ σκοπόν Str. 15.1.43.
throw like stones, χρυσὸν εἴς τινα App. Reg. 4.

children.label: II
children.definition: stone, τινα Anaxandr. 16, LXX 2 Ki. 16.6, Ev.Jo. 10.31:— Pass., dub. sens. in IGRom. 4.494.13 (Pergam.).
Stesich. Oxy. 1087.48; on the accent, v. Hdn.Gr. 1.150.
surgical instrument for extracting stone, Aët. 16.110 (100).
stony, λίθακι ποτὶ πέτρῃ Od. 5.415.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., = λίθος, Arat. 1112, Orph. A. 613; κωφὴ λ., of a gravestone, AP 7.392 ( Heraclid. Sinop.); of a precious stone, Man. 6.343; λ. τρητὴν σπόγγῳ ἐειδομένην, of the pumice- stone, AP 6.66 ( Paul.Sil.).
stony land, Epic. in Arch.Pap. 7.10, v.l. in Nic. Th. 150; cf. ἕρμαξ.

definition: λιθαργύρεος [ ῠ], α, ον, = sq., Stesich. 30.

children.definition: of or like λιθάργυρος, Arist. SE 164b23.
litharge, lead monoxide, Nic. Al. 594, Gal. 13.397, al.: sts. called λ. ἀργυρῖτις, to dist. it from λ. χρυσῖτις (flake litharge), Dsc. 5.87.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., = foreg., Achae. 19.
like litharge, Dsc. 5.85.
Dim. of λίθος, stone, Thphr. HP 3.7.5, Phld. Po.Herc. 1675.5, Dsc. 1.68, 5.40, PKlein.Form. 303 (vi A.D.).
gem, IG 11(2).287 B 46 ( Delos, iii B.C.), Annuario 6/7.405 ( Perge), PHolm. 5.4, al. (Condemned by Phryn. 158.)

stone, σεῦεν κύνας . . πυκνῇσιν λιθάδεσσιν Od. 14.36; θάλαμον δέμον . . πυκνῇσιν λ. 23.193; collectively, shower of stones, A. Th. 158 (lyr.); heap of stones, λιθάδας τε καὶ ἕρμακας ἐνναίοντες, of snakes, Nic. Th. 150 (v.l. λίθακας).
lapis calcinus, Gloss.
stoning, Sch. A. Th. 676.
one who stones, A.D. Adv. 135.25.
by stoning, μόρος Sch. A. Th. 199.
fine stone or marble, Plb. 4.52.7, Str. 9.5.16, J. AJ 8.2.9: collectively, IG ΙΙ(2).287 A 89 ( Delos, iii B.C.), Sammelb. 5801.3 ( i B.C., written - έα, and so in Gloss.).

children.label: II
children.definition: precious stones, jewellery, OGI 132.8 (ii B.C.), Str. 15.1.67, 16.4.22, D.S. 1.46, Peripl.M.Rubr. 56.
A. Pr. 561, 677; also - ος, ον Suid.
stone-merchant, IG 14.2247 ( Picenum), Supp.Epigr. 4.106 ( Rome, ii A.D.).
stone-carrying vessel, PCair.Zen. 176.6, PPetr. 2p.43, 3p.137 (all iii B.C.), IG ΙΙ(2).203 B 97 ( Delos, iii B.C.): pl., Rev.Phil. 50.70 ( Didyma, ii B.C.).
built of stones, AP 6.253 ( Crin.).
the disease of the stone, Hp. Aph. 3.26 (pl.), Gal. 10.917.

children.label: II
children.definition: a callosity within the eyelid, Id. 14.771, Aët. 7.82.

suffer from the stone, Hp. Aph. 4.79, al., Pl. Lg. 916a, IG 42(1).121.68 ( Epid., iv B.C.), Arist. Pr. 895a37, Ruf. Ren.Ves. 3, al., Philostr. VS 1.25.11; [ νοσήματα] -ιῶντα Hp. Hum. 12:—also λῐθάω, which is restored in Pl. l.c., cf. Phot. s.v. λιθῶντας; also λιθόωσα· πολύλιθος, Hsch.
Dim. of λίθος, pebble, gem, Pl. Phd. 110d, Arist. Pr. 934b22, Plu. Sollert. 2.979b, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 4.
gravel in the urine, Hp. Coac. 578 (pl.); stone in the bladder, Paul.Aeg. 6.60 (sg.).
look like a stone: λιθίζων, name of a kind of carbuncle, v.l. in Callistr. ap. Plin. HN 37.94 (sed leg. λιγνύζων).

of or for stones; ἔργα Arch.Pap. 3.128 (ii B.C.); but usu. λιθικά (sc. βιβλία), τά, a treatise upon precious stones, title of Orphic poem, ap. Tz. ( περὶ λίθων codd.); also βιβλία λιθιακά Eust. ad D.P. Prooem.; but Λιθικά, of D.P.’s work, Sch. Od. 10.323.
of or for stone in the bladder, Paul.Aeg. 6.60.

definition: λίθινος, η, ον, also ος, ον AP 9.719, D.L. 2.33:—

children.definition: made of stone, Hippon. 10, Ibyc. 22, Hdt. 3.88, Th. 3.68, Herod. 7.109, PHib. 1.27.26 (iii B.C.), etc.; λ. θάνατος, i.e. caused by seeing the Gorgon’s head, Pi. P. 10.48; so λ. εὐθὺς γίγνομαι Antiph. 166.4; but, ἕστηκε λίθινος, of a statue, Hdt. 2.141 (cf. ἵστημι A.Ι, B.ΙΙΙ.2); τὰ λ. marble statues, X. Lac. 3.5; Ἑρμῆς λ. Eub. 96; for Hdt. 2.69, v. λίθος II.1, ὕαλος II: metaph., καρδία LXX Ez. 11.19. Adv. - νως like stone, λ. βλέπειν πρός τινα, with allusion to the Gorgon, X. Smp. 4.24.
stony quality, dub. in Phld. Herc. 862.6.

definition: λιθίον, τό, Dim. of λίθος, Paus. 2.25.8.
λίθιος, Thess. for λίθινος, IG 9(2).517.21 ( Larissa).

children.definition: Hp. Morb. 4.55.
stone base of a tripod, BCH 29.541 ( Delos).
stoned, θνῄσκει λ. Tz. H. 3.246.
stone-throwing, pelting, εὐστοχίη AP 9.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: set with stones, κεκρύφαλα ib. 5.269 ( Paul.Sil.).
pelt with stones, stone, LXX Le. 20.2, al., D.S. 17.41, Ev.Matt. 21.35, Plu. QPlat. 2.1011e:— Pass., LXX Ex. 8.26(22).
E. Or. 50:—also λῐθο-βόλητος, Hsch. s.v. λευσίμου δίκης.
throwing of stones, Hp. Fract. 2 (pl., v.l. for λιθοβόλησις), D.S. 3.49.

children.label: II
children.definition: stoning, Sch. A. Eu. 189.

children.label: III
children.definition: λιθοβόλια, τά, festival at Troezen, Paus. 2.32.2.
Hsch.

throwing stones, pelting with stones: - βόλοι, οἱ, stone-throwers, distd. from σφενδονῆται, Th. 6.69, cf. J. BJ 3.7.18; γυμνῆτες λ. καὶ ἀκοντισταί Pl. Criti. 119b: sg., as winner of a contest, SIG 1061.6, 19 ( Samos, ii B.C.).

βόλος, ὁ, engine for hurling stones, Plb. 8.5.2, Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208c, Ath. Mech. 18.6; distd. from καταπέλτης, D.S. 20.48; also - βόλον, τό, LXX 1 Ma. 6.51, J. BJ 5.6.3; in full, λ. μηχαναί ib. 4.9.12.

children.label: II
children.definition: λιθόβολος, ον, Pass., struck with stones, stoned, E. Ph. 1063 (lyr.).
stony-eyed, Nonn. D. 48.456.
sculptor in stone, Gloss.
a cutting in stone, Man. 4.130 (dat. pl.); λιθογλυφέεσσι cj. Rigler.
sculptor, Luc. Somn. 18, Gal. 1.7; engraver, Dsc. 5.147 ( v.l. - γράφος); title of play by Philemon, Did. in D. 9.62.
set with sharp stones, ἀγυιαί Nonn. D. 40.354, cf. 6.138.
skilful in stones: λ. (sc. βιβλίον), τό, a work on stones, by Philostr., Suid. s.v. Φιλόστρατος.

definition: λιθογνώμων, ον, gen. ονος, = foreg., Jul. Or. 2.91b.

children.definition: Dsc. Eup. 2.118.
cunningly fashioned in stone, App.Anth. 2.534 (Halic.).
branching coral, Dsc. 5.121.
petrifying with a glance, Γοργώ APl. 16.147 ( Antiphil.).
with stony hide, Arist. Rh. post 1377a7 (interpol.).
throw stones at, Suid.
stone-built, AP 9.570 ( Phld.).
mason, τέκτονες καὶ λιθοδόμοι joiners and masons, X. Cyr. 3.2.11 codd. (sed leg. λιθοτόμοι).
like stone, Hp. Morb. 4.55, Pl. Ti. 74a, Gal. 2.745, etc.
= sq. I, Μέδουσα Opp. C. 3.222.
turning to stone, Γοργώ AP 6.126 ( Diosc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., stonemason, Man. 1.77.
placing of stones, Alex.Polyh. 14.
stone-collector, Tz. H. 11.518.
built of stone, οἰκία Alex.Aphr. in Top. 261.29.
of beautiful stone, μορφή App.Anth. 2.534 (Halic.).
stony-hearted, Sch. E. Or. 121.
with a stone in its head, χρέμυς Arist. Fr. 294.
cement, Dsc. 5.145.

set with precious stones, χιτών Callix. 2; ποτήρια Thphr. Char. 23.3, Parmenio ap. Ath. 11.782a; κρατῆρες Theopomp. Hist. 283 (a); φιάλαι Agatharch. 102; περιτραχήλιον Plu. Alex. 32, cf. Men. 372: metaph., χάλυβος λ. στόμιον a bit of steel set with stones (to make it sharper), S. Tr. 1261 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ λ. inlaid work, mosaic, prob. in Str. 16.4.19, cf. Thphr. Lap. 35 (pl.).

definition: λιθοκομικόν, τό, dub. sens. in IG 1(2).336.9.

children.definition: pelt with stones, UPZ 16.18 ( Pass., ii B.C.).
Suid.
of or for stone-cutting, σκεῦος Eust. 1533.10.
stonecutter, Antipho Soph. 92, D. 47.65, IG 3.307, prob. in 3455.
with crown of stone, of a cliff, Coluth. 103.
death by stoning, AP 9.157.
instrument for extracting the stone, Gal. 14.787.
pelt with stones, Sch. Ar. Ach. 233.
stoned, ὑπὸ τῶν ὄχλων D.S. 3.47; λ. ποιῆσαί τινα Plu. Par.min. 2.313b, Sch. Call. Iamb. in PSI 9.1094.25; λ. Ἄρης death by stoning, S. Aj. 254 (lyr.).
deserving to be stoned, Call. Epigr. 42.5, Alex.Aet. 3.12.
build with unworked stones, IG 2(2).463.39, Poll. 7.118; ὀπτάνιον IG 2(2).1672.189.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be demolished, Aq. Mi. 3.12.
foundation of unworked stone, X. Cyr. 6.3.25, IG 2(2).463.45 (pl.), 1672.47.
laying of a foundation of unworked stones, IG 2(2).463.97.
heap of stones, Aq. Ps. 78(79).1.

one who picks out stones for building: hence, one who builds with stones picked out to fit their places, not squared (cf. λογάς 2), BSA 3.112 ( Athens): so generally, mason, Pl. Lg. 858b; λιθολόγοι καὶ τέκτονες masons and joiners, Th. 6.44, cf. 7.43, X. HG 4.4.18.
adorned with statues, Nonn. D. 4.273.
workshop of a λιθοξόος, Gloss.
of or for stone-cutting, Klio 10.232, Eust. 341.28.
stone- or marble-mason, Luc. Somn. 9, Max.Tyr. 38.7, 39.5, f.l. in Timo 25.
sculptor, Plu. Adul. 2.74d, IG 3.1372, AP 5.14 ( Rufin.).
turn to stone, v.l. in Luc. DMar. 14.3.
turning to stone, Μέδουσα Luc. Im. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: producing stone in the bladder, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.109.
sawing stone or marble, πρίων IG 1(2).313.129, Poll. 10.148.
Hsch.
with stony skin, χελώνη Emp. 76.2.

definition: λίθος [ ῐ], ου, ὁ (v. infr. II),

children.definition: stone, Hom., etc.; esp. of the stones thrown by warriors, τρηχὺς λ., λ. ὀκριόεις, Il. 5.308, 8.327; also, stone-quoit, Od. 8.190; ἑλέσθαι . . ἐκ γαίας λίθον A. Fr. 199.4; of building- stones, λίθοι βασιλικοί PSI 4.423.28, PCair.Zen. 499.20 (both iii B.C.): prov., ἐν παντὶ γάρ τοι σκορπίος φρουρεῖ λίθῳ S. Fr. 37; λίθον ἕψειν ‘to lose oneʼs labour’, Ar. V. 280; also of stupid persons, ‘blockheads’, λίθοι Id. Nu. 1202, cf. Thgn. 568, Pl. Hp.Ma. 292d, Gal. 9.656; λ. τις, οὐ δούλη Herod. 6.4; προσηγορεύθη διὰ τὸ μὴ φρονεῖν λ., of Niobe, Philem. 101; ὥσπερ λίθον ζῆν Pl. Grg. 494a sq.; λίθῳ λαλεῖς prov. of ἀναίσθητοι, Macar. 5.61.

data.quote: ἐν παντὶ γάρ τοι σκορπίος φρουρεῖ λίθῳ

children.definition: stone as a substance, opp. wood, flesh, etc., ἐπεὶ οὔ σφι λ. χρὼς οὐδὲ σίδηρος Il. 4.510; λαοὺς δὲ λίθους ποίησε turned into stone, petrified, 24.611, cf. Pl. Smp. 198c; so [ νῆα] θεῖναι λ. Od. 13.156; as an emblem of hard-heartedness, σοὶ δʼ αἰεὶ κραδίη στερεωτέρη ἐστὶ λίθοιο 23.103, cf. Theoc. 3.18.

data.quote: ἐπεὶ οὔ σφι λ. χρὼς οὐδὲ σίδηρος
σοὶ δʼ αἰεὶ κραδίη στερεωτέρη ἐστὶ λίθοιο

children.label: II
children.definition: λίθος, ἡ, twice in Hom., Il. 12.287, Od. 19.494, just like masc., also in Theoc. 7.26, Bion Fr. 1.2: later mostly of some special stone, as the magnet is called Μαγνῆτις λ. by E. Fr. 567 (but ἡ λίθος simply in Democr. 11k, Arist. Ph. 267a2, cf. v.l. de An. 405a20); also Λυδία λ. by S. Fr. 800 (but in B. Fr. 10 J. Λυδία λ. = touchstone); Ἡρακλεία λ. by Pl. Ion 533d, Epicur. Fr. 293; so of a touchstone, Pl. Grg. 486d; ἡ διαφανὴς λ. a piece of crystal used for a burning-glass, Ar. Nu. 767, cf. Luc. Alex. 21; χυτὴ λ. was perh. a kind of glass, and so an older name for ὕαλος, Epin. 1.8 (the same thing as the ἀρτήματα λίθινα χυτά in Hdt. 2.69; cf. τὴν ὕαλον . . ὅσα τε λίθων χυτὰ εἴδη καλεῖται Pl. Ti. 61c); λ. = precious stone is fem. in Hp. Nat.Mul. 99, IG 2(2).1421.92, 1460.21, but masc. in Hdt. 2.44, etc.; in the sense of marble mostly masc., λευκὸς λ. Id. 4.87 (simply λίθος 1.164), S. Fr. 330 ( λευκοὶ λ. is opp. πέτρινοι λ. Supp.Epigr. 4.446.8 ( Didyma)); Πάριος λ. Pi. N. 4.81, Hdt. 3.57; Ταινάριος λ. Str. 8.5.7; λ. Θάσιος, Αἰγύπτιος, etc., Paus. 1.18.6, etc.; κογχίτης Id. 1.44.6; κογχυλιάτης X. An. 3.4.10; but Παρία λ. Theoc. 6.38, Luc. Am. 13; cf. λυχνίας, -ίτης; πώρινος λ. tufa, Hdt. 5.62.

data.quote: τὴν ὕαλον . . ὅσα τε λίθων χυτὰ εἴδη καλεῖται

children.definition: πέφυκε λίθος . . ἄφθονος, ἐξ οὗ . . X. Vect. 1.4.

children.label: III
children.definition: grave-stone (fem.), Call. Epigr. 8.1.

children.label: IV
children.definition: λίθος, ὁ, was a name for various blocks of stone used for rostra or platforms, as,
βῆμα (q.v.) of the Pnyx, Ar. Ach. 683, Pax 680, Ec. 87.
ἀγορά used by the κήρυκες, Plu. Sol. 8; prob. the same as ὁ πρατὴρ λ., on which the auctioneer stood when selling slaves, etc., Poll. 3.78, cf. 126.
altar in the ἀγορά, at which the Thesmothetae, arbitrators, and witnesses took their oaths, Philoch. 65, D. 54.26 (restored from Harp. s.v. λίθος), Arist. Ath. 7.1, 55.5, Plu. Sol. 25; cf. λιθωμότης.
stones on which litigants stood in the Areopagus, Paus. 1.28.5.

children.label: V
children.definition: piece on a draughtboard, Alc. 82, Theoc. 6.18, cf. γραμμή III.1: hence pron., πάντα λίθον κινεῖν Zen. 5.63 (who explains it differently).

children.label: VI
children.definition: stone in the bladder, calculus, Arist. HA 519b19, Hp. Morb. 4.55, al.

children.label: VII
children.definition: Δία λίθον ὀμνύναι, = Lat. Jovem lapidem jurare, Plb. 3.25.6.

children.label: VIII
children.definition: λίθοι χαλάζης hail- stones, LXX Jo. 10.11.

children.label: IX
children.definition: λ. ὁ οὐ λ. the philosophers’ stone, Zos. Alch. p.122 B.

definition: λιθοσπαδής ἁρμός, a chasm in the vault

children.definition: made by tearing out stones, S. Ant. 1216.
gromwell, Lithospermum officinale, Dsc. 3.141, Ps.- Gal. 19.694.
covered with stones, Sch. Lyc. 350.
paved with stones, S. Ant. 1204; δρόμος POxy. 2138.15 (iii A.D.), PFlor. 50.97 (iii A.D.).

tessellated work, λ. ἔδαφος Str. 17.1.28, Poll. 7.121; λ., τό, mosaic or tessellated pavement, IG 42(1).110.19 ( Epid., iv/iii B.C.), LXX Ca. 3.10, Ev.Jo. 19.13, CIG 2643 (Cyprus, - στρατ-), Roussel Délos: Colonie Athénienne p.422, Arr. Epict. 4.7.37 (v.l.), etc.

children.definition: Gloss.
quarry, Ph. 1.235, Philostr. VA 3.48:— Pass., to be cut out of stone, Luc. JTr. 10.

children.label: II
children.definition: cut for the stone, Gal. 1.168:— Pass., Dsc. 5.15, Paul.Aeg. 6.60.
stone-quarry, IG 2(2).1666 B72: mostly in pl., quarries, Hdt. 2.8, Th. 7.86, 87, D. 53.17; marble quarries, Thphr. Lap. 6, Paus. 1.32.1 (sg. in 1.18.9, 1.19.6), etc.; cf. λατομία.

Hermes 38.282.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., λ., ὁ, surgeon who cuts for the stone, Gal. 1.125, Thras. 24; but, who cuts the stone (internally), Ammonius ὁ λ. Cels. 7.26.3.

children.label: b
children.definition: λ., τό, knife for cutting for the stone, Paul.Aeg. 6.60.
stony-, i.e. stiff-necked, Jul. Gal. 213b.
of or for stone-polishing: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη), the art of so polishing, Lys. Fr. 69.
draw or quarry stones, Suid.: metaph., drag slowly along, Hsch.
haulage of stone, IG 1(2).347.38, al.
quarrying stones, Poll. 7.118.

children.label: II

work in stone, hew, λίθον LXX Ex. 35.33: abs., Porph. Hist.Phil. 11; carve a gem, PMag.Berol. 1.68.

children.label: II
children.definition: turn into stone, petrify, γυῖα AP 3.11 (Cyzic.), cf. Philostr. Im. 1.11.
worked in stone, εἰκόνισμα S. Fr. 574; βότρυς Aristeas 70.
sculpture in marble, IG 1(2).347.39, D.S. 4.76; working at or in stone, Thom.Mag. p.221R.: in pl., stone-quarries, Brut. Ep. 37.
of or for a λιθουργός, τέχνη LXX Ex. 28.11: - κά, τά, ib. 31.5: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη), Lys. Fr. 69: - κόν, τό, sum spent on masonry, IG 1(2).374.317, al.
stone-mason, Ar. Av. 1134, Th. 4.69, 5.82, etc.; sculptor in marble, opp. ἀνδριαντοποιός (in bronze), Arist. EN 1141a10, cf. Supp.Epigr. 3.464 (Thess., iv B.C.).
σιδήρια λιθουργά a stone-masonʼs tools, Th. 4.4.
passing gravel with the urine, Sch. Pi. P. 1.87.
carry stones, Th. 6.98.
carrying stones, ὁλκάδες D.S. 13.78; κεραῖαι Moschio ap. Ath. 5.208d; ἱερεύς IG 3.296.
Subst. λ., ὁ, = λιθοβόλος I.2, Plb. 4.56.3.
Dsc. 5.123), Olymp.Alch. p.93 B., Paul.Aeg. 3.59.
stone-polisher, Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).216 (- ψύκτ- cod.).

to be petrified, Arist. PA 641a21, GA 783a28, Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.577f, Luc. Asin. 4: impers., λιθοῦται petrifaction takes place, Arist. Pr. 937a17.
λελιθωμένον, prob. = λιθόστρωτον, Poll. 7.121.

like stone, stony, γῆ Hdt. 4.23; ὁδός X. Eq. 4.4; τόποι τραχεῖς καὶ λ. Arist. HA 590b23; πεδίον (as pr. n.) Str. 4.1.7: Comp., of plants, Arist. GA 783a31: metaph., λ. [κέαρ] Pl. Tht. 194e; Νιόβης αὐτῆς -ωδέστερος Lyd. Mag. 3.61. Adv. - δῶς, ὅσα (sc. ὕδατα) προσπήγνυται τοῖς χαλκείοις λ. Ruf. Fr. 66.16.
stone-like hardness, Eust. 24.7.
one that took an oath at the altar ( λίθος IV.3), Com.Adesp. 667.
gleaming with jewels, ὀφθαλμοί, of the Wooden Horse, Tryph. 68.
λιθῶπις, ιδος, turning one to stone by a look, Nonn. D. 30.265.
a turning into stone, petrifying, Plu. Frig. 2.953e.

children.label: II
children.definition: work in stone, λ. ποικίλη Aristeas 74.

definition: λικερτίζειν σκιρτᾶν, Hsch. λίκηνον· ἀγγεῖον ὀστράκινον, Id. λίκιγξ· ἡ ἐλαχίστη βοὴ τῶν ὀρνέων, Sch. Ar. Ach. 1034. λικμάζειν· περιλείχειν, Hsch.

Oec. 18.6; καρπὸν ἀπʼ ἀσταχύων B. l.c.: metaph., scatter like chaff, LXX Ez. 29.12; make away with, ib. Is. 30.22; crush, destroy, ἐλίκμησάν μου τὸ λάχανον BGU 146.8 (iii A.D.); ἐφʼ ὃν δʼ ἂν πέσῃ (sc. ὁ λίθος) λικμήσει αὐτόν Ev.Luc. 20.18.
winnower of corn, Il. 13.590.
winnowing-fan, shovel, Sm. Je. 15.7, Thd. Is. 30.14, Hsch.
PFay. 101.4 (i B.C.), Poll. 1.222, Aq., Sm. Je. 51(28).2, Serv.Dan.ad Verg. G. 1.166.
of or for winnowing, πτύον Eust. 135.43.
winnowing, AP 6.225 ( Nicaen.).
Lyd. Ost. 20.
PFay. 120.4 (i/ii A.D.), Gloss.
λ. ἀσεβῶν LXX Pr. 20.20(26).
LXX Am. 9.9, Sammelb. 5230.2 (i A.D.), Serv.Dan.ad Verg. G. 1.166, Hsch.

definition: λικνάριον, τό, Dim. of λίκνον, Gloss.

of the λίκνον, epith. of Dionysus, Orph. H. 46.1, 52.3, Plu. Isid. 2.365a:—fem. λικν-ῖτις, τροφή S. Ichn. 269.
Suid., Zonar.

definition: λίκνον, τό (also λεῖκνον acc. to Hdn.Gr. 2.543, and λικμός (q.v.)),

children.definition: winnowing-fan, i.e. a broad basket, in which the corn was placed after threshing, and then thrown against the wind so as to winnow the grain from the chaff, Arist. Mete. 368b29; sacred to Dionysus, and carried on the head at his festivals, AP 6.165 ( Phal.); also to Athena, S. Fr. 844; cf. λικνίτης, λικνοφόρος.

children.definition: cradle, h.Merc. 21, 150, al., Call. Jov. 48, Arat. 268, Gal. 6.37, etc.
carry the sacred λίκνον, Polem.Hist. 88.
carrying the sacred λίκνον in procession, D. 18.260, Call. Cer. 127.
part. dat. pl. λιγνοῦσιν (sic), dub. in Ostr.Strassb. 748 (ii A.D.).
cross-wise, sideways, λ. ἀΐξας Il. 14.463, Od. 19.451.

definition: λικροί οἱ ὔζοι τῶν ἐλαφείων κεράτων, Hsch. (also λεκροί Id.). λίκτης, ου, ὁ, ( λείχω)

children.definition: one that licks, Gloss. (better λείκτης).

long or desire earnestly, freq. in Hom., mostly c. inf., long to be or do so and so, τίμε . . λιλαίεαι ἠπεροπεύειν; Il. 3.399; λ. πολεμίζειν 16.89; εὐνηθῆναι 14.331: metaph., of a lance, λιλαιομένη χροὸς ἆσαι longing to taste flesh, 21.168, cf. 11.574, 15.317; λιλαιομένη πόσιν εἶναι longing for him to be her husband, Od. 1.15, 9.30, 32, 23.334: c. gen., long for, πολέμοιο, ὁδοῖο, βιότοιο, δόρποιο, Il. 3.133, Od. 1.315, 12.328, 13.31; also φόωσδε λιλαίεο struggle to the light of day, 11.223: so in later Ep., c. inf., A.R. 3.394, al.: c. acc., Nonn. D. 28.144: abs., ib. 42.132.—Cf. λελίημαι.

definition: λιλεῖ φθονεῖ, ἐπιθυμεῖ, Hsch. λιλουργετά· ἐν τῷ σώματι ἐξανθήματα, Id. λίλυ· τὸ ὕδωρ (Libyan word), Id.

famished, Hp. Epid. 2.1.8.
Hp. Art. 81, Antisth. ap. Stob. 3.8.26, LXX De. 8.3, Gal. 15.573.
of or for reducing by hunger, Gal. 1.605.
suffer from famine, of armies, Hdt. 6.28, 7.25; of a country, Nic.Dam. 45 J.
starved, Hsch.
Hdn. Epim. 77; λιμβία, Hsch. s.v. λιχνία.
Hdn. l.c.
Hsch., Anon. in EN 182.9, etc.
= Lat. limbus, a dinner-dress, Lyd. Mag. 2.4.

harbour-master, PGiss. 10.4 (ii A.D.), Cod.Just. 7.16.38, Gloss.
closing in the harbour, ἄκρη A.R. 2.965.

definition: λιμένιον, τό, Dim. of λιμήν, Str. 5.2.6 (pl.), Marcian. Epit. 8.

definition: λιμενίτης [ νῑ], ου, ὁ, voc. λιμενῖτα,

children.definition: god of the harbour, of Priapus, AP 10.1 ( Leon.), cf. 10.17 ( Antiphil.):—fem. λῐμεν-ῖτις, ιδος, of Artemis, ib. 6.105 ( Apollonid.).
λ. φυλακτῆρες custom-house officers, Dam. Isid. 186.
of a harbour, χρήματα harbour-dues, Cod.Just. 10.30.4 (- ητικός codd.).
like a harbour, κόλπος Str. 5.1.9.
construction of harbours, Tz. H. 2.8 (pl.).
things belonging thereto, Ph. Bel. 49.3.

definition: λιμενορμίτης [ μῑ], ου, ὁ, ( λιμήν, ὅρμος)

children.definition: god of harbours and mooring-places, epith. of Priapus, AP 10.5 ( Thyill.).
watching the harbour, epith. of Zeus and Phoebus, Call. Fr. 114, AP 10.25 ( Antip.): as fem., Call. Dian. 259.
harbour-making, Tz. H. 11.621.
harbour-watcher, Aen.Tact. 29.12: title of magistrate at Carystus, IG 12(9).8 (ii B.C.), 9 (i B.C.); τὸν λι[μενοφυλακοῦντα Ἀ] θηναίων may perh. be restored, ib. 2(2).133.23 (iv B.C.).

harbour, Il. 1.432 (here distd. fr. ὅρμος, mooringplace), al., Pl. Ti. 25a, etc.; Κανθάρου λ. a dockyard in the Piraeus, with a pun on κάνθαρος just above, Ar. Pax 145 (ubi v. Sch.): freq. in pl., λιμένες νηῶν ὀχοί Od. 5.404; λιμένες δʼ ἔνι ναύλοχοι αὐτῇ 4.846; λιμένες τε πάνορμοι 13.195, cf. S. Ph. 936, etc.: c. gen. objecti, λιμένες θαλάσσης havens of refuge from the sea, Od. 5.418, cf. Hes. Sc. 207.

Supp. 471; ὦ ναυτίλοισι χείματος λ. φανείς E. Andr. 891; ὕπνον . . τῶν καμάτων λ. Critias 6.20 D.; λ. τῆς πλάνης ἥδε ἡ γῆ μόνη λείπεται D.H. 1.58.

Ant. 1000; Ἅιδου λ. harbour of death, ib. 1284 (lyr.); ξείνων αἰδοῖοι λιμένες Emp. 112.3; βοῆς τῆς σῆς ποῖος οὐκ ἔσται λ.; what place shall not harbour (i.e. receive) thy cry? S. OT 420.

to be stagnant, Id. HA 513b4, Gal. UP 14.10.

Av. 272; of the crocodile, ἐὸν . . τετράπουν, χερσαῖον καὶ λ. ἐστι Hdt. 2.68; λ. κρηνῶν τέκνα, of frogs, Ar. Ra. 211; of the beaver, Nic. Al. 307; of an eel, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 8.355d (vulg. λιμνία) λ. φυτόν water-plant, Plu. Pyth. 2.399f.

of or for marshes, λ. πλοῖον, σκάφος, PLond. 2.317.9 (ii A.D.), Hld. 1.31; λ. ἄνεμοι Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: Λίμναι) of or from Limnae, epith. of Dionysus, from his temple there, Call. Fr. 37 P.: but Λιμναῖον, τό, a temple of Artemis at Limnae, on the borders of Laconia and Messenia, Str. 8.4.9, cf. Paus. 3.2.6: hence she was called Λιμνᾶτις v. λιμνήτης; also Λιμναία, epith. of Artemis at Sicyon and elsewhere, Id. 2.7.6, etc.

definition: λιμνάς, άδος, ἡ, poet. fem. of λιμναῖος, Theoc. 5.17, Babr. 115.1, Paus. 3.7.4.

children.definition: marshy ground, Arist. Pr. 938a7.
irrigation, flooding, PFlor. 21.3 (iii A.D.), POxy. 2121.41 (iii A.D.).
irrigation works, BGU 91.5 (ii A.D.).
supervisor of irrigation-works, PTeb. 209 (i B.C.), Wilcken Chr. 392.4 (ii A.D.).

definition: λιμνεία, ἡ, and λίμν-ευσις, εως, ἡ,

children.definition: Zonar.

pool of standing water left by the sea or a river, Il. 21.317: hence, marshy lake, mere, distd. from ἕλος, Pl. Criti. 114e, Lg. 824c; Βοιβηΐς λ. Il. 2.711; Γυγαίη ib. 865; Κηφισίς 5.709; λ. Γοργῶπις A. Ag. 302; Μαιῶτις Id. Pr. 419 (lyr.), cf. 729, Pers. 871 (lyr.), Hdt. 4.86; ἡ Βόλβη λ. Th. 4.103; λ. τροχοειδής, at Delos, Hdt. 2.170, cf. A. Eu. 9.

children.label: b
children.definition: artificial pool or basin, Hdt. 1.185, 191, al., SIG 799 ii 3 (Cyzic., i A.D.).

Hom. and other Poets, the sea, Il. 24.79, Od. 3.1; βένθεσι λίμνης Il. 13.21, 32: so in Trag. in lyr., λίμνᾳ πορφυροειδεῖ A. Supp. 529; ἐπʼ οἶδμα λίμνας S. Fr. 476, E. Hec. 446; Πόσειδον, ὃς γλαυκᾶς μέδεις . . λίμνας S. Fr. 371; Μηλίδα πὰρ λ. by the Malian bay, Id. Tr. 636.

children.label: II
children.definition: Λίμναι, αἱ, (used without the article), a quarter of Athens (once prob. marshy), near the Acropolis, in which stood the Lenaeum, Ar. Ra. 216, Th. 2.15, Is. 8.35, etc., cf. λιμναῖος II.
a quarter or suburb of Sparta, Str. 8.5.1.
a place in Messenia, Id. 8.4.9.
from the lake or sea, A.R. 4.1579.
Dsc. 3.7; = κενταύρειον τὸ μέγα, Ps.- Dsc. 3.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: Damocr. ap. Gal. 13.1051.

definition: Λιμνήσιος, ὁ, Laker, name of a frog, v.l. in Batr. 223.

children.definition: v.l. in Gal. 6.434.
drug prepared from λιμνήσιον II, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.92 (s.v.l.).

definition: λιμνήστιον, τό, = foreg. [λιμνήστινον], Rh.Mus. 58.104 ( λημνίστιον ib. 101).

children.definition: Dsc. 3.6, cf. Aret. CA 1.2, al.; = ἀδάρκη, Gal. 6.434:—also λιμν-ηστρίς, ίδος, ἡ, = ἀδάρκη, Androm. ap. Gal. 13.1036: gen. sg. λημνίτιδος (sic) Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.101.

definition: λιμνήτης, ου, ὁ, fem. λιμν-ῆτις, Dor. λιμν-ᾶτις, ιδος,

children.definition: living in marshes, βδέλλα Theoc. 2.56.
superintendent of lakes, POxy. 117.20 (ii/iii A.D.).

definition: λίμνιον, τό, Dim. of λίμνη, Arist. Mir. 840b33, dub. in Phld. Mort. 32.

definition: λιμνῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, epith. of the moon, Hymn.Mag. 5.46.

children.definition: living in a lake, opp. χερσόβιος, Ael. NA 6.10, Philum. Ven. 36.1.
Adv. - δῶς Eust.ad D.P. 48.
lagoon, Xanth. 3, Arist. HA 598a20, GA 761b7, Gal. 6.711; later, of the Dead Sea, Aët. 1 Praef.
candidate for the prize at the Lenaea, v. λίμνη II.1, Hsch.
become a marsh, Thphr. HP 5.4.6, CP 5.12.3, Str. 5.3.13.
POxy. 103.18 (iv A. D.).
edible oyster, which was kept in ponds by the sea ( λίμναι), Arist. HA 528a23, 547b11, GA 763a30.
marsh-bodied, ἐγχέλεις Eub. 37 (s. v.l.).
one who works in λίμναι, fisherman, Plu. Mar. 37.
marsh-born, δόναξ AP 6.23.
Grace of the marsh, or λιμνο-χᾰρής, Love-marsh, name of a frog, Batr. 12, 212.
marshy, ὕδωρ Hp. Aër. 10, cf. Arist. Mete. 353b24; ὁ Πόντος ἐστὶ λ. διὰ τὸ πολλοὺς ποταμοὺς εἰς αὐτὸν ῥεῖν Id. Pr. 932a28.

crave after fame, Ph. 2.273, 534.
craving for fame, Ph. 1.290.

definition: Λιμοδωριεῖς, οἱ, name given to colonists driven by famine from Peloponnesus, Hsch.

one who starves himself from avarice, Com.Adesp. 1073.

definition: λιμός, οῦ, ὁ ( Dor. ἡ, acc. to Phryn. 164, used by the Megarian in Ar. Ach. 743, cf. Herod. 2.17, Bion Fr. 14.4; Λ. ἔχων γυναικὸς μορφήν Callisth. ap. Ath. 10.452b; also h.Cer. 311, Call. Supp.Hell. 288.43, Plb. 1.84.9, AP 9.89 ( Phil.), Ev.Luc. 15.14, Act.Ap. 11.28):—

children.definition: hunger, famine, δίψα τε καὶ λ. Il. 19.166; λιμῷ θανέειν Od. 12.342; λιμὸν ὁμοῦ καὶ λοιμόν Hes. Op. 243, cf. Th. 2.54; λ. αἰανής Pi. I. 1.49; λιμῷ συνεστεῶτας Hdt. 7.170; σκότῳ λ. ξύνοικος A. Ag. 1642; δείπνου προφήτην λιμόν Antiph. 217.23; ἅπανθʼ ὁ λ. γλυκέα πλὴν αὑτοῦ ποιεῖ Id. 293; ὁ δὲ λ. ἐστιν ἀθανασίας φάρμακον Id. 86.6: prov., ἀπολεῖτε λιμῷ Μηλίῳ, referring to the siege of Melos, Ar. Av. 186: metaph., ἤδη γὰρ εἶδον . . λιμόν τʼ ἐν ἀνδρὸς πλουσίου φρονήματι, γνώμην δὲ μεγάλην ἐν πένητι σώματι E. El. 371.

children.label: II

λιμφεύειν ἀπατᾶν, Hsch. λιμφός· συκοφάντης, ἢ μηνυτὴς παρανόμων, Id.

definition: λιναγερτουμένη (fort. - αγρε-) · ἐνημμένη λινά, κακοείμων, λινεργοῦσα, Hsch.

Dim. of λίνον, thread, Roussel Cultes Égyptiens p.213 ( Delos, ii B. C.), Dsc. 2.171, PMag.Par. 1.1083.
sail, POxy. 2136.6 (iii A. D.), PLond. 3.1164h7 (iii A. D.).

Suid.
flax-merchant, POxy. 1414.7 (iii A. D.).

Aet. 3.1.37 [Fr. 75.37 Pf.]; ὅπλα λ. cables of flax, Hdt. 7.36: also λινᾶ, τά, A. Fr. 206, Ar. Fr. 19: Subst. λινέη, ἡ, tape-measure used in building, IG 7.3073.128 ( Lebadea), cf. Bito 63.7, 9 (v.l. λιναία); cf. λιναῖος.

surrounding with nets or snares, Nonn. D. 26.55; cf. foreg.

λινόσπερμον), Ps.- Dsc. 2.103.

sail-wafting, αὖραι E. IT 410 (lyr.).

sail-winged, λ. ναυτίλων ὀχήματα A. Pr. 468.

Fr. 139.5, Hdt. 2.79, E. HF 348 (lyr.), Ar.Byz. ap. Ath. 14.619c, and v. οἰτόλινος. (In Il. l.c. purchase of flax, PPetr. 3p.187, al. (iii B. C.).

definition: λίξ πλάγιος, καὶ λίθος πλατύς, Hsch.; also,

children.definition: Id. λιολεθρίᾳ· παντελεῖ ὀλέθρῳ, Id. λιοπέτριον· λίθος λεῖος, Id.

definition: λίπα [ῐ], used by Hom. as Adv. usu. in the phrase ἀλείψασθαι λίπʼ ἐλαίῳ anoint oneself

children.definition: richly with oil, Il. 10.577, 14.171, al.; χρῖσαι, χρίσασθαι λίπʼ ἐλαίῳ, Od. 3.466, 6.96, 10.364, Hes. Op. 522: once without ἐλαίῳ, λοέσσατο καὶ λίπʼ ἄλειψεν Od. 6.227; so later, τῷ ῥοδίνῳ ἀλείφεσθαι λίπα Hp. Mul. 2.150; ἐλαίῳ χρίων λίπα ib. 147: also without a dat., χρίεσθαι λίπα ib. 1.35; λίπα ἀλείψασθαι, ἀλείψεσθαι, Th. 1.6, 4.68, cf. Thphr. HP 9.8.5, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hp. sts. as Subst., neut. nom. or acc., χρῖσμα λίπα ἔστω Mul. 2.133; μηδʼ ἄλλο τι πῖον μηδὲ λίπα ἔχον ib. 145; so λίπα ἀσκεῖν D.C. 53.27. (Cf. λίπος.)
brotherless, Epigr.Gr. 241.9 ( Smyrna).

definition: λιπαίνω, aor. ἐλίπηνα Opp. H. 4.357, ἐλίπᾱνα Axionic. 4.10:— Med., aor. ἐλιπήνατο Euph. 9.9; part. λιπηνάμενος APl. 16.273 ( Crin.):— Pass., aor. ἐκ-λιπανθῆναι Plu. Mar. 21: pf. λελίπασμαι Damocr. ap. Gal. 13.225:—

children.definition: oil, anoint, τὴν κεφαλὴν ἐλαίῳ Hp. Mul. 1.35; χρῶτα μύροις Anaxil. 18.1; χαρᾶς ὕπο σῶμα λ. ἱδρῶτι Aspasia ap. Ath. 5.219c; πάσμασι σῶμα λ. Axionic. l.c., cf. PMag.Osl. 1.212; of oiling the τόνοι in a machine to preserve them, Ph. Bel. 61.37:— Med., anoint oneself, AP l.c.
make fat, enrich, χώραν ὕδασιν E. Ba. 575 (lyr.), cf. Hec. 454 (lyr.); of Sciron swallowed by a sea-tortoise, χέλυος . . ἐλιπήνατο λαιμόν Euph. l.c. (s. v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: glisten with tears, Epicur. Fr. 120.
to be in want of men, Ephor. 216 J.
want of men, Str. 13.1.32, J. BJ 3.3.2.
anointing, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.29.1.
one must anoint, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.104.
of or for anointing, ἔλαιον Sch. Od. 6.227.

Lipara, the largest of the Aeolian islands, Th. 3.88, etc.:— Adj. Λῐπᾰραῖος, α, ον, of Lipara, αἱ Λ. νῆσοι the group of these islands, Plb. 1.25.4, etc.; ἡ Λιπαραίων πόλις Arist. Mete. 367a6; λίθος Λιπαραῖος a stone like volcanic glass or obsidian, Thphr. Lap. 14, Orph. L. 692.
with bright fillet or headband, Μναμοσύνα Pi. N. 7.15; parodied by Ar. Ach. 671 (lyr.), as epith. of fishsauce.
bright-beaming, πορθμίδες Philox. 3.1.

persist, persevere, hold out, of obstinate resistance, λιπαρήσομεν οὕτω, ὅκως ἂν ἔχωμεν Hdt. 8.144: in part., τοὺς Λυδοὺς τέως μὲν διάγειν λιπαρέοντας continued to hold out, under pressure of famine, Id. 1.94: reversely, with part. added, λιπαρέετε μένοντες persist in holding your ground, Id. 9.45; ἐλιπάρεε ἱστορέων persisted in inquiring, Id. 3.51: c. dat., λ. τῇ πόσει keep on drinking, Id. 5.19; λ. τῇ ἑταίρᾳ D.L. 6.66.
to be importunate, λιπαρεόντων δὲ αὐτῶν Hdt. 1.86, cf. 2.42, 9.111, A. Pr. 520, Pl. Cra. 413c, Men. Epit. 54, Herod. 6.28, 93; γενοῦ γλίσχρος προσαιτῶν λιπαρῶν τε Ar. Ach. 452, cf. D. 21.206.

inf., beseech one to do a thing, A. Pr. 1004; also τοῦ με χρείας ὧδε λιπαρεῖς τυχεῖν; to obtain what request dost thou so importune me? S. OT 1435; λιπαροῦντι μὲν τυχεῖν importunate to obtain, Id. OC 776; ξυγγενέσθαι . . μʼ ἐλιπάρει . . μάζαις importuned me to become acquainted with cakes, Telecl. 38 (cj. Porson), cf. X. Oec. 2.16; also λ. τινὰ ὅπως . . PAmh. 2.79.47 (ii A. D.); ἐξαιτήσεσθαι καὶ λιπαρήσειν παρʼ ὑμῶν αὐτόν entreat earnestly for him at your hands, D. 21.208; but also λ. βωμούς importune . . , Plb. 32.15.7:— Pass., to be earnestly entreated, ὑπό τινων X. HG 3.5.12.
persisting or persevering in a thing, earnest, indefatigable, περί τινος Pl. Cra. 413a; περί τι, πρός τι, Id. Hp.Mi. 369d, 372b: also c. gen., παιδείας Luc. Am. 6.
λ. χειρουργία Ar. Lys. 672; προθυμία Luc. Abd. 4; λ. πυρετός an obstinate fever, Id. Hist.Conscr. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: earnest in begging or praying, importunate, c. part., λ. ἦσαν δεόμενοι Plu. TG 6; ἀκοῦσαί τι βουλόμενοι λ. ἦσαν Id. QConv. 2.665e; λ. χείρ a hand instant in prayer, S. El. 1378: c. gen., fawning upon, τῶν ἐν ἐξουσίᾳ Plu. Max. cum princip. 2.776b; τὸ λ. importunity, Luc. Herm. 24; πρὸς τὸ λ., = λιπαρῶς, S. OC 1119.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. - ρῶς earnestly, importunately, Pl. Lg. 931c; λ. ἔχων ἀκούειν longing earnestly to hear, Id. Prt. 315e; λ. ἔχω γίγνεσθαί τι I am importunate in desiring that . . , ib. 335b.
supplication, D.H. 1.81 (pl.).
one must be importunate, X. Ap. 23.
persistence, perseverance, λιπαρίῃ τε καὶ ἀρετῇ ἀντέχομεν Hdt. 9.21, cf. 70; importunity, Ael. Fr. 61.
fatness, Dsc. 1.40.

definition: λιπαρίσχιος, ον, dub. sens. in Lyr. in Philol. 80.338.

children.definition: with rich soil, Sch.D Il. 18.541.
bright-girdled, θύγατρες B. 8.49; Ἀέλιος E. Ph. 175 (lyr.).
bright-throned, A. Eu. 806, Lyr.Adesp. 140.6, Aristonous 2.16.
with bright headband, Il. 18.382, h.Cer. 25, 459, etc.
lustrous-eyed, Licymn. 4, Arist. Phgn. 808a34.
with glossy locks, Il. 19.126, Pi. Fr. 88.1.
Hsch.

oily, shiny with oil, once in Hom., anointed, λιπαροὶ κεφαλὰς καὶ καλὰ πρόσωπα Od. 15.332; λ. χωρεῖν ἐκ βαλανείου Ar. Pl. 616; θεᾶσθαι λιπαρὸν παρὰ τῷ Διονύσῳ Id. Eq. 536, cf. Nu. 1002; σοὶ δὲ μελήσει . . λιπαρῷ (Bentl. for - ρῶς) χωρεῖν ἐπὶ δεῖπνον Id. Ec. 652; of oil or oily objects, shiny, Simon. 148.4, X. Mem. 2.1.31, Pl. Ti. 60a, 84a, Arist. HA 520a27.

fatty, greasy, ἄρτος Ar. Fr. 109; τὰ λ. unctuous dishes, ib. 506.1; τὸ λ. fatty substance, Arist. PA 651a24; λιπαραί (sc. ἔμπλαστροι), αἱ, oily plasters, Dsc. 1.112, Gal. 12.468: sts. opp. τὸ πῖον (which implies resinous substance), Arist. Mete. 387b6, cf. Col. 791b23; of vegetables boiled in grease, Hp. Mul. 1.66. Adv. - ρῶς, ἕψειν boil in grease, Hp. Mul. l.c.; so λ. ἠρτυμένον Gal. 9.677; ἀνατρίβειν massage with a greasy or oily lubricant, Hp. Art. 9.

children.label: II
children.definition: shining, sleek, in Hom. in phrase λιπαροὶ πόδες bright, smooth feet, without a wrinkle on the skin, mostly of menʼs feet, in the line ποσσὶ δʼ ὑπὸ λιπαροῖσιν ἐδήσατο καλὰ πέδιλα Il. 2.44, al.; of Hera, 14.186; of Themis, Hes. Th. 901; -ώτεροι ἐγένοντο Hdt. 3.23; λ. στῆθος Ar. Nu. 1012; θηρία X. Cyr. 1.4.11; χείλεα Luc. Am. 13; radiant, θυγάτηρ χρόνου B. 7.1; ἄκοιτις Id. 5.169.

data.quote: ποσσὶ δʼ ὑπὸ λιπαροῖσιν ἐδήσατο καλὰ πέδιλα

children.label: III
children.definition: rich, comfortable, easy, γῆρας Od. 11.136, 19.368, Pi. N. 7.99; λ. εὐφροσύνη AP 11.63 ( Maced.). Adv. -ρῶς, γηρασκέμεν Od. 4.210; πλήσαντα λ. κύκλον ἐτῶν ἑκατόν Epigr.Gr. 451.

children.label: IV
children.definition: bright, brilliant, λιπαρὴ καλύπτρη Il. 22.406; λ. κρήδεμνα Od. 1.334, etc.; χοροί Hes. Th. 63; of city walls, Od. 13.388; λ. δόμος B. 15.29; νίκα Id. 10.38; στέφανοι Id. 1.47; λιπαρὰς τελέουσι θέμιστας splendid or rich tribute, Il. 9.156, 298; also, of the oily smoothness of a calm sea, λ. γαλάνα Theoc. 22.19, cf. Call. Epigr. 6.5; also σέλας Theoc. 23.8; and of smells, λ. ὀσμή rich, savoury, Arist. de An. 421a30, cf. Sens. 443b10.

children.label: V
children.definition: fat, rich, fruitful, as epith. of places, Χίος, ἣ νήσων λιπαρωτάτη εἰν ἁλὶ κεῖται h.Ap. 38; λ. πόλις Thgn. 947; λ. Ὀρχομενός, Θῆβαι, Νάξος, Μαραθών, Pi. O. 14.2, P. 2.3, 4.88, O. 13.110; λιπαραὶ Ἀθῆναι, favourite epith. with the Athenians, prob. with allusion to the Attic olive, first in Pi. I. 2.20, Fr. 76, cf. Ar. Ach. 639, 640 (where he plays on the double sense of brilliant and greasy), Nu. 300, Fr. 110; λ. τὸ χρῆμα τῆς πόλεως, of Nephelococcygia, Id. Av. 826; λ. χεύματα, of rivers, A. Supp. 1028 (lyr.); λ. ὅρμος Call. Del. 155; ἄντρον Orph. H. 59.4 ( Hermann), etc.

data.quote: Χίος, ἣ νήσων λιπαρωτάτη εἰν ἁλὶ κεῖται

children.label: VI
children.definition: Adv. λῐπαρῶς, v. supr. I, ΙΙΙ.
fattiness, ὑπάρχει ἐν γάλακτι λ. Arist. HA 522a21, cf. PA 652a29: in pl., fatty substances, Hp. Prog. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: brilliancy, ὀμμάτων Plu. QConv. 2.670f.
richly fed, μῆλα Pi. Oxy. 1792 Fr. 1.6.
with shining body, sleek of skin, Σελαναία λιπαρόχροε Theoc. 2.165:— also λῐπᾰρό-χρως, ωτος, ὁ, ἡ, acc. - χρων, ib. 102.
bright-looking, τράπεζα Philox. 2.1.
Aret. in nom. λίπας, CD 2.3, SD 2.9; gen. λίπαος CA 1.1; dat. λίπαϊ ibid.
a greasy form of ulceration, Hp. Alim. 16, Heliod. ap. Orib. 46.22.14, Gal. 15.316.
a fattening substance, Plu. Amat. 2.771b, LXX Ne. 8.10 (pl.).
salve, Man. 4.345.
λίπασμα ὀφθαλμῶν a glistening, i.e. a tear, Epicur. ap. Cleom. 2.1 ( p.89 U.).
anointing, Dsc. Alex. 14, Paul.Aeg. 2.48.
deserted by light, dark, sunless, IG 12(5).891.5 ( Tenos), Orph. H. 18.2; blind, AP 9.13 ( Pl. Jun.).
to be calm, λιπαυρεῖ (impers.) Hsch.

to be sleek, radiant, Ep. pres. λιπόω, v.l. for ῥυπόω, Od. 19.72; part. λιπόων Call. Fr. 141, AP 6.324 ( Leon.), Nic. Al. 487, Q.S. 10.274: regul. forms, ind. 3 pl. pres. λιπῶσιν Ph. 1.542, part. λιπῶν Phryn.Com. 38, Call. Fr. 121, Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.206f.

children.label: II
children.definition: anoint, γυῖα Nic. Th. 81.
pinguis olivi, Serv. ad Verg. E. 5.68.
unemployed labourer (s.v.l.), v. λιπερνήτης.
to be poor, Suid. (who also has λιφερνῶν sine gloss.);

senses.definition: to be meagre, στάχυς J. AJ 2.5.5:—but Hsch. has λιφερνοῦντες· ἐν συνδένδρῳ τόπῳ προσφιλῶς διάγοντες.

children.definition: poor, forlorn, outcast, ὦ λιπερνῆτες πολῖται Archil. 50 (borrowed by Cratin. 198); context doubtful in BCH 11.161 ( Lagina); = pupillus, ὀρφανός, Gloss.:—also λῐπερν-ήτης, ου, ὁ, AP 9.649 ( Maced.), EM 566.50, restored by Schäfer in Longus 2.22 for λιπεργάτης:—fem. λῐπερν-ῆτις, ιδος, Call. Fr. 66e, Epic. Oxy. 1794.17.
forsaker of her husband, of Helen, Stesich. 26.5.

definition: λιπήμεροι οἱ ἐν τῷ προσήκοντι χρόνῳ μὴ γεννώμενοι, Hsch.

children.definition: land that lacks rain, coined as etym. of Λιβύη by Varro ap. Serv. ad Verg. A. 1.22.
lose or be without herbage, Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.182e.
Eust. 1752.01 [not found]; = lacticularius, lacticulosus, Gloss.
having abandoned her marriage ties, ἡ λ. the adulteress, of Helen, E. Or. 1305 (lyr.); cf. λιπεσάνωρ.
without eyeballs, sightless, Nonn. D. 37.517.
tongueless, Nonn. D. 26.281.
wanting a letter, Suid. s.v. Νέστωρ, Eust. 1379.55.
wanting a limb, maimed, lame, AP 9.13 ( Pl. Jun.).
with few wants, Pythag. Ep. 2.
to be without skin, Hippiatr. 26.
without a skin, of ulcers, Hippiatr. 26; without a foreskin, Sor. 1.103; circumcised, Dsc. 2.82, Crito ap. Gal. 12.449, Gal. 19.445, Paul.Aeg. 6.53.
fail in strength, Gal. 10.842.
lacking strength (cf. ἀδρανής), Aret. SD 2.6.
deprived of the breast, of late-born pigs ( μετάχοιρα), which the sows will not suckle, Gp. 19.6.8.
hairless, Ael. NA 17.4, Nonn. D. 11.510.
wanting voice, mute, of Echo, Nonn. D. 4.327.
fall into a swoon, faint, Hp. Art. 68, Mul. 2.134, Plu. Them. 10, Gal. 1.139.

definition: λιποθύμημα, ατος, τό, = sq., Tz. H. 12.391.

children.definition: swoon, Hp. Aph. 1.23, Art. 68, Plu. Pomp. 49, etc.
subject to fainting fits, Hp. Liqu. 2, Antyll. ap. Orib. 7.7.7.
swoon-like, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.1.26, Aët. 9.40.
leaving a sting, μέλισσαι Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 7.15.
losing flesh, i.e. wasted, thin, Suid.: acc. pl. λ(ε)ιποκρέους in Tz. H. 11.60; neut. pl. - κρεα Phlp. in GA 200.22.
without handle, φασγανίδες cj. Toup in AP 6.307 ( Phan.) for λιποκόπτους or λιποκόπρους.
against a witness for non-appearance, Poll. 8.36, cf. D. 49.19, Lys. Fr. 321 S.
having left oneʼs mother, AP 9.240 ( Phil.).

definition: λιπομορία δένδρον τὰ ἐκ τοῦ θωρακίου κατεαγός, ἐκ δὲ τῆς ῥίζης φέρον βλαστούς, Hsch.

children.definition: deserting the fleet, A. Ag. 212 (lyr.) (or, deserted by the allied fleet); v. λιπόνεως.
leaving the sailors, Theoc. 13.73, Anon. ap. Suid.
against one who deserts his ship or duty at sea, Poll. 8.42.
D. 50.65, Luc. Cat. 3, Max.Tyr. 9.7.

definition: λιπόνηρος λίαν πονηρός, Hsch.; cf. λῖ.

children.definition: lacking wood: metaph., defective, feeble, πίστις Emp. 71.1, cf. 21.2.
childless, found in neut. pl., λέχη λιπόπαιδα Man. 4.584.
leaving oneʼs country, Nonn. D. 1.131.

children.label: II
children.definition: causing to forget oneʼs country, λ. ἐδωδή, i.e. the lotus, AP 15.12 ( Leo Phil.).
deserter of oneʼs father, E. Or. 1305.
death, Tim. Pers. 106.
breathless, dead, AP 12.132 ( Mel.), APl. 16.110.5 ( Id.), 133.5 ( Philostr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: without wind, deadly still, Ἅιδης Orph. H. 18.9.
leaving the war, Nonn. D. 35.389.
leaving the city, Nonn. D. 9.78; λιπόπολις, Hsch. s.v. λιπερνής, Phot. s.v. λιπερνῆτις.
want of beard, Crates Com. 22.
without skin, of Marsyas, Nonn. D. 1.44.
λίπος) with greasy skin, Nic. Al. 537.

animal fat, lard, tallow, Arist. Long. 467a3, cf. Pr. 935b20: pl., χηνὸς λίπη AP 9.377.8 ( Pall.); βεβρῶτες αἵματος λ. gorged with fat and blood, S. Ant. 1022; but λ. αἵματος a fleck of blood, A. Ag. 1428 (lyr., λίβος Casaub.); of vegetable oil, λ. ἐλαίας S. Fr. 398, cf. Thphr. HP 3.18.3, 8.7.3, Call. Ap. 39. (Cf. λίπα, λιπαρός, λιπάω, λιπαίνω, Skt. lip- ‘anoint’, Lith. lipti ‘stick’.)
lose flesh, opp. ἁδρύνομαι, Thphr. HP 8.11.4 (dub. cj.), Hippiatr. 26.
AP 11.374 ( Maced.), Man. 1.55, cj. for λειπόσαρκες in Opp. C. 2.106.
want of flesh, Sch. Hes. Sc. 268.
lean, thin, Hp. Ep. 17, v.l. in Opp. C. 2.106 (cf. sq. [λιπόσαρξ]); σκῆνος λ., of the skeleton, IG 14.2131 [ῐ]; of wounds, leaving a hollow, Hippiatr. 77.

definition: λιπόσαρξ, σαρκος, ὁ, ἡ, = foreg., prob. in Opp. C. 2.106.

children.definition: powerless, Nonn. D. 14.101.
to be in want of corn or bread, Suid.
casting no shadow, δένδρεα Nonn. D. 2.93.
unshadowed, αὐχήν ib. 10.186.
falling from the wreath, φύλλα AP 6.71 ( Paul.Sil.).
desert, refuse to serve in arms, Sch. Ar. Eq. 226.
desertion from the army, refusal to serve, Hdt. 5.27, Th. 6.76, D.H. 11.22:—also λῐποστρᾰτ-ιον, τό, Th. 1.99, Ph. 2.132.
deserter, dub. l. in App. Pun. 115.
desert oneʼs post, LXX 4 Ma. 9.23, Ascl. Tact. 3.6, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.241a; λ. τῆς τοῦ θεοῦ τάξεως Ph. 1.268.
deserter, D.H. 8.79, Ph. 1.144, J. BJ 5.3.4, (Max.Tyr. 9.7: metaph., λ. Μουσῶν Jul. Ep. 183.
desertion, D. 21.166 codd. (- ιον Cobet): metaph., διάλυσις τῶν ἐν τῷ ζῴῳ πάντων καὶ λ. συμβαίνει (after death) Anatolius ap. Theol.Ar. 35.

desertion, λ. διαπεπραγμένοι Ph. 2.132:—elsewh. in gen. λιποταξίου γραφή, indictment for desertion, Pl. Lg. 943d, D. 21.103; ἔνοχος λιποταξίου Lys. 14.5; τὰ δʼ ἐγχέλεια γράψομαι λιποταξίου, Com. phrase, Antiph. 129.9, cf. Pl.Com. 7, Ar. Fr. 808, v. Poll. 8.42.
childless, οἶκος Pi. Parth. 1.16.
to be in arrears with taxes, IG 9(1).334.14 ( Oeanthea, v B.C.).
fatness, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.225.4.
become relaxed, Nicom. Harm. 4 ( λειπ-, interpol.).
grow bald, Gal. 14.530.
AP 9.52 ( Carph.); λῐπό-τρῐχος, ον, Nonn. D. 26.159.
badly healed, Heras ap. Gal. 13.815:—hence λῐπουργ-ία, ἡ, Asclep. ib. 525, Heras ib. 546.
without tail, Call. Fr. 28.2 P.
Man. 1.65, Musae. 238.
swoon, S. Fr. 496, Th. 4.12, X. HG 5.4.58, Xenarch. 7.12, Arist. Somn.Vig. 456b15, D.S. 12.62, Plu. Glor.Ath. 2.347b, Arr. An. 6.11.2.
swooning, v.l. in Hdt. 1.86, Hp. Aph. 7.8, Arist. Somn.Vig. 455b5, Plu. QConv. 2.695a, Arr. An. 6.10.2.
like λιποψυχία, faint, Hp. Acut. 42.

to be eager, οὔτε μεῖον οὔτʼ ἴσον λελιμμένοι A. Th. 355 (lyr.): c. gen., to be eager for, long for, μάχης λελιμμένος ib. 380:—later in Act. λίπτω, A.R. 4.813, Lyc. 131, Nic. Th. 126. (Cf. λίψ· ἐπιθυμία, Hsch., ἔλιπεν, = ἐπιθυμητικῶς ἤσθιεν, Id., λιψουρία, and perh. Lith. liẽpti ‘command’.)

a malignant intermittent fever, Hp. Judic. 11:—also λιπύριον, τό, Id. Morb. 2.51:—hence λῐπῠρ-ίας, ου, ὁ, one who suffers from λιπυρία, Gal. 17(2).728, cf. 18(2).121, Ps.- Gal. 19.399:— Adj. λειπῠρικός (leg. λῐπῠρικός), ή, όν, like λιπυρία, Hp. Coac. 117; λῐπῠριώδης, ες, of the nature of λιπυρία, πυρετός Id. Ep. 21.
fatty, oily, Thphr. HP 3.12.1 ( Comp.).
to be bold or shameless, = ἀναιδεύομαι, Hsch.

definition: λίρινος, λιριόεις, λίριον, less correct forms of λειρ-.

children.definition: bold, shameless, lewd, Call. Fr. 229, Alex.Aet. 3.30.
lewd-eyed, Suid.

lion, mostly in nom., ἐφάνη λὶς ἠυγένειος Il. 15.275, cf. 11.239, 18.318, Hes. Sc. 172: acc., ἐπί τε λῖν ἤγαγε δαίμων Il. 11.480, cf. Theoc. 13.6: nom. pl. λίες [ῐ] Euph. 35, but λῖες Antim. 89: dat. pl. λίεσσι [ῐ] ibid. [ λίς but λῖν, Aristarch. ap. Hdn.Gr. 2.73, cf. 77.]
smooth, λὶς πέτρη Od. 12.64, 79.
spade, mattock, Sch. Theoc. 4.10, Suid. s.v. σκαφείδιον. (Mod.Gr. λισγάρι, a kind of rake or harrow.)
λίσκος· δίσκος, Hsch. λίσπη, ἡ, v. λίσπος.
smooth-buttocked, epith. of κίναιδοι, Phryn. PS p.86 B., Poll. 2.184; cf. Suid. s.v. λίσποι:—also λισπόπυξ, Eust. 1288.46: acc. pl. λισπόπυγας Sch. Ar. Eq. 1365.
smooth, polished, λίσπη γλῶσσα Ar. Ra. 826 codd.; cf. λίσφος.
Poll. 2.184; from λίσπος, = θηρίδιον λεπτὸν σφόδρα, acc. to Callistr. ap. Sch. Ar. Ra. 848.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. λίσπαι, αἱ, dice cut in two by friends ( ξένοι), each of whom kept half as a tally, Pl. Smp. 193a:—so λίσποι, οἱ, Suid.

definition: λισσάνιος [ ᾱ], ον, Lacon. for ἀγαθός ( Hsch., Phot.), ὦ λισσάνιε

children.definition: my good friend, Ar. Lys. 1171 ( λυσσάνιε cod. R).

definition: λισσάς, άδος, Boeot. λιττάς Corinn. Supp. 1.30,

children.definition: λισσός, λισσὰς αἰγίλιψ πέτρα A. Supp. 794 (lyr.), cf. E. Andr. 533 (lyr.), HF 1148, Theoc. 22.37, Lyr. ap. Plu. Util. 2.90d: Subst. λισσάς (sc. πέτρα), bare, smooth cliff, Plu. Mar. 23, Crass. 9, Opp. H. 2.320; of a tomb-stone, Epigr.Gr. 256.

definition: λίσσομαι, Hom., Lyr., Trag.; Ep. Iterat. λισσέσκετο Il. 9.451: aor. 1 ἐλῐσάμην, Ep. ἐλλ. Od. 11.35; imper. λίσαι Il. 1.394; subj. 2 sg. λίσῃ Od. 10.526: aor. 2 inf. λῐτέσθαι Il. 16.47; opt. λῐτοίμην Od. 14.406. (For pres. λίτομαι, v. sub voce):—

children.definition: beg, pray, either abs. or c. acc. pers., λισσομένη προσέειπε Δία Il. 1.502; εὐχωλῇσι λιτῇσί τε ἔθνεα νεκρῶν ἐλλισάμην Od. 11.35, etc.; the thing by which one prays is found with ὑπέρ, λ. ὑπὲρ τοκέων, ὑπὲρ ψυχῆς καὶ γούνων, Il. 15.660, 22.338; λ. τινὰ ὑπὲρ πατρὸς καὶ μητέρος 24.467: or simply in gen., λ. Ζηνὸς ἠδὲ Θέμιστος Od. 2.68; λ. τινὰ γούνων Il. 9.451, Od. 22.337 (for which in Il. 6.45 we have λαβὼν ἐλλίσσετο γούνων, cf. Od. 6.142; τῆ ἑτέρῃ μὲν ἑλὼν ἐλλίσσετο γούνων Il. 21.71; ἥπτετο χείρεσι γούνων ἱέμενος λίσσεσθʼ 20.469); also in Trag., πρὸ . . τέκνων σε λ. E. Tr. 1045 (v. infr.): an inf. is freq. added, as οὐδέ σʼ ἔγωγε λίσσομαι εἵνεκʼ ἐμεῖο μένειν I do not pray thee to remain, Il. 1.174, cf. 283, B. 10.69, Pi. P. 4.207; πρός νυν θεῶν σε λ. ἐμοὶ πιθέσθαι S. El. 428; καὶ μὴ προδοῦναι λ. prays her not to abandon him, E. Alc. 202: more rarely with an acc. and inf. added, λίσσονται Δία . . Ἄτην ἅμʼ ἕπεσθαι they pray Zeus that Ate may follow, Il. 9.511, cf. Od. 8.30: sts. folld. by ὅπως, λίσσεσθαί μιν, ὅπως νημερτέα εἴπῃ entreat him to say the truth, 3.19; or by ἵνα, ib. 327: in Trag. parenth., μὴ πρόλειπε, λ., πάτερ A. Supp. 748; μή, λίσσομαί σʼ, αὔδα τάδε S. Aj. 368, cf. OT 650 (lyr.), Ar. Pax 382.

data.quote: εὐχωλῇσι λιτῇσί τε ἔθνεα νεκρῶν ἐλλισάμην
λ. τινὰ ὑπὲρ πατρὸς καὶ μητέρος
τῆ ἑτέρῃ μὲν ἑλὼν ἐλλίσσετο γούνων
πρός νυν θεῶν σε λ. ἐμοὶ πιθέσθαι

children.definition: beg or pray for, οἷ αὐτῷ θάνατον καὶ κῆρα λιτέσθαι Il. 16.47: c. dupl. acc. pers. et rei, ταῦτα μὲν οὐχ ὑμέας ἔτι λίσσομαι this I beg of you no more, Od. 2.210, cf. 4.347.

data.quote: οἷ αὐτῷ θάνατον καὶ κῆρα λιτέσθαι

children.definition: Hom. freq. c. dat. modi, ἐπέεσσι Il. 21.98, al.; εὐχῇσι Od. 10.526; εὐχωλῆσι λιτῆσί τε ἐλλισάμην 11.35.—Rare in Prose, as Hdt. 1.24, LXX Jb. 17.2, Luc. Syr.D. 18; in Pl. R. 366a there is a ref. to Il. 9.501. [The λ- freq. makes position in Ep., Il. 1.394, al.; written λλ after the augm., v. supr.]

smooth, Hom. (only in Od.), λισσὴ αἰπεῖάτε εἰς ἅλα πέτρη a smooth rock running sheer into the sea, 3.293; λισσὴ δʼ ἀναδέδρομε πέτρη 5.412, cf. 10.4; λ. νῆσος A.R. 2.382; λ. δειράδες AP 15.25.11 ( Besant.).
poor ( = δεόμενος, Hsch.): hence, insolvent, SIG 527.115 ( Dreros, iii B. C.).
render insolvent, [λις]σωθέντων dub. in SIG 524.43 ( Crete, iii B. C.); cf. foreg. [λισσός] 2.
smoothness, λ. τριχῶν the crown or spot on the head from which the hair sets in different ways, Arist. HA 491b6.
setting of the hair from the crown of the head, Arist. HA 491b8.
to be moved by prayer, Il. 9.497 (as quoted in Pl. R. 364d): elsewh. only in compds. ἄλλιστος, τρίλλιστος.
dig round, Suid.
= foreg., φυτόν Od. 24.227.

definition: λιστρῆρες οἱ λιστρεύοντες, καὶ οἱ πρὸς ταῖς ὑποκαιομέναις χύτραις ἱστάμενοι σπινθῆρες, Hsch.

children.definition: Ar. Fr. 809 (restd.fr. Phryn. PS p.88 B.), Hsch.; cf. λείστριον.
tool for levelling or smoothing, spade, shovel, Od. 22.455, Lyc. 1348, Mosch. 4.101:—later also λίστρ-ος, ὁ, Sch. Nic. Th. 29, EM 587.43.
levelled, ἅλω δρόμος Nic. Th. 29.

definition: λίσφος, η, ον, Att. for ἄπυγος, Moer. p.245P.; said to be Att. for λίσπος (q. v.), Tz.ad Hes. Op. 156.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. λίσφοι, οἱ, = ἴσχια, EM 567.20.
i.e. plants which were ploughed into the ground, to serve for manure, as lupines in Italy, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: λίσχρος· φειδωλός, Suid. Adv. -ρῶς Hsch.

definition: λῖτα, λῑτί, case forms of a noun of which no nom. sg. is found (unless σινδὼν λίς is right in Michel 832.19 ( Samos, iv B. C.)),

children.definition: linen cloth, ἑανῷ λιτὶ κάλυψαν they covered [the corpse] with a fine linen cloth, Il. 18.352, 23.254; λῖτα may be acc. sg. or acc. pl., αὐτὴν δʼ ἐς θρόνον εἷσεν ἄγων, ὑπὸ λῖτα πετάσσας, καλὸν δαιδάλεον Od. 1.130; ἔβαλλε θρόνοις ἔνι ῥήγεα καλά, πορφύρεα καθύπερθʼ, ὑπένερθε δὲ λῖθʼ ὑπέβαλλεν 10.353: understood as pl. by Ath. 2.48c; used for covering a chariot, Il. 8.441: in AP 6.332 ( Hadr.) λίτα [ῐ] πολυδαίδαλα is prob. f.l. (Perh. akin to λίνον.)

data.quote: αὐτὴν δʼ ἐς θρόνον εἷσεν ἄγων, ὑπὸ λῖτα πετάσσας, καλὸν δαιδάλεον
ἔβαλλε θρόνοις ἔνι ῥήγεα καλά, πορφύρεα καθύπερθʼ, ὑπένερθε δὲ λῖθʼ ὑπέβαλλεν

children.definition: IG 14.2525, Arch.Anz. 19.8 ( Milet.), Opp. C. 2.373, Orph. Fr. 333 (perh. Act.), Inscr.Perg. 324 (hymn to Zeus).
hearing prayer, epith. of Zeus, BCH 2.509 (coin of Nicaea); also in form λιδαῖος ib. 24.389 (inscr. of Bithynia).
entreaty, LXX 2 Ma. 3.20, 10.16, PTeb. 284.9 (i B. C.), Corn. ND 12: pl., D.H. 4.67; -εῖαι πρὸς τοὺς θεούς Jul. Ep. 114, cf. Iamb. Myst. 1.15.
of or for praying, Sch. A. Supp. 809.
begged, entreated, Hsch. s.v. ἀμφιλίτην.

definition: λιτανεύω, in Hom. with λλ in augm. tenses, ἐλλιτάνευε, ἐλλιτάνευσα: ( λιτανός): —

children.definition: pray, entreat, πάντας δʼ ἐλλιτάνευε (v.l. δὲ λ.) Il. 15.422:— Constr. same as λίσσομαι, either abs., Od. 7.145: or c. acc. pers., Il. l.c., 9.581, etc.; that by which one prays in gen., γούνων ἐλλιτάνευσα Od. 10.481; for which in Il. 24.357 we have ἀλλʼ ἄγε, γούνων ἁψάμενοι λιτανεύσομεν ( Ep. for - ωμεν); also c. inf., 23.196: c. acc. pers. et inf., Hes. Th. 469, Pi. N. 8.8, etc.: c. Adj. neut., πολλὰ λ. τινά ib. 5.32: rare in Att. Poets, Men. 49 (dub. l.), and in Prose, X. HG 2.4.26, Pl. R. 388b, LXX Ps. 44(45).12; λ. τὸ θεῖον Str. 15.1.60; τοὺς θεοὺς εὐχαῖς D.H. 4.76.
praying, suppliant, μέλη A. Supp. 809 (lyr.): as Subst. λιτανά, τά, = λιταί, ἀμφὶ λιτάνʼ ἕξομεν engage in prayer, Id. Th. 102 (Seidler for ἀμφίλιταν or ἀμφὶ λιτὰν).
slip away, Ar. Pax 562; cf. ἀπολιτ-.
running quick, An.Ox. 2.236, EM 567.38, prob. in Semon. 7.12 ( λιτοργόν codd. Stob.).

prayer, entreaty, mostly in pl., λιτῇσι ἐλλισάμην Od. 11.34; καταβαίνειν ἐς λιτάς Hdt. 1.116; λιταῖς ἀποτρέπει [αὐτὸν] μὴ πορεύεσθαι ib. 105; λιταῖς πεῖσαί τινα Pi. O. 2.80, cf. 8.8; μαλθάσσειν κέαρ λιταῖς A. Pr. 1008; ηὔχετο λιταῖσι Id. Pers. 499; λιτᾶν ἀκούειν Id. Ag. 396 (lyr.); λιτὰς κλύειν Id. Th. 172 (lyr.), cf. E. Or. 1233, etc.; λιταῖς σεβίζειν S. OC 1557 (lyr.); ἐπεύχεσθαι λιτάς ib. 484; λ. δέχεσθαι Id. Ant. 1019; ἐν λιταῖς στέλλειν with prayers, Id. Ph. 60; λιταὶ θεῶν prayers to the gods, E. Supp. 262; but λιταὶ ἐμαυτοῦ ξυμμάχων τε prayers for myself, S. OC 1309: also c. gen. of that by which one prays, γενείου τοῦδʼ . . ἐκτεῖναι λιτάς E. Or. 290. (Poet., Ion. and late Prose, BGU 74.15 (ii A. D.).)

children.label: II
children.definition: Λιταί, αἱ, personified, Prayers of sorrow and repentance, Il. 9.502 sq., AP 11.361 ( Autom.).

definition: λιτῆρα θαλλόν (= Trag.Adesp. 234) · τὸν ἱκέσιον, Hsch.

children.definition: living plainly or sparingly, Str. 15.1.34.
of a plain way of life, D.H. 2.49.

simple, inexpensive, frugal, λιταὶ τράπεζαι Ps.-Phoc. 81; οἱ λ. χυλοί Epicur. Ep. 3p.63U.; λ. βίος Men. 633, Crates Theb. 10; τροφὴ λιτοτάτη Ath. 5.191f; λιτὴ δίαιτα Plu. QConv. 2.668f, cf. Sanit. 125d, etc.; τὸ λ. τῆς διαίτης, κατὰ τὴν δίαιταν, Epicur. Fr. 478, M.Ant. 1.3; παρέξοδος (q.v.) - οτέρη Hp. Decent. 8; λ. χλαμύδιον Men. 442; τὰ ἱμάτια λ. καὶ σώφρονα Jul. Caes. 317c; μίτρη λιτὴ στυππείου Michel 832.17 ( Samos, iv B. C.); ὑποκεφάλαια δύο ἡμιτυβίου λιτά ib.l.23; [ἀσπίδας] χαλκᾶς λιτὰς δύο, opp. περίχρυσος μία, IG 2(2).1491.31 (iv B. C.); ἅλα λιτὸν ἐπέσθων frugal salt, Call. Epigr. 48; λ. ὀξίς Nicostr.Com. 9 (cj. for λοιπή) ; λ. ὕδωρ πίνων D.L. 8.13; λ. χρίματα simple or plain unguents, Call. Lav.Pall. 25; λ. ταφή Phld. Mort. 30; λ. ζωμός thin (chicken-) broth, Gal. 12.295; of medicines, ἡ διὰ κωδυῶν λιτή (sc. δύναμις) Crito ap. Gal. 13.38; ἡ διὰ μόρων λιτή Archig. ap. eund. 12.973; λ. ἔμπλαστροι Androm. ap. eund. 13.495, cf. 486; χάρτης λιτός, as a cargo, perh. cheap or coarse papyrus, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.104.28.

poor, λ. γενόμενος τοῖς ἔχουσι μὴ φθόνει dub. in Dionys.Com. 10 ( = Dionys.Trag. 8); frugal, αὐτάρκεις καὶ λ. Plb. 6.48.7; κατὰ τὴν ἐσθῆτα καὶ σίτησιν ἀφελὴς καὶ λ. Id. 11.10.3; λ. περὶ δίαιταν Plu. QConv. 2.709b. Adv. - τῶς frugally, Sotad.Com. 1.6, AP 7.156 ( Isid.); λ. βιοῦν D.L. 6.105; λ. καὶ σωφρόνως ζῆν Ephor. 149 J.; λαμπρῶς ἢ λ. ἐξενεχθέντας Phld. l.c.

data.quote: κατὰ τὴν ἐσθῆτα καὶ σίτησιν ἀφελὴς καὶ λ.

children.label: II
children.definition: plain, simple, unadorned, Arist. Rh. 1416b25, D.H. Th. 23, al.

children.label: III
children.definition: paltry, petty, small, τάφος AP 7.73 (Gemin.), cf. 7.18 ( Antip.Thess.); of persons, opp. μέγας, Call. Ap. 10; πολισμάτια Plb. 32.8.3. Adv. - τῶς slightly, ἡψημένα Artem. 1.70; λ. ἑφθά Diocl. Fr. 141; dub. sens. in Alc. Oxy. 1788 Fr. 2.11. [ῑ, but ῐ late, λῐτὰ δεῖπνα Nonn. D. 17.59.]

definition: λιτός (A), ή, όν, epith. of γαῖα, dub. sens. in Alex.Aet. 1, Orph. A. 92; λιτὴ χθών· ἀπὸ τοῦ προσκυνεῖσθαι καὶ λιτανεύεσθαι, Hsch.

children.definition: suppliant, supplicatory, θυσίαι Pi. O. 6.78; ἐπαοιδαί Id. P. 4.217.
plainness, simplicity, κόσμου Democr. 274; τῶν στεφάνων Thphr. Fr. 142; τὴν λ. διώκουσι D.S. 2.59; λ. διαίτης Cic. Fam. 7.26.2; cj. for λεπτότης in Epicur. Sent.Vat. 63.

children.label: II
children.definition: assertion by means of understatement (cf. μείωσις) or negation, Serv. ad Verg. G. 2.125, Donat. ad Ter. Hec. 775.
Did. ap. Ammon. Diff. p.88 V.
a silver coin of Sicily, Epich. 9, Sophr. 72, Diph. 71, Posidipp. 8.—On its value v. Arist. Fr. 476, 510.

children.label: II
children.definition: 12 ounces, a pound, [ Simon.] 141, Plb. 21.43.19, D.S. 14.116, Dsc. 1.43, Plu. TG 2, J. AJ 14.7.1: metaph., λίτρᾰν ἐτῶν ζήσας having lived a pound of years, i.e. 72 (in late times a pound of gold was coined into 72 pieces), AP 10.97 ( Pall.).

children.label: III
children.definition: = 1 Italic κοτύλη, Gal. 6.287. [ ῑ as in Lat. libra; written λείτρα in CIG 2040.7 (Bosp.).] (Both λίτρα and Lat. libra prob. from early Italic *līprā.)
weighing or worth a λίτρα, χείλη AP 11.204 ( Pall.), cf. Gal. 13.415.

children.label: II
children.definition: λ. κέρας a drinking-cup holding 1 λίτρα, ib. 435.
libratio, Gloss.
weigh or deliver by weight, POxy. 1543.1 (iii A. D.).

definition: λιτρίς πυξὶς σαματοδόχος, Hsch. (perh. πυξὶς σμηματοδόχος ‘soap-box’, λιτρίς being from λίτρον I).

children.definition: delivery by weight, PFlor. 31.21 (iv A. D.).
box for holding λίτραι, Phot. s.v. λίτρα.
an apple weighing a λίτρα, Tz. H. 9.347.

definition: λίτρον [ῐ by nature], τό, older form for νίτρον, Hp. Epid. 2.6.9 and 29, Hdt. 2.86, 87, Ar. Fr. 320.1, Pl. Ti. 60d, 65d (pl.), Thphr. HP 3.7.6, Alex. 1, dub. l. in Pl.Com. 69.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: PFay. 331 (ii A. D.).
seller of λίτρον, IG 2(2).1673.22 (iv B. C.).
one who examines money, money-changer, S. Fr. 1065.
Pl. Ti. 65e, Thphr. Fr. 159, Gal. 6.559: Comp. - εστέρα Ath. 2.43b.

definition: Λιτυέρσης, ου, Dor. -έρσας, ὁ, Lityerses, a bastard son of Midas, who used to challenge wayfarers to a reaping match, and bound the heads of the conquered in his sheaves, Ath. 10.415b, Suid.

children.definition: a reaperʼs song named after him, Men. 264, Theoc. 10.41, Ath. 14.619a.
= Lat. lituus, Plu. Rom. 22.
lack blood, Arist. Pr. 877a30, Gal. 12.693; bleed to death, J. AJ 8.15.5, App. Gall. 10, Hsch.
bloodlessness, Ph. 2.512.
lacking blood, Emp. 100.1; pallid, Hp. Mul. 2.119, 125.

children.label: II
children.definition: aor. inf. λιχάξαι· ῥῖψαι, βάλαι (Cret.), Id.
locus of the λίχανος II, Aristox. Harm. p.26 M.; ὁ λ. φθόγγος the highest note of a πυκνόν, Bacch. Harm. 43, cf. Aristid.Quint. 1.6.
licking: ὁ λ., with or without δάκτυλος, forefinger, from its use in licking up, Hp. Art. 37, al., Luc. Tim. 54, Ath. 1.15d, PLips. 12.9 (iii A. D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. λίχᾰνος (sc. χορδή), ἡ, the string struck with the forefinger, and its note, Aristox. Harm. p.116 M., Arist. Pr. 919a17, D.S. 3.59, Plu. An.procr. 2.1029a, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adj., λ. σωλήν a tube of the alembic, Zos.Alch. p.225, 236B.
the space between the forefinger ( λιχανός) and thumb, the lesser span, Hero *Geom. 4, Poll. 2.158.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: λιχάδες· ὄστρεα πάντα, οἱ δὲ λίθοι καὶ ψῆφοι καὶ κογχύλια, Id.
Hes. Sc. 235; γλώσσῃ λ. Nic. Th. 229.

children.label: II
children.definition: lick, Opp. H. 2.250, Nonn. D. 44.111; Ion. impf., λιχμάζεσκε δέρην Mosch. 2.94.

definition: λιχμάς θρῖναξ, καὶ ἁπαλὴ πόα καὶ χαμαιπετής, ἣν τὰ ἑρπετὰ ἐπιλείχουσι, Hsch.
λιχμάω, fut. Med. - ήσομαι ( ἀνα-) J. AJ 8.15.4: aor. ἐλιχμησάμην ap. D.L. 8.91:—

children.definition: play with the tongue, of snakes, in Ep. part., αἰνὸν λιχμώωντες Q.S. 5.40: in irreg. pf. part., γλώσσῃσι λελιχμότες Hes. Th. 826:— Med., ἑκατὸν . . κεφαλαὶ κολάκων . . ἐλιχμῶντο περὶ τὴν κεφαλήν played like serpents round . . , Ar. V. 1033, Pax 756 ( ἐλιχνῶντο v.l. in Sch., Hsch.), cf. Theoc. 24.20, Euph. 51.6.
lick, ὄφεσι . . λιχμῶσιν γένυν E. Ba. 698:— Med., D.L. l.c., App. Hisp. 96, Mith. 38.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., also, lick up, λιχμώμενος ἔρσην Nic. Al. 569; used by Hom. only in the compd. ἀπολιχμάομαι.
licking, of mice, Nic. Al. 37.
playing with the tongue, of snakes, Nic. Th. 206.
gluttony, luxuriousness in eating, X. Lac. 5.4, Luc. Tim. 55: pl., X. Oec. 1.22, Pl. R. 519b; περὶ τὰ φαῦλα Ath. 5.220c.
dainties, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.225f: so in sg. in collective sense, Nic.Dam. 56 J.
a dainty, delicacy, Sophr. 24.
gormandize, περὶ τὰς πέτρας Luc. Pisc. 48, cf. Arr. Epict. 2.4.8, Plu. QConv. 2.713c.

children.label: II
children.definition: desire greedily, covet, τὰ δημόσια D.H. 8.73; δόξαν Plu. Comp.Dem.Cic. 2:— Med., desire eagerly to do, c. inf., Id. Glor.Ath. 2.347a; to be greedy, λ. εἰς ὅρασιν Lib. Descr. 30.3: c. gen., σαρκὸς ἀνθρωπείου λ. Sch. Il. Oxy. 221 ix 35:— Pass., to be lusted after, Nic.Dam. 1 J. codd. (dub.).
eating tit-bits, μῦς AP 9.86 ( Antiphil.).
greedy old woman, Timo 38.1.

definition: λίχνος, η, ον, also ος, ον E. Hipp. 913,

children.definition: gluttonous, X. Mem. 1.2.2, Pl. R. 354b, Plb. 3.57.7, Gal. 6.716; τὰ περὶ τὴν τροφὴν λίχνοι Clitarch. 1 J.: c. gen., τῶν ἐν διαίτῃ ποικιλμάτων Epicur. Sent.Vat. 69: metaph., λ. τὴν ψυχήν Pl. R. 579b: Comp. - ότερος Sophr. 62: Sup. - ότατος Arist. HA 594a6.

curious, inquisitive, E. l.c.; ὄμματα λ. Call. Fr. 107, AP 12.106 ( Mel.); lewd, Crates Theb. 4: c. gen., curious after, τοῦ κεκρυμμένου E. Fr. 1063.8; c. inf., λ. εἰμὶ καὶ τὸ πεύθεσθαι Call. Fr. 98d.

children.label: II
children.definition: luxurious, appetizing, ὄψα, ἐδέσματα, Gal. Anim.Pass. 6.
greedy glutton, Poll. 6.122.
both epicure and miser, Philyll. 17 (s. v.l.).
Ael. Fr. 325 ( Sup.).
the SW. wind, Hdt. 2.25, Arist. Mete. 364b2 (pl.), Mu. 394b27, Theoc. 9.11: pl., Plb. 10.10.3.
the South, freq. in LXX, Ge. 13.14, al.

the West, opp. ἀπηλιώτης, PTeb. 14.19 (ii B. C.), Vett.Val. 8.5, Paul.Al. A. 2, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.21.9, 1.49.45; rarely in LXX, 2 Ch. 32.30, 33.14, Thd. Da. 8.5; λιβός or λίβα εἰς ἀπηλιώτην from West to East, BGU 1037.15 (i A. D.), CPR 28.21 (ii A.D.).
πρωινὸς λ., μεσημβρινὸς λ., ὀψινὸς λ., position of a star on the W. horizon at sunrise, midday, or sunset, Ptol. Alm. 8.4.

definition: λίψ (B), ἡ, ( λείβω) only gen. and acc. ( λιβάς or λίβος being the nom. in use),

children.definition: stream, ἐξ ὀμμάτων λείβουσι . . λίβα (Burges for δία) A. Eu. 54; ἀφθονέστερον λίβα f.l. in A. Fr. 72; μέλιτος λίβα A.R. 4.1454.
libation, φιλοσπόνδου λιβός A. Ch. 292; εὐκταίαν λίβα Id. Fr. 55.

definition: λίψ (C) · ἐπιθυμία (cf. λίπτομαι) , πέτρα ἀφʼ ἧς ὕδωρ στάζει, Hsch.

children.definition: desire to make water, A. Ch. 756.

definition: λιώδης λιθόλευστος, Hsch. (Perh. λιώλης, cf. λεώλης.)
λιωργός κακοῦργος, Hsch. λόβαι· χεῖρες, Hsch.
λόβιον, τό, Dim. of sq. [λοβός] I.1, Gal. 14.701; of sq. 1.2, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: fruit of the σμῖλαξ, Dsc. 2.146.
lobe of the ear, ἐΰτρητοι (for wearing ear-rings) λ. Il. 14.182, cf. h.Hom. 6.8, Hp. Prog. 2, Arist. HA 492a16; ἄκροι λ. Lyc. 1401.
lobe of the liver, to which special attention was paid in divination, A. Pr. 495, E. El. 827, Pl. Ti. 71c, Euphro 7: generally, liver, A. Eu. 159 (lyr.).
lobe of the lung, Gal. UP 6.4, al.; of the whole lung, Hp. Loc.Hom. 14.

children.label: II
children.definition: capsule or pod of leguminous plants (cf. ἔλλοβος), Thphr. HP 1.11.2, etc.; esp. of φασίολοι or δόλιχοι, because they were eaten pod and all, Gal. 6.557, Jul. Or. 5.175c.
the white part, elsewh. ὄνυξ, Gal. 12.748.
picked, of troops, Plu. Oth. 6.
εἰργάζοντο λ. φέροντες λίθους καὶ ξυνετίθεσαν ὡς ἕκαστόν τι ξυμβαίνοι bringing the stones as they picked them out, Th. 4.4, cf. 31, 6.66, D.H. Comp. 22.
chosen, picked, Str. 1.3.18 (paraphrasing Ibyc. 22).

logaoedic, of verses in which dactylic and trochaic rhythms are combined, so that they stand between λόγος and ἀοιδή, between prose and poetry, D.L. 4.65, Heph. 7, Aristid.Quint. 1.23, POxy. 220 xii 2.
calculate, Eust. ad D.P. 907, Sch. Ar. Pl. 381:—hence λογᾰρ-ιασμός, ὁ, calculation, Sch. Luc. Cat. 4.

definition: λογαρίδιον, τό, = sq., POxy. 599 (i/ii A. D.).
λογάριον, τό, Dim. of λόγος, Ar. Fr. 810 (pl.); λ. δύστηνα wretched

children.definition: petty speeches, D. 19.255; τὰ ἐκ στοᾶς λ. Theognet. 1.2; λογάρια δειπνεῖν dine off mere words, Ath. 6.270d.

children.label: II
children.definition: account, PTeb. 20.8 (ii B. C.), etc.

picked, chosen, mostly in pl. of picked men, λ. νεηνίαι Hdt. 1.36, 43, E. Hec. 544, etc.; τριηκόσιοι Σπαρτιητέων λ. Hdt. 8.124; λ. Περσέων τοὺς ἀρίστους χιλίους Id. 9.63; Ἀργείων οἱ χίλιοι λ. Th. 5.67; στρατηγῶν λογάδες E. Andr. 324; of cattle, PStrassb. 24.32 (ii A. D.); φωναὶ λογάδες chosen phrases, Phot. Bibl. p.491 B.: with collect.Nouns, στρατιὴ λ. ἡμιθέων AP 15.51 ( Arch.).
λ. λίθοι unhewn stones, taken just as they were picked, Paus. 7.22.5; cf. λογάδην, λέγω B. I, λιθολόγος.

definition: λογάς (B), usu. in pl., λογάδες, αἱ,

children.definition: whites of the eyes, Sophr. 49, Call. Fr. 132, Nic. Th. 292 (sg., Poll. 2.70): generally, eyes, AP 5.269 ( Paul.Sil.).
to be fond of talking, Luc. Lex. 15.

children.label: II
children.definition: λογάω or λογέω, fut. 3 sg. λογήσει, perh. will take account, Tyrt. Fr. 1.42 Diehl.
A. Fr. 112, Ar. Fr. 811, cf. Phryn. PS p.87 B.
stones with holes in them, through which mooringcables were passed, Hsch., Phot. s.v. λογγάζειν:—sg. λογγᾰσίη, Hsch.:—also λογγῶνες, οἱ, Syracusan acc. to EM 569.42, cf. Suid.

collection of taxes or voluntary contributions, PHib. 1.51.2 (iii B.C.), PTeb. 58.55 (ii B. C.), POxy. 239.8 (i A. D.); collection for charity, 1 Ep.Cor. 16.1, Hsch.; for religious purposes, GDI 4156 ( Lindos), PSI 2.262.3 (i A. D.); perquisite, PPar. 5xxvii 6 (ii B. C.).
speaking-place: in the theatre, stage, IG 11(2).161 D 126 ( Delos, iii B. C.), Vitr. 5.7.2, Plu. Thes. 16, etc.: generally, platform, Arch.Pap. 2.564 (pl.), unless λογείων = λογίων.
Poll. 2.98.
phrase-monger, Artem. 2.70: a pecul. accent λογεμπόρος is mentioned by Eust. 463.40, 1447.47.
taxes collected, PRev.Laws 56.15, al. (pl., iii B. C.).
speaker, Critias 54 D., Plu. Praec. 2.813a.

children.label: II
children.definition: prose-writer, Sch. D.T.pp. 114,119 H.
office of the λογευτής, PRev.Laws 11.13 (iii B. C.).
tax-collector, PRev.Laws 9.2, al. (iii B. C.), Ostr. 318, PTeb. 90 (i B. C.), etc.
cost of collection, ib. PTeb. 105.24, cf. 5 (pl., ii B. C.).

collect contributions, taxes, etc., PRev.Laws 39.14 (iii B. C.), PTeb. 5.139, al. (ii B. C.), Plb. 31.31.1, GDI 4156 ( Lindos), IG 12(5).186.4 ( Paros, ii B. C.), 12(7).237.24 ( Amorgos, i B. C.), OGI 665.37 (i A. D.), 629.156 (ii A. D.).

definition: λογία, late spelling of λογεία (q. v.).

children.definition: a physician only in words, Gal. Libr.Propr. 1, Id. 15.159, al.:—hence λογ-ιατρεία, ἡ, Ph. 1.526 (v.l. λογοιατρεία).

definition: λογίδιον, τό, Dim. of λόγος, Isoc. 13.20, Pl. Erx. 401e.

children.definition: little fable or story, Ar. V. 64.

definition: λογίζομαι, Att. fut. - ιοῦμαι Ar. Ra. 1263, Th. 5.87, etc.: aor. ἐλογισάμην E. Or. 555, Th. 6.31, etc.: pf. λελόγισμαι Lys. 32.24,27, D. 28.12:— Pass., v. infr. III: ( λόγος):—

children.definition: count, reckon, οὐκ ἐπισταμένους λογίζεσθαι Hdt. 2.16; εὗρον λογιζόμενος Id. 7.28, cf. 194, etc.; in full, λ. ψήφοισι Id. 2.36; λόγισαι φαύλως, μὴ ψήφοις ἀλλʼ ἀπὸ χειρός calculate roughly, not by rule, but off-hand, Ar. V. 656: c. acc. rei, λ. τοὺς τόκους calculate the interest, Id. Nu. 20; τρεῖς μνᾶς ἀναλώσας λογίσασθαι δώδεκα spend 3 minae and set down 12, Id. Pl. 381.
inf., reckon or calculate that . . , λ. μύρια εἶναι [τὰ ἔτεα] Hdt. 2.145; τὰς βλάβας, ἃς ἐλογίζεθʼ αὑτῷ γεγενῆσθαι D. 21.176: without acc., Θηριππίδῃ μισθὸν ἀποδεδωκέναι λ. Id. 27.20.

data.quote: τὰς βλάβας, ἃς ἐλογίζεθʼ αὑτῷ γεγενῆσθαι

children.definition: λ. τινί τι set down to oneʼs account, οὗτος . . τὸ ἥμισυ τούτοις . . λελόγισται Lys. 32.24, cf. 27; τἀνηλωμένʼ . . οὐκ ἐλογιζόμην I did not charge them . . , D. 18.113: metaph., τὰ παραπτώματα λ. τινί 2 Ep.Cor. 5.19.

children.label: b
children.definition: audit the accounts of a person, c. dat., τοῖς ὑπευθύνοις Arist. Ath. 54.2; ταῖς ἀρχαῖς ib. 48.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: take into account, calculate, consider, ταῦτα Hdt. 9.53, cf. S. Aj. 816, etc.; λ. τὰ ξυμφέροντα Th. 1.76; λ. τι πρός τινας with them, D. 5.24; also λ. περί τινος calculate, form calculations about . . , Hdt. 2.22, X. Mem. 4.3.11.

inf., reckon, consider that . . , τὸν ἕτερον [παῖδα] οὐκ εἶναί μοι λ. Hdt. 1.38; τὸν Πᾶνα τῶν ὀκτὼ θεῶν λ. εἶναι Id. 2.46; λ. ὅτι . . or ὡς . . , X. HG 2.4.28, 6.4.6; ἐλογιζόμην πρὸς ἐμαυτὸν . . , ὅτι . . And. 1.52, Pl. Ap. 21d: c. acc. et part., Σμέρδιν μηκέτι ὑμῖν ἐόντα λογίζεσθε Hdt. 3.65: also with inf. omitted, reckon or account so and so, τὸν καθʼ ἡμέραν βίον λογίζου σόν [εἶναι], τὰ δʼ ἄλλα τῆς τύχης E. Alc. 789; πολὺν [εἶναι] τὸν κάτω χρόνον ib. 692; λογίζεταί τʼ ἐκεῖνα πάνθʼ ἁμαρτίας Ar. V. 745; μίαν ἄμφω τούτω τὼ ἡμέρα λ. count both days as one, X. Cyr. 1.2.11.

data.quote: τὸν ἕτερον [παῖδα] οὐκ εἶναί μοι λ.
τὸν Πᾶνα τῶν ὀκτὼ θεῶν λ. εἶναι
τὸν καθʼ ἡμέραν βίον λογίζου σόν [εἶναι], τὰ δʼ ἄλλα τῆς τύχης

children.definition: inf. also, count or reckon upon doing, calculate or expect that . . , ἐπισιτιεῖσθαι ἐλογίζοντο Hdt. 7.176; ἐλογίζετο κατύπερθέ οἱ τὰ πρήγματα ἔσεσθαι Id. 8.136; λογιζόμενοι ἥξειν ἅμα ἡλίῳ δύνοντι X. An. 2.2.13; λελογισμένοι . . εἰσὶν . . διαζῆν E. IA 922, cf. Or. 555 (dub. l.); τί λογίζομʼ . . προσδοκῶν χάριν παρὰ γυναικὸς κομιεῖσθαι; Men. 564.

data.quote: ἐλογίζετο κατύπερθέ οἱ τὰ πρήγματα ἔσεσθαι

children.definition: count upon, εἴ τις δύο ἢ καί τι πλείους ἡμέρας λ., μάταιός ἐστιν S. Tr. 944.

data.quote: εἴ τις δύο ἢ καί τι πλείους ἡμέρας λ., μάταιός ἐστιν

children.definition: conclude by reasoning, infer that . . , c. acc. et inf., Pl. Grg. 524b, X. Ages. 7.3; λ. ὅτι . . Id. HG 6.1.5, cf. Pl. Phd. 62e, al.
τοὺς ἐπισταμένους λογίζεσθαι Archyt. 3; ὁ σπουδαῖος λελόγισται ἤδη has finished reasoning, Plot. 3.8.6, cf. 4.4.12.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., mostly aor. ἐλογίσθην and (less freq.) pf. λελόγισμαι, also in pres., part. λογιζόμενον Hdt. 3.95, freq. in later Gr., PPetr. 3p.340 (iii B. C.), Ep.Rom. 4.5, etc.; χρήματα εἰς ἀργύριον λογισθέντα counted or calculated in silver, X. Cyr. 3.1.33; ὁπλῖται ἐλογίσθησαν οὐκ ἐλάττους δισμυρίων Id. HG 6.1.19; οὗτος λογισμὸς λογισθείς Pl. Ti. 34b; οὐδʼ ἐξ ἑνὸς λόγου λελογισμένου Id. Phdr. 246c; τὸ λελογισμένον, = λογισμός, E. IA 386, Luc. Nigr.Prooem.
to be merely arguing, πρὸς ἐπίδειξιν Dam. Pr. 320, cf. 162.
of or for speaking or speech, μέρη λ. the organs of speech, Plu. Cor. 38: λογική, ἡ, speech, opp. μουσική, D.H. Comp. 11; λ. φαντασία expressed in speech, Stoic. 2.61.
of or in eloquence, ἀγῶνες Philostr. VS 1.22.1; ἀκροάσεις λ. καὶ ὀργανικαί Supp.Epigr. 2.184.6 ( Tanagra, ii B.C.).
suited for prose, ὁ ἡρῷος σεμνὸς καὶ οὐ λ. Demetr. Eloc. 42; τὸ λ., opp. τὸ μεγαλοπρεπές, ib. 41; of persons, writing in prose, D.L. 5.85; ἐγκώμιον λ. in prose, IG 9(2).531.43 (Thess.).

data.quote: ὁ ἡρῷος σεμνὸς καὶ οὐ λ.

children.label: II
children.definition: possessed of reason, intellectual, μέρος Ti.Locr. 99e, al.; τὸ λ. ζῷον Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.95; ἀρεταὶ λ., = διανοητικαί, opp. ἠθικαί, Arist. EN 1108b9.

dialectical, argumentative, οἱ λ. διάλογοι of Plato, such as the Theaetetus and Cratylus, D.L. 3.58; in Arist. usu. like διαλεκτικός, λ. συλλογισμός APo. 93a15, cf. Top. 162b27; διὰ λογικωτέρων καὶ ἀκριβεστέρων λόγων more abstract, Metaph. 1080a10; λ. δυσχέρειαι ib. 1005b22; λ. ἀπόδειξις GA 747b28; but also, logical, λ. συλλογισμοί, opp. ῥητορικοί, Rh. 1355a13. Adv. -κῶς dialectically, Metaph. 1029b13, APo. 84a7, 88a19; φυσικῶς καὶ λ. GC 316a11: Comp. - ώτερον Cael. 275b12.

children.label: b
children.definition: Subst., ἡ λογική (sc. τέχνη) logic, Cic. Fin. 1.7.22; also τὰ λογικά Id. Tusc. 4.14.33; περὶ λογικῶν title of work, Democr. 10b; τὸ λ., opp. τὸ φυσικόν, τὸ ἠθικόν, Zeno Stoic. 1.15, etc.
ἡ λ. αἵρεσις Gal. Sect.Intr. 1.
rationality, Gal. 19.481, Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 205.33, Eust. 1953.44.

definition: λόγιμος, η, ον Hdt. 2.98, also ος, ον Id. 6.106: ( λέγω B):—

children.definition: worth mention, notable, famous, πόλις Il.cc.; πόλισμα, ἔθνος, ἀνήρ, Id. 1.143, 171, 9.64; λ. ἐς τὰ πρῶτα Id. 9.16; - ώτατος ib. 37; as epith. of temples in Egypt, ἱερὸν λ. PTeb. 302.4 (i A.D.), etc. ( ἐλλόγιμος is more freq.).

oracle, esp. one preserved from antiquity, Hdt. 4.178, 203, 8.60.γ, Plu. Thes. 26, Lys. 22: more freq. in pl., oracles, Hdt. 1.64, 8.62, 141, E. Heracl. 405, Ar. Eq. 120, al., Plu. Fab. 4, Marc. 3: distd. fr. χρησμοί, Th. 2.8 (the former being prose, the latter verse, acc. to Sch., but this distn. does not hold), cf. Plu. Pel. 20, Nic. 13, 2.412c.
τὰ λ. Κυρίου the sayings of the Lord, LXX Ps. 11(12).6, cf. Act.Ap. 7.38, Ep.Rom. 3.2, 1 Ep.Pet. 4.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ λ. τῶν κρίσεων the oracular breastplate worn by the Jewish High-Priest, LXX Ex. 28.26(30), cf. Ph. 2.154; τὰ λόγια Aristeas 158.
of or belonging to λόγοι:

children.label: I
children.definition: versed in tales or stories (cf. λόγος v), λόγιοι καὶ ἀοιδοί Pi. P. 1.94, cf. N. 6.45: hence of chroniclers (opp. poets), Περσέων οἱ λόγιοι Hdt. 1.1; Αἰγυπτίων - ώτατοι Id. 2.3, cf. 4.46; so later, οἱ -ώτατοι τῶν ἀρχαίων συγγραφέων Plb. 6.45.1, cf. 38.6.1, D.S. 2.4, D.H. 5.17, etc.

learned, erudite, Democr. 30, etc.; λ. περὶ τὴν ὅλην φύσιν Arist. Pol. 1267b28; ὁ λ. Ἀκεστῖνος, of a learned physician, Hld. 4.7; οἱ - ώτατοι Τυρρηνῶν, of the Tuscan haruspices, Plu. Sull. 7; Χαλδαίων οἱ λ. Arr. An. 7.16.5, cf. J. AJ 17.6.2, etc.; λογιώτατος as title, OGI 408.5 (Theb. Aeg.), POxy. 902.1 (v A. D.), etc.; ὁ τῆς λ. μνήμης σχολαστικός PMasp. 118.30 (vi A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: skilled in words, eloquent, τὸ μεγαλοπρεπὲς ὅπερ νῦν καὶ λόγιον ὀνομάζουσιν Demetr. Eloc. 38, etc.; Arist. is said to have made Thphr. [ τὸν] -ώτατον (of his disciples), Str. 13.2.4; λ. ἐξ ἀφώνου γενόμενος Plu. Pomp. 51; epith. of Hermes, as the god of eloquence, Luc. Apol. 2, Gall. 2 ( Sup.), Jul. Or. 4.132a; οἱ λ. θεοί Id. Ep. 80; this sense is condemned by Phryn. 176. Adv. - ίως eloquently, Plu. Pyth. 2.405a; ὡς ἐνῆν - ώτατα as nearly in words as possible, of the elephant, ib. Sollert. 968d.

data.quote: τὸ μεγαλοπρεπὲς ὅπερ νῦν καὶ λόγιον ὀνομάζουσιν

children.label: III
